PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Medical Centres
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable senators and members assembled in Parliament:-
The petition of certain residents of Western Sydney draws the attention of the Parliament to the proposed legislation which may prevent X-ray services being available at medical centres.

Your petitioners therefore request the Parliament to, allow qualifying medical centres to continue to attract Medicare benefits for X-rays performed at those centres, so that this worthwhile service to the community will be able to continue.

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated and Violent Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. The petition of citizens of Australia points out:

that all State Governments, States Attorneys-General, most women's groups and the majority of men in Australia, including significant numbers of members of Parliament, are totally opposed to the importation and distribution of `X' and excessively violent `R'-rated video pornography in Australia;
that most `X'-rated material available in Australia is imported;

that the Federal Government, by its Customs power under the Constitution, and not the Australian Capital Territory Government, is solely responsible for controlling the importation of this pornographic material;
that by continuing to allow the importation of such pornographic material, the Federal Government is neglecting its responsibility to the women, children and families of Australia.
Your petitioners, therefore, request the Senate to:
1. Ban `X'-rated pornographic material at the point of entry into Australia;
2. Exclude from the `R'-rating all gratuitously violent material.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tax-file Numbers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The Petition of certain Citizens of Australia showeth:

(1) ``The adoption of the upgraded Income Tax-File Number proposal, to compel every Person to quote the number for many ordinary business dealings, would be an intrusion on the traditional liberty we have enjoyed under the Common Law and our Parliamentary Federation.

(2) ``The databanks and surveillance methods that would probably increase under this proposal would tend to provide a constant unwarranted threat to the privacy of Citizens, Residents, and perhaps Visitors and Tourists.

(3) ``There are other parallel threats to our privacy and liberties, such as: The move to give police in Australia and overseas access to our Income Tax File details, and to provide computer-based information to an international bureau in Brussels, Belgium; the proposal that the power to listen to our telephone conversations be extended from the Federal Police to the State Police; plus the financial dossiers arising from the Cash Transactions Reporting Act.

THEREFORE your Petitions pray that the Parliament defeat any Bill, or repeal any Act, to establish the compulsory use of Tax File numbers for the various transactions outlined by the Government or others. AND your Petitions, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BISHOP

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present to the Senate the following petition, from 17 petitioners, which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders as it is not in the correct form:

SPEECH.PARA: We, the members of Wesleyan Women in NSW, wish to advise that we strongly oppose some of the proposals set forth in the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child.

We feel that parents have the privilege and duty to train children in responsible citizenship and in Christian living. We believe in the freedom of the individual to exercise his right to conscientiously express his Faith, his opinions, his philosophy, within the limits of law but within the wider responsibility of obedience to Christian principle.

We feel that by implementing the complete proposals of this Convention, the basic rights of parents as Australian citizens are being eroded, and our freedom to raise our children as we would is being strictly limited.
To extend the rights of the child by denying rights of the parent is undemocratic, unthinkable and unacceptable.
We would strongly urge that this Government think again, and decline to sign the aforementioned Convention statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KERNOT

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present to the Senate the following petition, from 320 petitioners, which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders as it is not in the correct form:

SPEECH.PARA: As a citizen of Australia, I wish to bring your attention to my TOTAL OBJECTION to the Therapeutic Goods Act, 1989.
Under the guise of protecting the public against inferior therapeutic goods and devices, the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 will . . .
* prohibit advertising of vitamins, minerals, organic produce, herbal and homoeopathic medicines to practitioners and to the public;
* will impose exorbitant fees and charges on manufacturers thereby increasing the cost of natural medicines to the consumer and putting many people out of business;
* will have the effect of restricting freedom of choice of customers in their choice of medicines, health care and severely prohibit the right to self treat with home remedies;

* this Act breaches the freedom of speech, as this Act will severely fine anyone who wishes to share with another person a natural remedy; books and any printed information will also be banned by this Act. Natural remedies have a proven heritage of thousands of years and do not have to be proven by research experiment-we know they work;

* this Act is a breach of freedom of Religion as the Act will ban 44 plants plus many species. The Bible says in Genesis 1.29 that every plant is given to man for his use; and in James 5:16, ``pray for one another that you may be healed''. (If anyone is claiming healing through faith or prayer of Schedule 1 item, then it means they are making a prohibited representation which is a breach of the Act.)

I know it is my duty to keep you informed of my WILL on all matters that come before Parliament. Accordingly, it is my will that you register my concern about the Therapeutic Goods Act and the regulations to that Act. I am in favour of Natural Therapies, and it is a fundamental right to be able to exercise FREEDOM OF CHOICE in my method of health care.
Therefore, it is further MY WILL that you act to protect this FREEDOM OF CHOICE by rejecting the Therapeutic Goods Regulations which are due to be represented at the next session of Parliament.

Also, as a large number of Australian citizens object to this Act, (this we know from the media, and public debate), then I ask that this Act be annulled. It is my request that this Act be completely repealed.
I request a speedy reply to my letter, that you will be acting as my representative, to repeal the Therapeutic Goods Act at the next session of Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
notes and commends the adoption, by the General Assembly of the World Conservation Union meeting in Perth from 28 November to 5 December 1990, of resolutions including those which:

(a) call on governments, particularly the Western Australian Government, to exclude exploitative industries from national parks and nature reserves, and not to exclude land from these areas in order to allow mining in them;
(b) call on State and Federal Governments to protect wilderness qualities and biological diversity of the Kimberley region while respecting traditional Aboriginal ownership of the land;
(c) urge the incorporation of the `conservation zone' and the Jabiluka and Koongarra Project Areas into Kakadu National Park, and the nomination of stage III for World Heritage listing;
(d) call upon the Queensland and Australian Governments to immediately halt logging operations on Fraser Island and accelerate its nomination for World Heritage listing; and
(e) call upon all members of IUCN to recognise the rights of indigenous communities to participate in the formulation of policies and programs affecting their environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek a point of clarification, Mr President. It seems to me that, under standing order 142, the Minister can move that a Bill be declared urgent. Is it in order that he move, as he has just done, that a batch of this number be declared? Do they need to be put separately? Or does he require leave to seek to put the motion in the form that he has put it?
—No, he can put the motion that he has just moved. There are many precedents of its having been done this way in the past, Senator Hill.
—I would have thought that the standing order would have said `Bill or Bills', if that was to be a correct interpretation.
—This morning I did check this matter. It has been done in this form in the past, and it has been ruled to be in order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to my contingent notice of motion, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of standing order 142 be suspended as would prevent debate taking place on the motion.

I speak to the motion that standing order 142 be suspended because 142, as it stands at the moment, requires the motion that has been moved by Senator Robert Ray be put without debate. Today is a dark day in the history of the Senate when an enormous number of Bills are being sought to be declared urgent Bills basically as a result of the incompetence of the Government in the management of its business.

We warned the Government at the start of this session that it was getting into an appalling mess in relation to its program. You might recall, Mr President, that we gave notice of motions to that effect. We suffered the indignity of the Senate having to conclude its business on days without Government business before it.

We could see what was ahead with important packages of legislation foreshadowed, including: telecommunications reform, extension of the tax file number system into areas of social security, the corporations package, and the Commonwealth Bank reconstruction-not just the normal program of Bills but major pieces of legislation that clearly require careful consideration by this chamber. That is why we voiced our frustrations so early in the session that, if the Government could not get its program in order, then there was going to be trouble at the end. Such trouble has come upon us now. I have not had time to count this number of Bills. What is it?

TALK.START.PARA: —Fifty-two.

—We now have before us 52 Bills that have to be disposed of between now and Christmas-an intended further five or six sitting days. I do not know that the Senate has ever in its management of business reached a situation of this enormity.
—I think 30 was your last guillotine.

—So the Government is doubling that, is it? Early in the session we said that there were some 85 bills before the Senate and we asked why the Government could not get its program in order so that some of these could have been dealt with earlier.

SPEECH.PARA: Just consider for a moment the corporations package. This is a major package of legislation that is having to go through the Senate now because the Government did not take the advice of its constitutional advisers before and the last Corporations Bill was defeated by the High Court. We now find the situation where the corporations package has to go through the Senate today. Why? Because the Government then has to get the royal assent and then issue regulations that still have not been seen. I might say that the corporations package is pursuant to an agreement between governments that still has not been signed. Once the regulations are put down, they have got to be distributed. Practitioners have got to become aware of the law and advise their clients. Consumers of corporation law have got to become aware of their obligations. When is that package due to take effect? It is due to come into effect on 1 January.

TALK.START.PARA: —We had four hours of this last night.

—How could any consumer under company law expect to understand his obligations in that ridiculous period of time? If it was not for the efforts that we have made, there would not have even been a hearing by a committee of some of those aspects. Senator Schacht attended last night. He heard the Business Council of Australia, the Law Council of Australia and the Law Institute of Victoria all putting down their concerns about the flaws in this legislation, but this Government does not care if they are passed.

SPEECH.PARA: There are over 50 pieces of legislation before the Senate today that deserve proper and careful consideration in accordance with the standards that this Senate has sought to reach in the past. It is a matter of great regret that the Government has decided that it has no choice, as a result of its incompetence, but to seek to move the guillotine on this day. Therefore, we will oppose it. We will oppose it with all the vigour that we can muster, because the one thing that this chamber has traditionally done is to treat the legislative process seriously and endeavour to give each Bill its proper and due consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just make three or four points. When this has been done previously in the Senate-and it was consistently done between 1975 and 1980-no such debate as this occurred because the gag was moved the moment a person moved a contingent notice of motion. I do not seek to do that. I think it is reasonable, both on this and a later motion, that we have debate. The second point I want to make is in terms of Senator Hill's accusation that this chamber did not have legislation. Of course it had legislation to debate in that period in which I was absent.
—Why didn't you bring it on?

—It had industrial relations legislation which had to be put off because the requisite people were not in the chamber. That has occurred on several occasions in the life of this Parliament. But if that is the only occasion that the Opposition can refer to, a few hours, then it does not really meet Senator Hill's point. This chamber has spent an inordinate amount of time on non-legislation-most of it, I have to say, productive but some not so productive.

SPEECH.PARA: In spite of the new committee procedures, we spent 37 1/2 hours in Committee of the Whole repeating what had already been done in Estimates committees. Also, many hours were spent on the appropriations debate. There have been two other reasons why the legislative program is somewhat delayed this time: firstly, it was an election year with an abbreviated autumn sitting.

TALK.START.PARA: —You did not even call us back.
—Secondly, several major statements have been put down, including two on the Gulf, one on Cambodia, and one on micro-economic reform.
—A record low Representatives sitting year.

—I am glad that some of the recidivists here have intervened. We have heard from Senator Walters about the guillotine. Here are the Hansards from 1975 to 1980. How many times does Senator Walters's name appear, to support not only the guillotine, this sort of debate, but a gag on the debate on the guillotine? Time and time again the following Opposition senators have supported a guillotine: Senator Durack, Senator Teague, Senator Peter Baume, Senator Walters and Senator Archer. Senator Herron there puts his hand up. Senator Herron comes with clean hands; he can say what he likes and moralise to me; and I have to accept it because he is not on the record as ever supporting a guillotine. Some of our refugees from the House of Representatives are here today. How many times did they vote for guillotines in the House of Representatives?

SPEECH.PARA: This guillotine is as generous as we can make it. It is also a rolling guillotine. That is why it is introduced today, not on the last day of sitting, when those opposite have wanted to whack 30 Bills through in two hours. That is why it has been introduced today.

Some weeks ago, I revised the legislative program and kicked every Bill that we could sacrifice off the list. That was done to notify the Opposition, the Australian Democrats and the independents here of exactly what the task was between now and the end of the year. Instead of doing it last week, we did it weeks ago. This chamber has tended to meander on and on in respect of a lot of this legislation, without any discipline and without any approach. I am not going to go on the record and say that I think a guillotine is the best thing since sliced bread-if you will pardon the pun. It is not. But these are urgent Bills that are required by the end of the year.

I should also indicate-although I daresay that when the time comes I can expand these remarks-that I hope that, having put the guillotine down, the Government will not remain inflexible. If we are coming to the end of a debate-and this is not on every Bill-and more time is required, we will try to fit that in. It is not a guillotine, for instance, that excludes matters of public importance. It is deliberately framed so that most of the other activities that occur in this place can occur. It is nowhere near as ruthless a guillotine as former Senator Withers and his cohorts used to introduce in the period between 1975 and 1980 when absolute numbers applied in this chamber.

To reiterate, it is hard for anyone opposite to point to day after day when there was no legislation to deal with. There was a brief period around 8, 9 and 10 October when for half a day or a day there was not sufficient legislation to be considered. I also indicate that the Government has tightened up deadlines by which legislation has to come in. If the drafting instructions are not now lodged for the autumn session, the Bills will not be considered, with one exception, of course-Budget related Bills and economic and appropriation Bills, which are always drawn up at the last moment. The Bills we are discussing are urgent. There is no need to suspend Standing Orders to disprove that fact.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite clear that the Australian Democrats are going to support the Government's guillotine. Apparently they are not even prepared to debate the excessive use of numbers in this chamber. Senator McLean is waving his finger and arm around, as we have got used to in the last few weeks, when he himself has added to the inordinate length of debate. The Government has to take responsi- bility for the problem which has been created this session. We are programmed to sit until next Friday, 21 December, which is much later than normal, although it has occurred occasionally in the past. We are being kept here by this Government to deal with legislation which has been mounting as this session has progressed.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that, when the Government was elected in March this year, it had no real program to place before the new Parliament. It never expected to be elected at all and it never had any plan about what it would do if it were elected. It has fumbled and bumbled around as a government for months and months. In about October this year, a sudden flood of legislation was introduced into the other House and it has now found its way here. That legislation was dealt with in the House of Representatives in the fashion which has become quite usual under this Government, by putting through 39 Bills in one week under a guillotine.

In this chamber, it has not been possible for the Government to behave in this arrogant way, because in the past the Democrats took the view that they were not going to be party to it. But, as we have now seen demonstrated time and time again in this Parliament, the Democrats-under their new leadership and with their new members-are simply, as somebody has rightly said, the fourth faction of the Government. They have become totally subservient to the Government's whim and wishes on all major issues. What greater proof of that could there be than their support today of the outrageous guillotine proposed by the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray) to put 52 Bills through the Senate over the next week?

There may be the need for a guillotine from time to time. If an Opposition is being thoroughly obstructive regarding legislation, a guillotine may be justified. But it should be justified only in the case of certain Bills and in certain circum- stances. Here we have a situation which the Government has created for this chamber, for itself, where totally inadequate consideration will be given to 52 Bills. It is not as though these Bills have been given any adequate consideration by the Parliament. As I have said, they were guillotined in an even more draconian fashion through the House of Representatives only a few weeks ago.

This problem is not due to any obstruction by the Opposition or to any excessive and unnecessary debate by this chamber. It is due, as I said, entirely to the Government's mismanagement of its own program and the fact that it has not been able to get its own house in order. It has not known what it has wanted to do. It did not know what legislation it wanted to propose to this Parliament until it had had its special conference in September to get its riding instructions from the party organisation. This Government did not know what it wanted. Since it got its orders and permission from the special Labor conference in September, it suddenly decided that it wanted to show some activity and it has rushed through this Parliament all this legislation. That is what we are now being called upon to give effect to in totally inadequate debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator POWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray) has pointed out that this debate has not been gagged and will not be gagged, unlike many debates in which Senator Durack would have taken part as a member of a government in this place which did implement a gag. It is interesting to hear Senator Walters in full flight on this. I point out to members of the coalition that it will be Christmas the week after next and some of us do have homes and families that we are welcome to go back to. Senator Durack says that there is a time and a place for a guillotine, and the Christmas period has to be one of the motivations. It certainly is for me. But can we get to some more substantive issues--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I apologise to the Senate for rising on a point of order, but I am a little confused. I thought we were debating a motion to suspend Standing Orders for the purpose of debating the motion proposed by Senator Robert Ray. I was wondering whether the comments made thus far were relevant.

—Senator Harradine, you are correct, but it is very hard to work out which comments are relevant. That is one of the reasons why we have brought in the new procedures whereby people get five minutes each and at the end of half an hour the question is put. But I will remind speakers that they are supposed to be debating why Standing Orders should be suspended.

—Thank you, Mr President. Senator Hill has moved his motion to suspend Standing Orders because he believes that this declaration of Bills as urgent should not be occurring, it being, in effect, a rolling guillotine for the next week. The Australian Democrats are pursuing this particular line, as I have said, because we believe that this is the time and the place for this kind of procedure to be imposed on the Senate-for some discipline to be imposed on the Senate-unlike the performance during the appropriations debate where we had 11 hours of second reading debate and 37 hours in committee, in spite of the Estimates committees' time. There was not any change at all, even given the new committee procedures.

SPEECH.PARA: Many of the Bills which have been proposed by Senator Ray to be declared urgent have been subject to extensive debate under the new committee system under which we have been operating. Several of the significant Bills and packages have been the subject of a great deal of debate and can be and should be dealt with expeditiously by this chamber. It is interesting to note-and maybe this is part of the motivation for Senator Hill's motion and for the Opposition's plan to oppose the effective rolling guillotine-that my spokespeople tell me that in many cases Opposition shadow spokespeople still cannot tell our people what they want to do with these Bills. Clearly, the Opposition is not doing its work. There is one opposition in this place, and that is the Australian Democrats.
Opposition senators-Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, if those shadow spokespeople know what they want to do with those Bills, they should let our people know and stop lobbing amendments on at the last minute.

SPEECH.PARA: We will get a chance to test the bona fides of the Opposition in this place in the next session. There are at least two dozen Bills ready to be debated and they will be lobbed on us at the beginning of next year. It will be interesting to see how expeditiously they are dealt with. The practice and performance of this sitting period has been abominable. Two days ago, over two hours of the time of this chamber was taken up with a matter of public importance. Certainly, the rates of unemployment and bankruptcy are important, as is the proposed urgent legislation before us.

We believe that this is the time and the place for this kind of procedure. It will enable students and farmers to get their levies in place and social security recipients to get their payments-a great deal of other important things can be done. The Democrats put on record their opposition to the Government's plans for the privatisation of Aussat Pty Ltd and the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and its plans to sell off the Pipeline Authority. We will oppose the Government on many things on this list of urgent Bills. We want the chance to show that we are the only real opposition in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the contingent motion moved by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) to suspend Standing Orders. In the last two or three weeks the Opposition has debated only two matters of public importance. A matter of public importance was submitted to the Senate for discussion on Tuesday as the Opposition felt it was important to discuss the 16,030 businesses that have gone into receivership. A total of 52 Bills will be passed by guillotine. This has never happened in the eight years I have been in this place. We have had guillotines in the past, but certainly not for 52 Bills. This is a record that the Government cannot take any pride in.

SPEECH.PARA: It is obvious to me, and to everyone in Australia, that the Government is running its business in exactly the same way it is running the economy. It has caused many people to go bankrupt and it is going to bankrupt the democracy of this place.

This chamber can be relied upon to investigate legislation thoroughly-debate and democracy are supreme. This right is being taken away from the chamber. I am absolutely surprised that the Australian Democrats support the guillotine. I shudder to think what their founder and former leader would say. He always said that it was the job of the Democrats to keep the Opposition and the Government honest. Today they have vacated that position as the honest brokers of this Parliament. They have decided to take away the rights of all democratically elected senators in this place to debate the Bills coming before the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a gag.

—It is not a gag; it is a guillotine. The time requirements for this legislation are very tight indeed. We will not be able to give the Bills on the list sufficient scrutiny and debate. People should be able to express their concerns in this Parliament. The time allotted is not sufficient and will not enable us to give careful scrutiny to the legislation that is coming before us. On behalf of the National Party and the Opposition, I wish to say that the 52 Bills that have been listed today have been jammed into some type of rolling guillotine. It is the worst performance I have seen in my eight years in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McMullan just looked across my shoulder at a piece of paper I was holding which recorded one of the many occasions, regrettably, in past years-certainly not in the last eight years-where legislation was guillotined. The reason it has not happened in the last eight years is that this Government has been in office--
—And because the Democrats wouldn't do it.

—I thought I would let Senator Powell interject on her own account. Senator McMullan said to me, `That's not Senator Durack's name against the mover of that motion on the guillotine, is it?'. I said, `Yes, indeed it is'.
—It was a gag.
—It was a gag-guillotine with no debate allowed at all. I will not embarrass other senators opposite by reading out the names of those who are still here who voted--
—Go on.

—I do not have time to do so in the five minutes available to me. If I went down the list-they are all here-of those opposite who voted in divisions on gag-guillotines with no debate allowed it would be embarrassing for them all. It was particularly cheeky to hear the sanctimonious claptrap from Senator Durack this morning. I will remind honourable senators what Senator Harradine said on that occasion. The reason I do so-I was interested to see it-is that it might save Senator Harradine the trouble of repeating what he said to Senator Durack. When Senator Durack moved a gag-guillotine Senator Harradine said:

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to raise a number of points on this clause and if the Attorney-General--
that is, Senator Durack--
intends to attempt to sit me, the only national officer of a registered industrial union in this chamber, he does so at his own risk.

I do not know what the threat implied. Perhaps Senator Harradine will have the opportunity to say it again. I simply make the point, as Senator Robert Ray has already done: between 1975 and 1980-the Hansard record clearly shows this-the behaviour of those opposite when they had the numbers in this place was a disgrace. Regrettably, this is the first time in eight years that this has happened.

There has only been one sensible contribution to the debate from the opposition benches this morning on this urgency motion. To my amazement it came from the person who is significantly individually responsible for the mess that we are in-Senator Walters. She wastes more time in this chamber than most people. She made a very sensible contribution to this debate when she said to Senator Powell, `Why don't you go home?'. We moved this urgency motion for two reasons: firstly, there are important Bills on this list that the Senate has to deal with. Unless we can perform miracles and turn 24-hour days into 50-hour days, the only way-I would like to hear one person opposite suggest another-of dealing with these absolutely essential Bills--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. This is the same point of order that I raised before. On this occasion the Minister said that the reason that he is supporting the motion moved by Senator Ray is--
—I am debating urgency.

—We are not debating that motion. It is important that we follow Standing Orders. Mr President, I will be quite happy if you rule otherwise because it will set a precedent and open the way to other debates which will advantage the Opposition and myself.
—On the point of order, Mr President: I am speaking directly to the urgency motion, not the motion for the allotment of time.

—Order! I have reminded speakers before that the motion before the Chair is to suspend Standing Orders. It is not up to me to make suggestions. Perhaps the Minister could point out in his speech the reasons why he is supporting or opposing that proposal.

—Mr President, that is precisely what I am doing. The declaration of urgency is absolutely essential for two reasons. The first is that, having spent 50 hours in here on the Appropriations debate, with Senator Walters--
—You weren't here.

—I was in here for a good deal of that time. Having indulged in tedious hours of nonsensical debate, frankly, on stuff that had been canvassed to death in committees, nobody on the other side of the chamber has a leg to stand on in this respect. The only way we can, firstly, turn up in our homes I hope on Christmas day-barely-and, secondly, deal with Bills that have to be dealt with is, regrettably, through the process that the Government today is moving to institute.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly on the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders to protest at the way this Government treats debate on primary industries and energy Bills, including mining legislation. In every session since I was elected to this place, Bills to do with primary industries and energy have always been put on in the last phase, the dying hours, of the Parliament. It has happened every time. Primary industries, including mining, provide 84 per cent of this country's export income.
—What has this got to do with the suspension of Standing Orders?
—Senator Collins has had his go; now I will have mine. Primary industries and energy, including mining, provide 84 per cent of Australia's income.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT
