The list does stipulate the amount of time. As much as possible, I will try to allocate the time having regard to what I know of the amendments that are coming and the number of speakers that have been forwarded to us. If, on some of these Bills, Opposition or Democrat amendments eventuate and that particular stage of the debate has not been reached, each of those groups have contingent notices of motion that allows those amendments to be voted on. We will certainly not be trying to obstruct the use of that, if we get into a situation where we are not in the committee stage. It will allow for some sensible planning of speakers in the second reading debate and for time for the committee stage. This particular guillotine and the allocation of time is quite unlike many in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is bigger than most.

—I point to the last great guillotine moved by Senator Carrick, that Senator MacGibbon voted for, to put 16 Bills through at 8.08 p.m. in May 1980 to be carried by 10.55 the same night. So Senator MacGibbon should not come in here and start preaching to me about guillotine motions. His hands are not clean on this particular matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the real irony of the guillotine-and I might as well put this on the record-is that in the next hour we will hear a lot of argy-bargy debate from the Opposition. Some of that will come from senators with clean hands because they have never voted for a guillotine; others will be recidivist. There is only one reason why Senator Hill never voted for a guillotine, and that is because he was not preselected in 1977; he was preselected in 1980. That is the only reason he never voted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't be too sure of that.

—Come on! I have heard all the promises in the world. If Senator Hill is on this side of the chamber one day and has the numbers, he would move a guillotine motion. At least, I hope he moves one that is moved early, with at least six sitting days to go--
—Anybody would think this is the first time you have done it.
—The Boadicea of the Liberal Party opposite has voted constantly for gagging guillotine motions in the past.
—How many times have you done it?

—How many times have I done it? I have not looked up the record. But I have never resiled from doing it. I want to put the reality on the record. We will hear a lot of argy-bargy from the Opposition about the rape of democracy and the abuse of this chamber. The truth is that 80 per cent of the Opposition senators will walk out of the Senate door and be pleased that the guillotine motion has been passed. In their deep heart of hearts, Opposition senators know two things: they will say, firstly, `It is going to get me home on time at Christmas'; and, secondly, `We know the disciplined way in which the debate is going to go'. Opposition senators will not have this terrible nagging at the back of their heads that their delaying tactics will cause them to miss their Christmas turkey. That is the reality of it. They know it and I know it; they cannot say it but I can.

SPEECH.PARA: On the question of the consideration of legislation in this chamber, it is a reality that in modern times there will be more legislation than there was 20 or 30 years ago. The complexity of today's society is reflected in the need for legislation. It is not a philosophical position. I think it is a reality of the complexity of the late 20th century.

The second thing is that this year has been an election year and there has been an abbreviated autumn sitting. Even though I hear people say, `You should have had a longer autumn session', I guess that if we had called for volunteers opposite they would have been very few in number. The third aspect is how this chamber treats legislation. It is readily admitted by me that a weakness on the Government side is that legislation does not come in on time. I have admitted that and that we are trying to address that by changing the cut-off point for instructions to draftsmen, and Ministers who do not comply will have their Bills dumped. Opposition senators should acknowledge that the House of Representatives is passing 20 to 25 Bills. The Bills are not coming to this chamber this session; they will be ready and available in the autumn session.

In addition to admitting that there is some guilt on the Government side generally in terms of programming, it is also true to say that honourable senators in this chamber do have a tendency on occasions to meander. Five hours was spent debating smut on 0055 numbers. We get off when someone gives a trip report. It takes an hour and a half to relate how they have swanned around the world somewhere. This session we have had more ministerial statements than normal-and I really think it helps this chamber-and that will continue into the future. It has been a complaint of the Opposition that, too often, major announcements are made outside the chamber or at Question Time. So, on the very major issues, we are making sure that ministerial statements are available. We have gone on with disallowance motions; we have had committee reports debated at length; and we have had all sorts of Government responses to committee reports, because the more committees we have the more reports we have and the more Government responses we need. All those sorts of activities impinge on the time available to discuss legislation in this chamber and, because they impinge on that time, there is always a rush towards the end.

Later on people may ask, `Why don't you try to let goodwill work? Let the system work itself out and you will probably get most of the legislation'. I took that approach weeks ago when I detailed the amount of absolutely essential legislation that has to be passed by the end of the year. I knocked 15 to 20 Bills off the agenda then. That is normally done in the last week, but I did it well in advance so that everyone knew. There has been no concentration of the minds of honourable senators on what is a realistic timetable; that is regarded as someone else's problem. We could get up here every day and draw attention to the fact that time is slipping away and we should move on, but what good would that do? This chamber, to its credit or otherwise, is not disciplined in terms of the allocation of sensible time. What worries me about the guillotine and the rush at the end of the year is that some people are prohibited from speaking on issues about which they feel deeply and which are often very important to them. One reason they have to make that sacrifice is that earlier on, just for the sake of ego trips or whatever else, hour after hour was wasted on what most people here would regard as irrelevancies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't speak about Senator Bishop like that!

—I am not speaking about any individual senator at this stage. There is no use in being hypocritical about this: when we were in opposition we objected to the guillotine but we were never given the chance to debate the matter other than by way of points of order because debate was gagged straight away. Those were the circumstances which existed at the time.

SPEECH.PARA: I sum up by saying that the allocation of time, as much as possible, has been done on the information received about the amendments and the number of speakers required. The Government will not take a totally intolerant view on the time if on two, three or four Bills a request, by leave, is made to extend debate by another 10, 15, or 20 minutes because it has not been completed.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is very generous of you.

— Senator Short has just acknowledged the massive largess and generosity in that statement. On the other hand, that cannot be done in respect of every Bill. If this guillotine operates to the exact times-leaving aside divisions-36 hours will be available. Forty-two hours will be available, excluding Question Time and time for papers, with another four hours added over the next six days by sitting until 11.30 p.m. tonight and Monday, Tuesday and Thursday of next week. Basically that means the timetable-with two two-hour matters of public importance-can be met: that this House will rise at 3.45 p.m. on Friday and people will be able to get their flights. If they do not meet those flights, they might be lucky to get one.
—Was thought given to sitting on Friday this week?

—It was, but that would have made 10 sitting days in 12. I am conscious that some honourable senators do wish to get home, although I will not make a partisan statement about which side of the chamber they might be on. It was regarded as better to sit the extra hour at night because we would have had only four hours of Government business tomorrow. We do not intend to go past 11.30 p.m., nor do we intend to sit on Wednesday night because people need that break in the middle. We are trying to arrange the sittings in such a way that people are not run into the ground by a massive number of hours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes the motion. I will not speak at length because a number of my colleagues want to raise specific issues about the time allotted to particular Bills. In some instances they are Bills on which honourable senators have been working for many months in an individual capacity and through the committee system in this place. One has only to glance at the list that has been put before honourable senators to appreciate that the time appropriated to particular Bills is totally unsatisfactory.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the suspension motion I did not get an opportunity to say that while I am not surprised the Government is in the business of restricting debate, which is really what this amounts to, it runs contrary to everything the Australian Democrats pledged when they were established and came into this place. As one of my colleagues colourfully reminded us the other day, the Australian Democrats came in here under the pledge to `keep the bastards honest'; the Australian Democrats were never going to support a gag, a guillotine or a limitation of debate because this chamber was the chamber of debate.

We all know that the other place is not a chamber of debate; it is simply a chamber of numbers where legislation gets rubber-stamped. There was no better demonstration of that than the 37 Bills which were rubber-stamped through the House of Representatives in the last day or two of its sittings this year. There was no reason for that to have happened. The Senate is sitting weeks longer and the House of Representatives could have done so also. Since the Government has the numbers in the other place, it was not prepared to so do.

The Government does not want to debate the legislation. Once the Government says it is in the interests of the nation, that is the end of it and the parliamentary process can be damned. That is the attitude of this Government. Had the Government the numbers in this place, we would not be sitting these extra days. There would not even be the opportunity for the limited debate we have been given. These Bills would have been rubber-stamped already and the Senate would have risen. The Australian Labor Party simply sees the parliamentary process as an impediment to government. That does not surprise me because the Government has applied the guillotine before. Senator Collins was wrong when he said this is the first time in eight years that the Government has sought to apply the guillotine. The Government has applied it before.

However, this is the only opportunity for the Australian Democrats to contribute. Apparently they were elected by their constituents to contribute on these issues. I think it is appalling that they are now prepared to enter into a deal with the Government to restrict debate. I can tell the new generation of Australian Democrats that I cannot imagine Chippy being prepared to enter into a deal like this. The Australian Democrats may well want to get home early but they have an even greater responsibility, and that is to their constituents. Members of the National Party and the Liberal Party are prepared to give the proper time necessary to deal sensibly with the legislation to the best of our capacities in order to produce a better product than the Government has put up to us.

Senator Ray said that in his view some speeches by honourable senators are irrelevant. Everyone has their particular interests; they bring to this place particular expertise and particular areas of responsibility, and that is what makes this place work, when it is allowed to work well. Senator Robert Ray might regard some contributions as irrelevant but to other honourable senators and their constituents they might be highly important. Today is a disappointing day. The Government is doing what it would do so readily had it the numbers in this place-that is, simply applying a rubber stamp to the decisions of its factions and its Caucus.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the ACTU?

—Yes, and to the instructions of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. I am disappointed with this total abdication of responsibility by the Australian Democrats, who have now left no doubt that only two parties in this place-the National Party and the Liberal Party-are prepared to meet the responsibility of opposition, and we will do so. I remind the Senate that not only at the end of the year but also at the end of every parliamentary session it is said that there are too many Bills to go through in the time allotted. However, through the application of commonsense that can always be achieved. The Government does not have to go over the edge in the regulatory process in the way it is seeking to do today. The program would have been achieved and the Senate would have got through it. The Opposition has always indicated that Bills necessary to be passed in a session will be passed by this side of the chamber. We are not in the business of blocking that type of legislation, but we are in the business of seeking to do our job properly. It is of great regret that the Government will not do that and it is of even greater regret that the Australian Democrats have forfeited their right to be here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Never when we were in government was there not legislation ready for the Senate to debate. Although it has been said before, I would like to underline the fact that this year the Senate had to get up early because the Government was so incompetent it did not have legislation ready for it to debate.

SPEECH.PARA: We all remember that we had an election in March. When did we sit? We did not sit until May. The last period of sittings is the shortest time in the history of Australia that the House of Representatives has sat. This is what the Government thinks of the Parliament of this country. We are all well aware that it is the policy of the Government to abolish the upper House, so it really does not surprise me.

Do not tempt me to quote Senator Gareth Evans. Without any doubt, the abolition of the upper House was written into the Government's policies. Gareth Evans said, `Well, that does not go down too well with the people, so let us make it our aim but take it out of the written policy'. We all remember that. The Government does not have to remind us. That is the way it treats the Senate. It treats the Senate as though it were totally unnecessary and, as Senator Hill said, as just an impediment to the Executive of the Government.

The Government has the added blessing of the new committee system. I know that Senator Zakharov will agree with me when I say that her chairmanship of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs has worked extremely well. We were able to avoid hours of debate at the committee stage of one of the Bills that we looked at by saying in the committee stage that we had already gone through all that in the committee system that operates on a Friday. There was no debate at the committee stage. I would say that it saved the Government hours of debate that would have normally taken place on such a large Bill.

The Government has had the cooperation of the Opposition. It is totally the Government's fault that it is now proposing to use the guillotine. I say again to the Australian Democrats: `You promised that you would never vote for the guillotine, but we are used to your broken promises'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, but that was a different party.
—Well, they promised that they would not do it, but we see them cross over and vote with the Australian Labor Party on every occasion.
—Don't lock me into the past.

—Okay, in future I will not associate these Democrats with their original intentions and their original leader. I will say that they are different-that they are more to the left of the Labor Party. At least Don Chipp was not to the left of the Labor Party, but this new Democrats party is to the left of the Labor Party, and so every time we vote we see them cross over and vote with Senator Schacht, Senator Zakharov and the other lefties over there.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at just what the Democrats have said. Senator Powell got on her feet today and said, `I want to go home. Let's have a guillotine and get all this rubbish over'. What sort of a leader do the Democrats have? Ye Gods! For Heaven's sake, bring Chippy back. I have never heard of anything so pathetic. Do the Democrats not know why they were voted for? Are they unaware of their responsibilities in this House? Are they unaware that what they are meant to be doing is scrutinising legislation, instead of saying, `I want to go home. It's Christmas and to heck with the legislation. It does not matter that we have only an hour for the corporations legislation and only three hours for the Commonwealth Banks Restructuring Bill. That does not matter at all. We want to go home'? This is my invitation: please go home and allow those people who want to carry out their responsibilities to do so.

It really does concern me that what is carried on down in the House of Representatives, where the Government has the numbers, is now being reflected here. There is no doubt at all that the further we go the less democracy in this country is able to occur in both Houses of the Parliament. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had a two-hour meeting with Mr Keating.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, three.
—Three-and-a-half.

—Three or four; it depends whom one listens to. They came up with a six-line agreement after that many hours. Within a few hours the whole thing was scrubbed because the Prime Minister then went to a press conference and said, `No, I will be here forever'. I have got news for you lot: you will not be here after the election. And, fortunately, the Democrats will be decimated, too.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats say that they listen to debate. We were lectured the other day by Senator McLean, who told us that they listened to debate-remember?-and that they do not come in here with preconceived ideas. I hope that they have listened to debate today. I hope that we have reminded them of their past promises and of what they went to the electorate on, and I hope that they will on this occasion refrain from voting with the Labor Party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —A great deal of hot air passes in this place. What we have just heard-and I was disappointed to hear it from Senator Hill, no less-is a complete denial of the reality that goes on in this place. Honourable senators talk about debate. They are locked in as parties, and they know full well before they even come into this place precisely how they are going to vote on particular issues. The so-called debates are not debates at all.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Opposition for pointing out that Senator Herron did cross the floor the other day, along with Senator Peter Baume and Senator Archer. That is an extremely rare occurrence. I have spoken with many members of both the Government and the Opposition after a vote has been taken and have been told, `I did not agree with that vote, but I simply voted with the Party'.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the reality. The second reading stages of debates are not debates at all. One comes in here with prepared speeches and positions, and nothing whatsoever is changed. As Senator Powell pointed out, we have spent hour after hour, day after day, on the appropriation debates, so-called, and not one thing has changed.

The Opposition simply votes, with a rare exception, as a bloc. Today we have an adequate opportunity to deal with important legislation. It may well be true that the second reading stages of Bills will be truncated but, as I have indicated, nothing happens in them. The second reading stage is not a debate. That occurs in the committee stage. Even there, since I have been in this chamber, very rarely have we had real debates. I recall the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission debate, which was a real debate. It went on for a very long period of time, and people changed their position. That is very rare.

Will there be any change in position at all on the majority of Bills that are before us at the moment? Because of the committee system that Senator Walters has drawn attention to, mostly the positions are known, the positions can be put. We will see Government and Opposition vote as blocks, and nothing will change as a consequence of that. Senator Ray indicated in introducing this motion that the Government will look at changes to times. As we go along, some extra time may be needed on some Bills. It seems to the Democrats that that situation is perfectly adequate to deal with the Bills which are before the Senate, particularly bearing in mind the enormous procrastination and waste of time which has gone on in this chamber in this session on the part of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the remarks made by Senator Hill and Senator Walters in discussing this absolutely disgraceful truncation of the time of the Senate for the consideration of Bills for which we have been elected to come to this place to legislate and give consideration to. The excuses that the Australian Democrats have made today, particularly Senator Powell, for supporting this guillotine and breaching every promise they have ever made to the electorate of Australia that they would never do this are absolutely pathetic. That is being reflected in the opinion polls about the Democrats around this country. The Democrats had better make the most of this term because they are not going to be here after the next election, particularly after today's performance.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to point out a couple of things. This is not just a guillotine in the Senate. Most of the Bills that are to be guillotined over the next six days were also guillotined in the House of Representatives, so there will be a double guillotine on most of them. Some of the Bills that I have responsibility for in this chamber-and I will come to those in a moment-went through the House of Representatives in maximum times of up to 40 minutes, some of them down to 15 minutes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Six minutes.

—Some of them, as has been said by others, were dealt with in as short a time as six minutes. It is not just a denigration, as Senator Walters said, of the Senate that is involved in this process; it is a denigration of the whole of the parliamentary legislative process-the whole process on which this democracy of Australia is based.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation is that 52 Bills are to be guillotined through this place. I do not know whether people listening to this debate know what we are talking about. We are talking about pushing Bills right through all the processes in the Senate, and some of them in no more than 30 minutes. There is only one reason why that is happening. I hate to say this to Senator Ray because he is not a bad bloke in some other respects, but as Manager of Government Business in the Senate he is hopeless. There has been a totally incompetent--

TALK.START.PARA: —He was away for a while; Richo helped him.

—He had a bit of help from a couple of others, I admit. The Government has been totally incompetent in its management of the legislative program. I am probably being a bit unfair to Senator Ray. It is not just Senator Ray; it is the whole of the process of government that led, in the early part of this session, to us almost having to walk out of the Senate because there was nothing to debate, because the Government had not been able to produce even one Bill for us to debate.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a drift in this place over weeks and weeks now. There has been no evidence of any form of planning of the legislative program. Now we are being forced to guillotine legislation that is worthy of much greater debate. Senator Ray magnanimously said that he is going to be fairly flexible on this, that he will allow for sensible planning over the next six days. I asked, `What does that mean?'. He said that if we are running a bit late on a Bill he will give us another 10 or 15 minutes in which to debate it. As I said, big deal!

There are many important amendments to very important pieces of legislation to be considered over the next few days. In the tax area, for example, there are some major pieces of legislation affecting a large number of Australians. Senator Watson, if he gets a chance in this debate, will say something about that. For example, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Income) Bill is going to be debated with two other important tax Bills. The total time for debate on all of that is 1 1/2 hours. There are fundamental flaws in that Bill which require amendment and require proper consideration. That is not going to take place at all, given what has now happened today.

The Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill, the biggest package of measures dealing with the law and the administration of corporations in Australia, has been allotted one whole hour for debate and consideration. The Commonwealth Banks Restructuring Bill, a major Bill, will get three hours. It will get more, I think, than any other Bill. One of the reasons for that is that it was such a cataclysmic and traumatic exercise for the Government even to be able to get its left wing power brokers and its trade union dictators of what it does here to allow it even to sell 30 per cent of the bank. The Commonwealth Bank should be 100 per cent privatised. The issues involved in the Commonwealth Banks Restructuring Bill go to the whole heart of a large part of public sector management and aspects of ownership and control in Australia, and it is being guillotined in three hours.

The Pipeline Authority (Charges) Bill is going to get 45 minutes; it got even less in the House of Representatives. That is a Bill to set in train the privatisation and the sale of the Moomba to Sydney Gas pipeline. So badly has the Government handled this whole exercise that it has been in the courts for months and the processes it has been following have been found by the courts of Australia to be illegal. The Government is going to try to push that Bill through this Parliament. I hope the Democrats are going to stick with what they said last week and oppose it. There are fundamental issues there that need to be debated and we are going to have 45 minutes to deal with that Bill.

The Commonwealth Funds Management Limited Bill is going to get 30 minutes. That Bill is about corporatising the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust, turning it into quite a different animal. That fund deals with something like $6 billion of superannuation funds, and there are faults in that Bill as well. All that is to be pushed through this place in 30 minutes. Other major asset sales, relating to the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation in particular and some other related aspects of further asset sales, will receive 45 minutes. Again, there are major issues there to be debated.

We are seeing here yet another example of the determination of this Government, supported now by its fourth left wing faction, the Democrats, to further prostitute the proper parliamentary processes and democratic procedures of this nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to stem the flow a bit. I could have written the speeches for all of the sanctimonious claptrap, nonsense and hot air that has been delivered in this debate this morning, all of it anticipated, because I have written such speeches in the past when in opposition. I have made this observation on past occasions: on matters of political principle there is a huge gap between government and opposition. But I have noticed over the 14 years that I have been in this business that on certain issues, particularly issues of parliamentary procedure, for some strange reason absolutely separate from the political complexion of whichever party is on the government side of the House, governments tend to sound like governments and oppositions tend to sound like oppositions. I notice from the smile on Senator Bjelke-Petersen's face that she probably agrees with me.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that guillotine and gag motions were moved on a fairly routine basis in the House that I spent 10 years in. The only substantial difference in the speeches I have heard from the Opposition this morning and what I used to say in the Legislative Assembly is that I used to do it better. I have said it all.

The Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray) has pointed out repeatedly in the debate this morning, without getting a response from the Opposition-I, too, tried to get a rise from the Opposition and failed-that a number of people, most of whom have spoken already in this debate, really have no right to speak. Senator Walters is certainly one of them.

If Senator Ray, with all of the abuse that has been heaped on him this morning, had attempted to apply a gag-guillotine in the routine way it was applied by the Opposition when in government, then the Opposition would have something to complain about. In respect of my experience in the Senate and the democratic process being impeded by putting in a bit of discipline on time spent on legislation, if the quantity of debate was directly relative to the quality of the end product, without doubt this chamber would produce the best legislation in the world. I think it is probably arguable whether it does or not.

The harsh reality is-to use an expression much favoured by Andrew Peacock-that we in the Senate tend to debate everything in front of us to death; we bludgeon it to death with debate. Very little discipline is exercised by the Opposition in respect of debates with its own members. Senator Ray has made an allusion to it this morning and I share with him the regret that he has expressed. I believe that these are chambers for debate. If people have strong views on a subject they are entitled to debate them. I have the same irritation when people on both sides of this chamber get up in debate-and they have certainly done plenty of that this parliamentary year-and simply talk for the sake of talking.

This is truth time. Senator Ray has delivered the most substantive contribution to the truth debate this morning, the Realpolitik of this debate, and I intend to add to it. To the credit of Senator Durack, he tried to exercise a bit of gentle discipline with his own side. He stood up in the second reading debate on the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 and remonstrated very gently with members of his own side that perhaps there was no need to prolong the debate unnecessarily. It availed him nothing. We had hour after hour of absolutely useless debate in respect of that particular legislation, which has been repeated. The one criticism we could not deliver at this chamber--

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't elevate it by the term `debate'.

—That is a very valid interjection. We should not elevate a lot of it by the expression `debate'. The one criticism that could not be routinely levelled at this chamber is our lack of capacity or willingness to debate subjects, which is second to none. The application of this kind of guillotine is a rare event. A much gentler guillotine is being applied on this occasion. As we have not voted on it as yet, I should say that this is a much gentler guillotine than has been applied in the past. The early stages of the debate this morning were led by Senator Durack. He has moved guillotines in this chamber on previous occasions. This just shows how hollow and sanctimonious this debate really is.

SPEECH.PARA: Contributions have been made this morning regarding Senator Ray's alleged lack of involvement in attempting to get some rationality into the debate on an earlier occasion. He did precisely that: lists were produced and discussions were held weeks ago, much earlier than in past years. It availed the Manager of Government Business in the Senate nothing. It fell on deaf ears, which is why we are in this position at present. As I said before, it is easy for Senator Walters. In defence of Senator Powell, I want to inject a bit more truth into this debate. Senator Powell was attacked rigorously by Senator Walters this morning for dereliction of duty and not fulfilling the role to which she has been elected-and various other claptrap.

I want to put something else on the record. If we are going to sit forever and we have a Senate that places no regard-I support healthy debate in the Senate and support everyone getting a go, everyone usually does in here--

TALK.START.PARA: —Sit down, and let us have a go now.
—I have a few more minutes left which I am entitled to, and I am going to take them.
—Talking for the sake of talking.

—I am not talking for the sake of talking. This is a little bit of truth in the face of claptrap. With the greatest respect, it is easy for Senator Walters to make those accusations against Senator Powell. Senator Walters has reached a point in her personal life and she has the hide to talk about people not living up to their responsibilities--
—She is one of the hardest workers in the Parliament. What a lot of rubbish.

—I am confirming that. I am praising Senator Walters, not condemning her-but I am defending Senator Powell. It is easy for Senator Walters to sit here and say that the majority of her responsibilities are in this chamber or on the committees of the Senate. It is easy for her to say that at this time of her life, but there are some members of the chamber who do have families. In my case--

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Robert Ray interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —That is dead right. A little bit of truth in this debate is a breath of fresh air. It is easy for some senators in this chamber-I will not single out Senator Walters-to say that they have no difficulty in sitting here week after week and month after month. But some of us are not in that position; some of us have responsibilities. To be fair, only two responsibilities concern most senators-the Senate and their family. A few senators in this place occasionally need to get home.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion I will repeat what Senator Ray said this morning as it is worth repeating. In the face of all the claptrap delivered this morning, he said-most Opposition senators could not keep a straight face while he was saying it-that 80 per cent, but I will upgrade it to 90 per cent, of those opposite will walk out of this debate and say, `Thank God that was passed and not defeated'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I take this opportunity to congratulate you today as it has been fifteen years since you were elected to this chamber.
—And you too, Senator Harradine.

—The guillotine motion is very serious because it takes away and limits the rights of individual senators of this chamber. That is why I am going to oppose this motion. It appears that I am the only one who has voted consistently on guillotine motions. I am not referring to the people who have not been present when guillotine motions have been put. I have taken a deliberate attitude towards this matter. It is a limitation of the rights of individual senators on behalf of their constituents.

SPEECH.PARA: I have heard all of the arguments before-all of them-except one of the key arguments put forward by Senator Ray and by Senator Collins, that too much time was spent on the appropriations. Who is to say whether too much time was spent on the appropriations?

TALK.START.PARA: —I can say that.

—Senator Coates can say it from his point of view, but who else can say it? The point is that here we have billions of dollars being appropriated and it is our responsibility to exercise our function of audit and control to ensure that that money is properly spent.
—We have Estimates committees.

—That is why we have Estimates committees, Senator Coates. Senator Ray talks about truth, but he said something that was totally untrue when he insinuated that the Senate wasted five hours on smut when discussing the 0055 service. That is untrue. It shows Senator Ray is ignorant of the issues involved and is not prepared to tell the truth on this issue.
—It is a matter of judgment.

—It is not a matter of judgment, it is a matter of looking at the Hansard and seeing how much time was taken. If one looks at the time that was taken on questions asked by me and by other senators, one will see that in so far as 0055 is concerned, it was around about an hour and 45 minutes. That was for questions. Senator Collins, on the other hand, was the one who was at fault because he obviously could not understand what the implications were, and if one studies that document one will see that. Senator Ray glibly made that statement. He obviously did not know that I raised this issue in the Estimates committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that the officer of Telecom Australia, Mr Stan Fish, Manager of the External Relations Branch of the Office of the Corporate Secretary, was present at the Estimates committee, and the Minister indicated that there was no-one present at the Estimates committee who could answer the questions. We had present the man who was writing to my constituents about 0055 and the Discovery service. The Discovery service was an important issue, similar to 0055. The real issue was whether the Federal Government should permit Telecom to act in effect as the publisher and agent of sexploit profiteers undermining the status of women in Australia. If Senator Ray thinks that is of no interest then let him be judged on that. If Senator Collins thinks that is of no interest, let him be judged on it-and he will be. Whilst I am on that subject, certain questions were asked by me in the Committee of the Whole which have not been answered. Senator Collins said that answers would be obtained, and those questions have still not been answered.

The same goes for the Attorney-General's Department portfolio. Senator Tate was asked questions about the role of Justice Elizabeth Evatt on the international committee on the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women. Those questions have not been answered. With regard to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans has not yet answered questions that I raised at the Estimates committee. I put the Government on notice that I am getting sick and tired of not getting the answers to the questions. I have been waiting and waiting. So far as the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is concerned, I have been waiting two years for answers to questions that I have been raising with Senator Evans on violations of human rights in China and various other places. Still those questions are not answered. Does he not think they are important?

TALK.START.PARA: —He's given you the answers.
—He has not given me the answers, and he knows it-and he has said it. Does Senator Coates think that Senator Evans has given me the answers?
—Yes.
—Senator Coates does?
—You have disagreed with him.

—No; it is because he has promised me the answers, and Senator Coates should have a look at Hansard. He will note that these answers have not been given. If that is the way the Government is going to treat this then there are a number of ways under the Standing Orders in which I can act, and I will act on them now that I know the Government is obstructive and is not prepared to give me the answers on important questions on violations of human rights. Senator Coates and Senator Evans are not prepared to give me the answers, so I am prepared to stand up here for human rights and I am going to use the Standing Orders of this Senate to make sure that the Government very clearly gets the message. I finally say that I am disappointed that the Australian Democrats for the first time--
—Not the first time, it has been four years.

—I am sorry, it is the first time for four years that the Senate has been prepared to vote for the guillotine. I am disappointed in that and, as far as I am concerned, I am going to maintain consistency. I admit consistency is not everything in this life, but at least I am going to be consistent and vote against this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The unrealistic allocation of time by the Government in guillotining important Bills currently before the Senate is a reflection of a lack of communication between members of the Executive Council. When undertakings are given by responsible Ministers and Parliamentary Secretaries, reasonable people should be entitled to rely upon those undertakings being honoured.

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberal-National Party coalition, on the understanding that there would be adequate time allocated to the Tax Laws Amendment (Foreign Income) Bill, decided that the Bill could be fully debated in this chamber-we were given that undertaking-rather than be referred to a Friday Senate standing committee. Because of the importance of the issue, we now ask that tomorrow be allocated so that undertaking can be fulfilled. A request should be made by the Government that the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration be convened to examine the committee stages of what is a very important piece of legislation.

If I can speak to just one Bill, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Income) Bill comprises the most complex set of amendments ever to find their way into taxation laws. These amendments mask even the momentous capital gains changes which the courts have described as confusing, unintelligible, badly drafted and a nightmare for interpretation. It is important that we discuss the issues involved so that the wider community can take on board the matters that are going to be raised within this debate.

It is unfortunate that the coalition was ready for this debate weeks and weeks ago, perhaps even months ago, but because of the Government's priorities the Bill has slipped down the debating order of importance, and now a sensitive and important Bill is going to be guillotined to 1 1/2 hours. This compares with three hours for the Commonwealth Banks Restructuring Bill, and that Bill has already been to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. Surely the Government should be prepared, within this guillotine arrangement, to set aside tomorrow. This would be at some inconvenience to members, but I am prepared to sit and I hope others are, and I hope the Government can in this way honour its undertaking to the people of Australia and particularly to this Senate.

The Government must be impressed, to some extent, with the discipline that the Liberal-National Party coalition has exercised in relation to taxation debates. The issues of irrelevance that Senator Collins has raised could not be pointed in this direction. I refer to the debate yesterday, for those who have short memories, on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5), when the three contributors on this side deliberately limited themselves to the issues for which they have personal responsibility. I also express some disappointment in the attitude of the Australian Democrats in supporting this guillotine motion. Perhaps it would be more appropriate if they called themselves the `New Democrats', because what they are doing today is a far cry from their original charter.

It is important that we look at the issues involved in the debate subject to guillotine so that outside contributors can come in and focus on those issues in those Bills. Is it all that important that all the guillotine legislation is passed? It is more important that we get the Bills right. The coalition has assured the Government that it will give priority to getting through Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) expeditiously because that Bill involves, among other issues, tax cuts to ordinary people which were announced on 20 November. That is not a Bill that has been declared urgent. The Government is seeking to create a precedent to set up those tax changes effected through regulations. We understand that this procedure has received some sort of authority from the Attorney-General's Department. I regret that, despite requests, this information and this brief have not yet been given to the Opposition. We believe this is a denegation of the rights of the legislature and again reflects the position of the Executive vis-a-vis the Parliament. It is indeed a sad day for democracy when we have to resort to that sort of practice which overlooks the rights of the Parliament. In the guillotining of this sort of legislation, important issues and important rights are being sacrificed. We cannot afford to sacrifice democracy, rights issues, et cetera, merely for the personal convenience of honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate is about management. It is about whether or not the Government has ordered its business in such a way that there can be proper debate and discussion of important legislation that comes before this chamber. What we have seen in fact is incompetence. What we have seen is lack of management. In this particular list of so-called urgent legislation-and, indeed, this and perhaps other pieces of legislation that are not even listed could be termed `urgent' in the concept of legislation which is required-are two Bills that concern me particularly. Firstly, the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990 and, secondly, the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990 concerning computers.

SPEECH.PARA: What makes a piece of legislation urgent in the eyes of the Government? As far as the bounty Bill is concerned, the Government before the end of the financial year forgot about that scheme and forgot that it required new legislation. In the interim, we have had press releases and a promise to bring in the legislation. The question arises whether any of the payments that are made between the expiry of the scheme and the passing of legislation will indeed be valid. Yet we have been given a very short period of time in which to debate this matter.

It is a management question. We have seen incompetence by the Government. It is concertinaing debate through this chamber, and the price of denied debate is poor legislation. We have seen plenty of poor legislation coming from the Government, and we have to subsequently remedy the mistakes that the Government makes. This concertinaed program that we have been presented with today simply means that, once again, we see a government that is not in control of its own business.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

That the motion (Senator Robert Ray's) be agreed to.
