DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill 1990.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL 1990CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL 1990PETROLEUM EXCISE (PRICES) AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 December, on motion by Senator Collins:
That these Bills be now read a second time.
upon which Senator Parer had moved by way of amendment:
Leave out all words after ``That'', insert:

``the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1990 be now read a second time, and that consideration of the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1990 and the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Amendment Bill 1990 be deferred until the money which is determined to be due and payable to Bass Strait crude oil producers by the decision of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal on 12 December 1990 has been ascertained and refunded to the producers.''

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am concluding my remarks on the second reading on the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1990 and the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Amendment Bill 1990 to which the Opposition has moved a second reading amendment. The amendment seeks to give effect to a decision which was handed down by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT). I exhort members of all parties in this chamber to carefully consider the consequences of not supporting this amendment. The Government has moved the goalposts while the game was still in play and honourable senators, who in this case are acting as the umpire, must act to ensure the goalposts are moved back to the place where the contest started, otherwise it will be impossible for justice to be done for the players who, in this instance, happen to be the Bass Strait partners.

SPEECH.PARA: If this amendment is not supported, every citizen and every business will be on notice that they can no longer expect certainty with our laws-and worse, that by this type of legislation they can, and will, be prevented from mounting any sort of successful and effective challenge to that legislation. The purpose of this amendment and the subsequent committee stage amendments is simply to allow an appeal to the AAT to be given effect and not aborted by legislation which is blatantly retrospective.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak to two of the Bills very briefly: firstly, the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Amendment Bill 1990 and, secondly, the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1990, to which Senator Parer has directed so much attention in relation to Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd's (BHP) exploitation of wells in Bass Strait. The Australian Democrats do not oppose the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Amendment Bill. We recognise that the amendments contained in this Bill are necessary since the principal Act, as it now stands, applies only to offshore petroleum production areas and the Government, quite correctly, seeks to incorporate onshore areas into the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Act, as it was initially drafted, failed to anticipate at that time that any onshore petroleum production operation would ever reach the 30 million excise-free barrels limit in this country. Accordingly, the Democrats agree that these amendments are necessary so that the definition of oil producer is expanded to include onshore producers as well as those operating in an offshore capacity. The Democrats have been advised that cumulative production from the Jackson oilfield in south-west Queensland will exceed the 30 million barrel excise-free limit early in the new year but, as Senator Parer has already pointed out, even with this field this amendment may not apply for other reasons. In the spirit of the principal legislation, it is absolutely appropriate and proper that production from the Jackson oilfield and other onshore producers become liable for petroleum excise.

In relation to the retrospective commencement dates under clause 3 of this Bill, the Democrats have a longstanding opposition to retrospective legislation. Nevertheless, we believe that under certain circumstances that is not an absolute impediment to retrospective legislation. In this case, we believe that the commencement clause being backdated to 26 December 1987 is justifiable, since it involves bringing all producers onto a level playing field-something much touted by the Opposition as a desirable goal, as was clearly intended in the original legislation and as is appropriate. Significantly, this legislation will not prejudice or unfairly affect any person's rights or legitimate expectations.

The operation of this amending legislation is prospective in its application. It is important to stress that the regulations under the Act will not operate retrospectively. This is the essential point of debate on this legislation. The Senate must appreciate that the regulations will operate prospectively and not retrospectively. The Democrats remain opposed to legislation that includes elements of retrospectivity within it, but it is important that we judge each Bill on the reasons it has been introduced. Accordingly, the Australian Democrats will not be opposing this Bill; nor will we be supporting any Opposition amendments in this instance.

I return to the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill, which is the one in greatest contention. I thank Senator Parer for making several comments in relation to greenhouse and several in relation to former Senator Chipp, whom he quoted as saying that he found retrospectivity repugnant and that there should be substantial reasons for accepting retrospective legislation. We believe that there are substantial reasons in this particular case. BHP has been paying excise with respect to several wells in the Bass Strait region at the old oil rate since 1980. This amending Bill seeks to correct an error which crept into an amending Bill which was passed in 1984.

As I have said, no-one likes retrospective legislation. The Government should be very closely scrutinised when it proposes retrospective legislation, particularly when legal action has already begun under the law as it stands and prior to a case being adjudicated on before the courts in which the Government seeks to change the ground rules, as it were.

In this case, I believe, the Government has been negligent in its responsibility in not properly scrutinising over the last six years, that is, between 1984 and March 1990, the sections of this legislation in which BHP found that there was a defect, which defect it sought to use before the courts. It seems to me that the responsibility is fairly and squarely on government to continually scrutinise its own legislation and to attempt to discover loopholes and defects and to close them before matters come before the courts.

In this case, the Customs officers have had six years to find this drafting error and correct it. It was left to BHP to find the error and to bring a case, as Senator Parer has pointed out, before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. It was only at that stage, unfortunately, that the Government chose to correct this error. I believe that, as far as possible, this should simply not happen.

However, as I have already indicated, our opposition to retrospectivity is not absolute. I point out, as Senator Spindler has already, that the Opposition accepts that the public good is more important than the retrospective law concerning the legitimate confiscation of dangerous weapons, which goes back much further than 1984. I understand that the Opposition is quite prepared to accept that piece of retrospective legislation, which will legitimise an action which the courts have already ruled was illegal. There we have an instance where the court case has already been held. The Opposition quite clearly is prepared to accept retrospectivity, under certain circum- stances.

I would like to draw a parallel with a piece of legislation recently passed in South Australia, because the principle on which we rely in this case to support this retrospective legislation is best illustrated by that example. In the case of the proposal to build a tourist development in the Wilpena Pound National Park, the South Australian Government acted contrary to several laws in South Australia, including the laws under the national parks Act and the planning Act, which required the preparation of environmental impact statements. As a consequence of that illegal action, the Australian Conservation Foundation and the Conservation Council of South Australia sought to take action against the Government of South Australia.

Just as in the case of BHP in relation to this Excise Tariff Amendment Bill, the legal advice was that both those conservation bodies had an extremely good chance of success and that indeed the Government had acted illegally with respect to two quite separate pieces of legislation. In that instance, the South Australian Labor Government sought to pass retrospective legislation to change the legislation and essentially to pull the rug from underneath the Australian Conservation Foundation and the Conservation Council of South Australia. The Liberal Opposition in South Australia jumped up and down about that just as much as the Opposition in this place has jumped up and down about retrospective legislation but, when it came to the vote in the upper House in South Australia, the Liberal Opposition collapsed completely and supported retrospective legislation.

I think it needs to be put absolutely fairly and squarely on the record that the Liberal Opposition in the Legislative Council of South Australia took a totally different position with respect to the important protection of a national park in the Flinders Ranges in South Australia-an area, incidentally, that has been suggested for World Heritage status.

In that particular instance-and this is the reason I use this example-everybody in the South Australian community, including the Government and the conservation groups, believed that the law meant a certain thing and operated in a certain way. The legislation there changed the way in which the law was understood and the way in which the law was expected by everybody to operate.

In the particular case before us today, we have retrospective legislation which does not in any sense change the way in which the law was intended to operate or was interpreted prior to 1984, or has been interpreted from 1984 right through until March 1990. Everybody believed that the law meant a certain thing and operated on that assumption. Indeed, BHP con- tinued to pay the excise at the old oil rate. It was only when a technical defect was discovered in the amending law of 1984 that BHP believed that it had a loophole which would allow it to claim that this oil was new oil and not old oil.

I believe it is not honest of Senator Parer to have claimed that everybody agreed that the oil was new oil and not old oil. Everybody agreed that the oil was new oil, based on the wording in the amending 1984 Bill. There is no contention about that. The point is that right throughout the period everybody believed-the Government believed and BHP believed-that the oil was not new oil but old oil. If BHP had believed it was new oil, for six years it had a perfectly legitimate mechanism by which it could have objected to that. That did not happen until this technical loophole in the law was discovered and action was taken in March 1990. In the present case, we have an amending Bill which retrospectively changes the wording of a 1984 Bill but does not change the way in which that Bill was intended to operate and the way in which everybody believed it should operate and the way in which everybody operated under that Bill.

The Wilpena legislation, which, as I indicated, the Opposition supported, not only changed the legislation but changed the intention of the legislation, changed the way everybody understood the legislation would operate, and effectively changed the way in which the legislation did operate. It pulled the rug from underneath the Australian Conservation Foundation and the Conservation Council of South Australia.

It was interesting that BHP in its letter made a considerable point that it was concerned primarily not about the amount of money involved, but about the principle of retrospectivity. At this stage the retrospective legislation in South Australia had not yet gone through the upper House. I asked BHP whether it would write a letter to the Advertiser saying, `Here is this piece of legislation which is retrospective. We think the principle is important and we object to this on a matter of principle'.

I said to Senator Parer, `Here is this retrospective piece of legislation which your people in South Australia are going to support in the South Australian upper House. You believe this is a matter of principle; will you simply write a letter to the Advertiser expressing your abhorrence on this important matter of principle?'. Both BHP and Senator Parer took no action on that matter. The Opposition is clearly not interested in protecting national parks; it is interested in collecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. At present we are operating under a guillotine which has been imposed on the Senate by the Government and the Democrats. One hour has been allocated for the remaining stages of this Bill, as I understand it. Any way you look at the number of senators, either at the total of 76, or at the Democrats' share of eight of the total, it seems to me that Senator Coulter is being extremely greedy having taken 15 minutes of that hour already. There are other speakers on the list. There are committee stage amendments. I wonder where we are going and how we are going to get there if the Democrats seek to take this length of time. Senator Spindler spoke previously in this debate. I would have thought 10 minutes was more than a fair thing and I would like to know where we are getting.
—There is no point of order.

—I have only a couple of moments and a few brief points to make. The situation is that the Opposition has already had three-quarters of the time which has been used so far. We have pulled one speaker off the speakers list. Senator Bourne will not be speaking. I have told the Opposition that it will have, as far as I am aware, all the remaining time, which is two-thirds of the hour.

SPEECH.PARA: The point that I am stressing is that we will not be supporting the amendments in either form being put by the Opposition. Therefore, the committee stage can be considerably truncated because our position is quite clear. The principle on which we are not supporting this retrospective legislation is that the way this legislation was intended to operate, the way it was understood to operate and the way it did operate and was accepted by all players until March 1984, is not being changed by this Bill. It is simply a technical change in the legislation.

Finally, there is one section of this Bill which imposes a 5c a litre-I think it is better to express it in that form-excise on liquefied petroleum gas (LPG). I express some concern that at this time, when many people are having motor vehicles changed from petrol to LPG as a cost saving measure and as a measure which will address the problem of imports of foreign oil and also the problem of greenhouse to some extent, the Government is seeking to increase the price of LPG by as much as 5c per litre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1990 with very limited time as a consequence of the Australian Democrats having agreed with the Government to guillotine legislation. I will try to keep my remarks as brief as I can.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation has been outlined reasonably clearly by earlier speakers but for the benefit of those people who may be listening on this broadcast day and the people in the gallery I will explain the situation with respect to one aspect of this Bill. There is some oil in the Bass Strait that excise has been paid on since 1984 as though it were old oil. The Government passed legislation in 1984 intending to describe and classify that oil as old oil. That is what the Government thought it had done. It now finds out that is not what it has done. This particular oil in the Tuna oilfield is actually new oil. That means that the producers have been paying excise at a much higher rate and now they want some money back.

The Government wants to say, `Hold on, you can't have this money back because we thought all along it was old oil. The fact that we didn't make it old oil by legislation does not matter; we are going to make it old oil by retrospective legislation'. The Democrats are getting into this ugly little plan on the basis of saying, `Well, the producers thought it was old oil as well'. That is not what the producers are saying. They do not say that they agreed that it was old oil.

Let me outline the basis on which the Government and the Democrats say that the producers should be judged as having agreed that this is old oil. It says that they have not complained, as if there is some responsibility on a private citizen-because it happens to be a company in this instance it is no different-to check out Government legislation, to thoroughly scrutinise legislation and to point out to the Government when it is wrong. The cost of not doing that is to have the legislation operating on citizens as though it said what the Government meant it to say. It sounds like Richard Nixon-`I know what I said and I know what I meant to say'. It is just not on.

The law is meant to be like a map-hopefully we will get it in plain English one day-that we can follow. We are meant to be able to follow it to the letter of the law. If the law says that we can go up alleyway A the Government is not entitled to say, `Hold on, we meant to call that alleyway B'. We are entitled to rely on what the law says. The Democrats say that we can throw that out. I suspect that part of the reason they say that is that the citizen being affected in this case is a corporate citizen and a big one. If this were one of their constituents that they are constantly seeking to bestow favours on it would not be the case. But because it is a big corporate citizen somehow this principle changes-big corporate citizens can afford to lose money; they can afford to be told that the law was that but now we are going to change it back to something else. That is what we are facing.

I agree with one aspect of what Senator Coulter said; that is, retrospectivity is not something that we dislike per se. There is a reason we dislike it. It is not as though we have opened a fridge to find a container we do not like the colour of so we will never look at it again. There is some reasoning behind this. The reasoning is that if we have retrospective legislation we take peoples' rights away retrospectively. They operate on a certain basis for a period of time and then all of a sudden the Government says, `We're going to go back before that time and we are going to change what you are entitled to do'. The Government is going to take rights away. That is one of the reasons there is almost a unanimous agreement that retrospective legislation is generally a bad thing.

The other reason is that for the community to operate-I do not mean by that just the business community-and for citizens to follow the law they have to have some certainty as to what the law is. How are they to have that certainty? They do not go and ring up departmental officials and say, `What did you mean to say?'. They go to the legislation and see what it says. That is what the law is-what the legislation says.

If the Government makes a mistake, as it has done in this sense, that is bad luck. Let the Government bear the burden of it. If we are getting to the stage where, if the Government makes a mistake we will decide in the Senate whether the citizens can afford it and we will make them pay, we are going down a very sorry road. It is all too easy to say that because it is BHP in this instance, a big corporate citizen, we will for some reason take a different attitude, forgetting that BHP is made up of lots of little shareholders.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has 165,000 shareholders.
—It has 165,000 shareholders; that is what BHP has.
—And the superannuation funds.

—We could also mention the superannuation funds. We should not look at this as being a big corporate citizen that can afford it. We should look at this and say, `The law said A'. People operated as though it were B. The Government said it was B and so this corporate citizen went along with it as though it were B. Then the corporate citizen, some time down the track says, `Hold on, you've got it wrong; the law is A'. Now we have the Government and the Democrats getting into bed with each other and saying, `Ha, Ha, we're going to change it back to B anyway'. That is exactly what we are doing in this particular instance. We are changing the law to the cost of a citizen. Some people in this chamber imagine this is a fair thing, simply because it is a big corporate citizen.

SPEECH.PARA: This sort of thing has happened from governments on both sides. I will not pretend that it has not happened on my side of the chamber. There was a big debate in 1965, again in relation to a set of customs regulations. Customs seem to make a lot of mistakes. The last bit of retrospective legislation that was discussed, in relation to some machine guns, was a Customs one. We cannot blame the current officers because that may have happened before they were born-or not long after, in any event.

The matter I want to talk about today relates to Ipec Transport Group. Remember the two-airline agreement? Ipec wanted to import some planes and run a freight business between the States. Ipec was originally refused permission by the government of the day, a government of my political persuasion. It appealed and said that permission was improperly refused on two counts. On one of those counts it was successful and permission was granted to trade a freight business between the States. On the second ground it was unsuccessful and it lodged an appeal to the Privy Council. At great expense it got to the Privy Council. What did the Government do? It met Ipec at the door of the court and said, `Ha, ha, we have introduced a regulation and now someone else has to give the permission, so all this is a big waste of time.'

That was an appalling thing to have happened. It was changing the rules when someone had gone to the umpire and gone to the court. All governments have done and it and every parliamentarian should speak against it when it happens-as certain Labor senators did at that time. Senator Turnbull from Tasmania was moved to look up some words of Sir Samuel Griffiths, who said:

I am sometimes inclined to think that in some parts of the Commonwealth the old fashioned traditional and almost instinctive standard of fair play to be preserved by the Crown in dealing with subjects, which I learned a long time ago to regard as elementary, is either unknown or thought out of date.

That is what seems to be the case now. Because we are dealing with a corporate citizen, we somehow think that the manner in which the Crown can deal with that citizen does not need to be as fair as it would be in dealing with anyone else. Let me paraphrase what another senator said and just insert BHP for Ipec: `What can be done to BHP today can be done tomorrow to any citizen. The Government is setting up a precedent of injustice to citizens and it is all the worse when that injustice is perpetrated by Ministers of the Government. It is no credit to them, it is no credit to the Cabinet which endorsed the decision, and it will not be to the credit of this Senate if it approves of the Government's action.'

The original speaker of those words was Senator Lionel Murphy, a judge much revered by many on the other side and in the community and a man who played a very significant role in setting up the Senate committee system. If he were here he would not, in my opinion, approve of this retrospective piece of legislation. Prior to that, Senator Murphy said:
If we are to have the rule of law in this community it should be applied not only as between citizen and citizen but it should be applied as between the Government and its citizens.

Let me move towards concluding because I know that we do not have much time. The situation is this: the Government admits it made a mistake; it thought the law said one thing, and it did not say that. As a consequence of that, one of our corporate citizens has been paying excise at a higher rate, and now the Government wants to get out of paying it back.

That corporate citizen has been to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT). There were some very ugly manoeuvres on the other side of this chamber trying to get this Bill through, as I understand it, before that hearing was held. Then the Government decided to agree. There was not really a hearing in the AAT yesterday; there was a consent order filed, as I am informed.

It is not a case of the Government denying that it was wrong. I think the Minister admits that the Government made a mistake. Of course he does; otherwise it would not need the Bill. The corporate citizen was in effect denied its day in court by the Government coming along and getting consent orders filed. Why was that done? I could be wrong; I see the Minister frowning but that is what I was told. The Government went along to the AAT yesterday and said `Yes, we were wrong; this oil was the sort of oil that BHP says it was. Yes, there should be a refund', and that is that. Yet it comes in here today and says, `You should join with us in passing this Bill to make sure that refund is not given'. How can we put up with that? It is manifestly ridiculous if citizens cannot rely on the letter of the law.

Let me repeat it. The reasoning that the Government and the Democrats are using to say it should be okay today-in club, entre nous-to quietly slip this through and deprive a corporate citizen of the money is that they say the corporate citizen went along with it. All the citizens of Australia can now know that if they follow the law, perhaps believing that the law is as the Government says it is, and then they find out it is not, tough luck; the Government will be justified in changing the law because the citizen took the Government's word for it. We all know now that we cannot do that.

What a disastrous situation. What the Government is saying and what the Democrats have been saying is that, because BHP did not complain, we can take their silence to be assent: `BHP agreed to this so it is all right; we will just change it back to what we thought it was'. I cannot stress strongly enough what an obligation the Government and the Democrats are seeking to put on citizens.

The obligation now goes much higher than simply knowing the law. Heaven knows, there are plenty of people who say that being assumed to know the law is an unfair assumption because it is such a difficult task. Now we are going beyond that. We are saying that not only are people assumed to know the law but that they are assumed to know when the Government has made a mistake and that, if people do not know that, they can bear the financial cost of it.

It may be all right for some to say `That is okay in this instance because it is BHP and they can afford it', but I invite the Democrats to consider two things. Firstly, it is a mistake to think of BHP as just a corporate giant who can afford it. There are shareholders-165,000, Senator O'Chee tells me-who have an interest in this matter. That is the first reason. The second reason is the precedent that is set. Surely we must stick by the appropriate interpretation of the law -and that is what it says. If we shift today from the law being taken to mean what it says and as it is written; if citizens can no longer go along, look up a law and say, `That is what it says and that is what it means'; if we today endorse a decision that says, `No, the law does not mean what it says; it means whatever the Government thinks it meant it to say', then we are in very big trouble.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that there is the pressure of time, so I will be as brief as I can. In other circumstances I would not sum up in the second reading debate at all, but there are a number of important principles that I wish to refer to. The broad thrust of that--
—Don't you take up the time.

—I promise the honourable senator I shall not use much time. The broad principles that I wish to state have essentially been set down in the extensive committee hearings in response to debate between Senator Vanstone, Senator Kemp, Senator O'Chee and me, and I will not take time to reiterate them now. I certainly will not enter into any of the rhetorical flourishes about when the Opposition voted for retrospectivity before and all those sorts of things which I would otherwise enjoy.

SPEECH.PARA: But I do think it is important to put briefly on the record that the Government and, I am sure, every member of parliament shares the concern that retrospective legislation is not a matter to be taken lightly. It is, on its face, something that one should not do, and it requires very extraordinary circumstances to justify. Governments of all political persuasions around the world from time to time find themselves in circumstances where not so to act is worse than to act and, on balance, they take that action.

The Government collectively has not taken the decision lightly and I, individually, have not taken my role in the debate lightly. But we do have a situation where it is not a citizen who has merely failed to protest. We have a circumstance in which the people paying this excise have paid it more than 200 times without protest in the sure and certain knowledge of what the mechanisms for protest were, because they were simultaneously paying another payment under protest on the same form, on the same day.

So we are dealing with an informed citizen, and we are dealing with a law-as this Excise Tariff Amendment Bill amends that law-under which everybody thought they were operating. I think it is fair in that sense; people are not having actions which they took rendered illegal or even made inappropriate retrospectively. All the decisions and judgments--

TALK.START.PARA: —They have had a right to money withdrawn.

—If the honourable senator wants to interject, I can respond. We did deal with that. I acknowledged in the Committee that obviously there are adverse consequences for Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. It will be worse off if this legislation is passed than if it were not. I acknowledge that. I was skipping over it for brevity, but I do acknowledge that point, obviously. I simply say that, on balance, I think it is fair in the circumstances, but it is not taken lightly. There is a lengthy argument that I feel ought properly to be made, but I have had an alternative opportunity to make it and other senators have forgone their time.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two points I make in conclusion. One is that this is in a drafting sense a minor Bill, although it is major in principle. It is what I would call a technical corrections Bill in its substance, although I understand its impact is significant and worthy of debate. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal in considering its matter said nothing new; it merely confirmed what we all knew as to what the law now says-and that is why the Government sensibly agreed yesterday.

As to the other two pieces of legislation, the Volware legislation is a very technical matter and nothing more needs to be said about that. I simply confirm for the record that the Government has circulated and will move an amendment, which I also understand is non-controversial, to the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Parer's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., pursuant to sessional order, we will now move to matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 December last on the adjournment I raised a matter concerning the Australian Customs Service, specifically a case entitled Oxford Clothing Co. and the Comptroller-General of Customs. I said that this case was to be determined on 11 January. I said also that it was a most important case because it was a test case concerning the practice of the Australian Customs Service of registering an error against not only the person who signed the form but also the owner of the goods if that was not the person who signed it, as well as the Customs officer who in fact did sign it. This particular case of Oxford Clothing Co. was a matter involving only $300, but both the owner and, as I understand it, the Customs agent were sufficiently concerned about this as a matter of principle, and about the way the Customs Service had behaved, that they proceeded to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) to use this as a test case. This morning, around lunchtime, I called the AAT and spoke to the Deputy Registrar to ask him if that case was still scheduled to be held on 11 January, because I intended to be in Adelaide on that date to hear that case argued, as I too believe it is an important test case.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I am very concerned to hear the following: the Deputy Registrar tells me that a preliminary conference was held between the owners, the agent, and indeed the Customs Service and that the Customs Service has offered a 100 per cent remission. It is highly questionable whether that is a legitimate thing for it to do, but of course it does have one serious consequence. Once the Customs Service offers a 100 per cent remission, no longer is there a dispute, and therefore the AAT is no longer seized of jurisdiction.

I am particularly concerned about this case for a number of reasons. Firstly, it is an important matter of principle. Secondly, I am most interested to know the amount of money, that is, taxpayers money, that has been spent in preparing this case both in terms of the initial penalty imposed and with regard to the AAT case. I am particularly concerned about this case being settled in this manner. I do not know whether or not the company or the agent concerned wished to have the case settled, but, of course, once the Customs Service makes the offer, there is no longer a dispute and therefore it is taken out of its hands.

I do not know whether the purpose of this settlement is simply to remove this case from scrutiny. In light of some of the other behaviour that has been going on, I could be well tempted to believe that that is the real reason for the settlement being offered.

I understand from the Deputy Registrar that documentation for this settlement must be filed with the AAT by the end of this week. I will be most interested to see the documentation. I will also be most interested to ask some questions about the costs that were incurred prior to this settlement offer being made. I would not want the Australian Customs Service to think that it would be possible to camouflage or conceal the costs, which may or may not include the cost of flying people over to Adelaide, putting them up in hotels and the like.

It is highly important, given the important question that was to be determined by this case, that I have found that the case has suddenly been pulled off. It opens up all sorts of questions rather than answers any. I simply want to inform the Senate that this case that I raised on 6 December and said was to be an important case has now been dealt with in this way by the Australian Customs Service and I shall be watching subsequent procedures regarding this matter with great interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not detain the Senate very long on this matter of public importance. I do not think honourable senators will be surprised that I am still sticking with the theme of imprudent lending practices by banks. In recent times there has been much publicity relating to imprudent banking practices by bankers and the huge losses occasioned by banks by the adoption of these practices. I propose to illustrate those practices by reference to Huon Valley Springs Pty Ltd, a case which I have previously cited in reference to other aspects of banking.

SPEECH.PARA: Miss Donna Batiste, the principal of Huon Valley Springs, applied to the Commonwealth Bank of Australia for finance to purchase the lease of a penthouse at the Regent Hotel. The application was approved. The bank provided Miss Batiste a fixed rate bill endorsement facility for $1.1m, terminating on 28 March 1988. The interest rate was quoted at 15.1 per cent per annum.
The bank did not waste any time before defrauding Miss Batiste. In a memorandum dated 12 June 1985, a Mr P.B. Herden, District Manager, New South Wales southern division, wrote:
Only the amount of the fixed interest rate is to be advised to borrowers. The following entries are to be passed in your branch's books:
1. At the time of discounting:
One of the entries required was:
c) credit Discount Account . . . . with the amount of discount;
Another entry required was:
d) credit Accommodation Bill Fees Account with appropriate `endorsement fee'. This fee will be advised by Money Market Dealing Section and must not be advised to the borrowers;
Another entry required:
e) credit borrower's account with net proceeds after deduction of c) and d).
What this means is that the endorsement fee was to be charged to Miss Batiste but disguised as a part of the net discounted amount representing the interest.
But, of course, while Australia's leading bank was prepared to defraud Miss Batiste, it was not prepared to inconvenience its own branch. The memorandum continues:

For purposes of Branch Contribution Reporting (BCR) a fee approximating all up fees will be passed on so as not to disadvantage branches. To sustain this, bills will be discounted at a lower rate than advised to borrowers thus enabling branches to retain income . . . . This arrangement is internal and under no circumstances are details to be advised to borrowers nor the fee debited to borrower's account.
Bills will be discounted at a lower rate than advised to borrowers! Mr Acting Deputy President, I would suggest that such practice is blatant fraud on the part of the bank.

There is more, however. Honourable senators will recall that in the case of Tony Rigg, which I have outlined in this place on several occasions for other reasons, the bank carried on the business of dealing in the bills to the overdraft account of Rigg's company. What that meant was that the bill rollover costs, representing interest and fees, increased the debit balance standing on the overdraft account, thereby incurring overdraft interest as well. That is what the bank did to Miss Batiste. The bills were rolled over to her personal overdraft account. That is naked greed on the part of the bank. The effective rate was far in excess of the quoted 15.1 per cent.

Honourable senators will recall that in the case of Tony Rigg the bank purported to cancel the bill facility and issued proceedings out of the Supreme Court of New South Wales to obtain summary judgment for the face value of the last bill together with the roll-over costs and fees. That is what the bank also did to Miss Batiste. In the proceedings against Mr Rigg, an officer of the bank committed perjury. In the proceedings against Miss Batiste, an officer of the bank committed perjury. In an affidavit sworn on 15 December 1986, the Chief Manager of the New South Wales branches administration deposed as follows:
6. The initial bill of $1,100,000.00 . . . was due and payable by the defendant to the plaintiff on 30 September 1985.
7. The defendant failed to pay to the plaintiff on 30 December 1985 the amount of the initial bill drawn under the Facility.

The allegation that Miss Batiste failed to pay the $1.1m on 30 September 1985 implies that Miss Batiste was in default to the bank. That allegation is false. Miss Batiste was not obliged to pay the $1.1m upon maturity of the first bill because it was part of an ongoing facility. The senior officer well knew that the first bill was part of an ongoing facility. Annex D to his affidavit, which is a copy of the application for the fixed rate bill facility dated 21 June 1985, stipulated as such. The application discloses the facility termination date as 28 March 1988 and states:
The Bank may determine the tenor of each Bill provided that no Bill except the initial drawdown Bills shall have a tenor of less than 85 nor more than 95 days.

What that means is that, during the term of the facility, bills would be rolled over on a periodic basis. Upon the maturity of a bill, any liability to pay the amount of the bill would be discharged save for the roll-over costs upon the drawdown of the fresh bill. I have previously explained the mechanics of bill roll-over facilities in relation to the Tony Rigg case. In any event the affidavit gives the lie to the allegation. Clause 8 states:
On or about 30 September 1985 the plaintiff rolled over the amount of the initial bill and endorsed and discounted a further bill of exchange.

A banker of this senior officer's standing should have known better than to make the misleading allegation. However, there is more. The senior officer went on to allege that the facility was granted by way of a single bill. Clause 5 states:
The plaintiff granted accommodation to the defendant by endorsing and discounting a bill of exchange with a face value of $1,100,000.00 . . .

That was not so. There were three bills, two with a face value of $500,000 each and one with a face value of $100,000. I will seek to table copies of these bills later. The bills were consolidated in one bill at a later time.
There is yet more. Clause 8 of the affidavit goes on to state:
Interest and other costs charges and expenses associated with the rollover of the initial bill were debited by the plaintiff to another account of the defendant with the plaintiff.

Nor was that so. The bank carried on the business of dealing in these bills to account No. 2018-291-941, that is, Miss Batiste's overdraft account at the Park and Castlereagh streets branch in Sydney, and to no other account.

I will be seeking leave to table bank statements as follows: page 1 showing the initial drawdown on 21 June 1985; page 14 showing the maturity of three bills on 30 September 1985, and drawdown of a fresh bill on that date. The difference between the face value of the initial three bills of $1.1m and the net discount amount of the fresh bill of $1,060,091.20 represents the `interest and other costs charges and expenses' referred to by the senior officer.
Honourable senators will see that, by the very nature of the roll-over transaction, the interest and other costs, charges and expenses could not be charged to another account.
The senior officer goes on to state:
The defendant failed to pay to the plaintiff the face value of the bill due and payable by the defendant to the plaintiff on 30 December 1985.

Again, that allegation is false. The bill was rolled over and I will seek to table bank statements as follows: page 35 showing the maturity of the fresh bill on 30 December 1985; and page 36 showing the drawdown of the last bill on 30 December 1985.

There is one other matter which I will raise at this time and which I will return to in greater detail at a later time. I table a copy of an account card for Ms Batiste's overdraft account. Written on the card are the words, `Destroy original of statements'.

I call upon the Attorney-General for New South Wales to investigate these matters and I seek leave of the Senate to table the documents referred to. I apologise for the fact that, due to shortage of time, I have not extended the normal courtesy of allowing the perusal of these documents but, if the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), who is at the table, wishes me to do so, I will make them available immediately and seek leave to table them at a later date.

DEBATE.TITLE: LAW AND JUSTICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 November, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 principally amends the Bankruptcy Act 1966 and the Circuit Layouts Act 1989. It corrects a number of technical defects in the Acts Interpretation Act, the Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court Act, the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act, the Family Law Act, the Federal Court of Australia Act, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Act, the Marriage Act, the Racial Discrimination Act, the Service and Execution of Process Act, the Sex Discrimination Act and the Statutory Declarations Act.

SPEECH.PARA: As many of the amendments are minor and technical in nature, I do not propose to comment further on them other than to say that the Opposition is not opposing them. I will confine my remarks to the more substantial amendments to the Bankruptcy Act and the Racial Discrimination Act.

In the context of the present economic climate, in this recession that we `had to have', this is an appropriate time for us to be talking about the issue of bankruptcy. In the September quarter this year there was a 32 per cent increase in the number of bankruptcies in Australia as compared to the September quarter last year. In the State of Victoria bankruptcies increased 70 per cent during the June 1990 quarter as compared to the same quarter last year. So it is somewhat encouraging to note that the Government is at least considering the issue, albeit in a piecemeal fashion, by way of this Bill which amends the Bankruptcy Act in several respects.

One of the more significant developments is that, pursuant to the amendment to section 139d, the court will have a wider power to make an order in relation to property which is not strictly owned, but is at least enjoyed, by a person who is a bankrupt. This addresses the quite legitimate concern in the community that people who have been declared bankrupt often seem to enjoy a high standard of living. This amendment will allow some of the proceeds which might have been lost to the creditors to be brought back into the estate to be divided among the creditors.

Another important provision is that all bankrupts will be entitled to be discharged after three years, unless a valid objection to the discharge has been entered. The Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) assured the Opposition during the second reading debate in the other place that this provision was designed to remedy the undesirable situation where a large number of active bankruptcies cannot be finalised because in many cases of multiple bankruptcies the people cannot afford to apply to the court for a discharge order.

The Opposition supports the amendments relating to the interaction between creditors' petitions and debtors' petitions, which will allow the court to supervise the date of bankruptcy and prevent a debtor lodging his own petition to defeat backdating the date of bankruptcy on a creditor's petition. Another change which the Opposition welcomes is that search and seizure warrants, which may now be issued by judges or magistrates, will only be able to be issued by `an eligible judge'.

The main points I would wish to raise in relation to this Bill concern the significant changes which it makes to the Racial Discrimination Act 1975. The Bill introduces three principal amendments: a definition of indirect discrimination is inserted; the existing `dominant purpose' test is removed; and vicarious liability for discriminatory conduct is created.

These changes have apparently come about as a result of recommendations made to the Government by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to bring the test for discrimination in the Racial Discrimination Act in line with the test in the Sex Discrimination Act. Firstly, in relation to indirect discrimination, the Racial Discrimination Act contains a definition of direct discrimination in subsection 9(1). Direct discrimination arises if a person treats another person less favourably than others would be treated in comparable circumstances.

This Bill seeks to introduce a new section 9 (1a) containing a definition of indirect discrimination with the following elements: the discriminator must require the aggrieved person to comply with a requirement or condition; the requirement or condition must be unreasonable; the aggrieved person must not be able to comply with the requirement or condition; and the requirement to comply has the purpose or effect of nullifying or impairing the enjoyment of rights of equality. At present, the Racial Discrimination Act is the only piece of equal opportunity legislation not to have an indirect discrimination test.

Secondly, in relation to the issue of a dominant purpose test, section 18 of the Act provides that conduct can be discriminatory where it is done for two or more reasons provided that a person's race is one of the reasons for the conduct, and that that reason is the dominant reason for the carrying out of the conduct. By way of contrast, under the Sex Discrimination Act, a person's sex, marital status or pregnancy does not have to be the dominant purpose for the carrying out of the conduct for the legislation to apply; it need be only one of the reasons for doing the act. Pursuant to this Bill, section 18 will be repealed and replaced with a provision similar to the one in the Sex Discrimination Act.

Thirdly, in relation to the issue of vicarious liability, the Bill provides that, where an employee or agent of a person does an act in connection with his or her duties which is unlawful under the Act, the person or employer will be taken to have also done the act-in effect, a joint liability. However, there is a proviso that, if the employer or person took all reasonable steps to prevent the occurrence of such an act, the employer would not be liable.

The Opposition has concerns about the phrase `in connection with his or her duties'. It may mean that, should an employee do an act which is not specifically authorised by the employer, the employer could be liable notwithstanding the proviso. It was held by the Commonwealth Human Rights Commission in a 1986 sex discrimination case, Boyle v. Ishan Ozden, that an employer can be liable without having knowledge of the relevant conduct; for the qualification to be invoked it is necessary to show that the employer took active steps to reasonably prevent the discrimination.

We would prefer that the vicarious or joint liability be confined to situations where the employee is carrying out acts within the authority, both apparent and real, of the employer. However, we recognise the desirability of the two pieces of legislation, that is, the Racial Discrimination Act and the Sex Discrimination Act, being uniform; for this reason we are not proposing an amendment.

The shadow Attorney-General raised several matters during the brief opportunity he had for debate on this Bill in the other chamber. I have just received a copy of the letter which the Attorney-General, Mr Duffy, has today written to Mr Peacock in relation to these matters, principally the constitutional implications of extending the definition of racial discrimination and the matter relating to vicarious liability to which I have just made a brief reference. However, I have not had time to consider the arguments advanced in this correspondence and nor has Mr Peacock. We will therefore have to trust that the issues lend themselves to satisfactory resolution by correspondence of this nature.
Despite these concerns, as I have said, the Opposition is supporting the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill and, indeed, welcomes a number of the changes which the Bill seeks to introduce.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief. As Senator Hill has said, and as the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) said in introducing the legislation, none of the amendments in this Bill are major new policy, although some are fairly important, and none of them have direct financial impact. The Government has had the opportunity in second reading speeches and otherwise to express its view, so I will add only one point to that, which is to comment on one part of the legislation about which I have been concerned for some time. The Bill creates the capacity to extend to the Australian Capital Territory the cooperative arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States and Territories under the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act. It has been a matter on which the cooperation of the ACT Government has been a little bit slow in coming, but I am delighted that both sides are now proceeding to what should be a satisfactory resolution. I thank the Opposition for the support of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
