DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 November, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 is a large Bill which proposes a number of amendments to the Customs Act 1901 and the Excise Act 1901 and a consequential repeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975. The Opposition will be supporting this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I will principally be dealing with the major amendments to the two Acts and regulations with which this Bill is concerned.

Clauses 3 to 38 of part 2 of the Bill contain amendments to the Custom Act 1901. The main changes proposed concern the repeal of the export return scheme and the introduction of EXIT, which is an electronic entry and cargo reporting system for exports. The commencement date for the EXIT provisions will follow proclamation early in 1991, although the scheme has been up and running in a limited way since 1988. EXIT is an EDI scheme-that is, an electronic data interchange system-which will result in exports being reported prior to departure. Presently under the export return scheme, exporters lodge an entry manually, shipping and airline companies present a manifest for acquittal to obtain clearance and, after processing, copies of export entries and returns are forwarded to the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

A number of problems have been identified with the present paper based system of reporting exports. They include failure to report quantities, lodgment of late and inaccurate export data with the Australian Bureau of Statistics and a difficulty in controlling restricted goods. In addition to having the latest and more accurate statistics as an aid to facilitate economic planning, there is also the matter of being able to oversight the international trade regulations and customs law.

It is a well established principle that nations can control the entry of goods into their countries and, of course, customs laws are one of the processes by which rights of entry are controlled. Following a prototype trial which commenced in Sydney on 23 October 1987, we now have the three-phase EXIT scheme which is designed to capture this export data prior to shipment. I might say parenthetically, having watched the export scheme, that it has not been without some high degree of criticism from a large number of users. Part of that, of course, results from the fact that costs are involved in setting it up. To be quite blunt about it, part of the problem has been the marked inflexibility of the person in Customs who fathered the scheme to enter into much or any debate about its shortcomings and to modify it accordingly. Nevertheless, it started, as I said, from a prototype trial on 23 October 1987.

Phase one of the scheme commenced on 12 December 1988. I should note in passing that the manual system is still available to operators. The intention of the scheme is to link exporters or their agents, depot operators, consolidators, freight forwarders and airline and shipping companies with the Australian Customs Service and, through the ACS, with the Australian Bureau of Statistics and other government agencies having control over restricted or prohibited control goods. Exporters or their agents will be able to dial up the ACS and have the option of either manually keying in an export entry and having basic editing performed or automatic transmission of export data prepared on in-house software, using electronic data interchange standards or a manual entry. The Australian Customs Service will allocate an export clearance number which will in effect preclear goods for export.

The system will operate a third party communications network to connect users to the Australian Customs Service. In EXIT bulletin No. 3, users were informed that the ACS had selected OTC Ltd to supply the electronic store and forward facilities to be used for EXIT. There are costs involved with the scheme; this, of course, was one of the objections raised when it first came on line. The exporter will need a personal computer which is IBM compatible. Certain capabilities in that system will be required to access the software programs and do the communication required, and I do not propose to go through those.

As with anything the Government does, there is a cost. There is a registration fee of $33 per mailbox password for users who require one. Larger organisations have an option of registering and paying a corporate account of $300. Then there is a service fee, which for business accounts will be $20 per month for mailbox password; for corporate accounts it will be $150 per month. Next there is the transmission charge, with each connection to the EXIT network attracting a transmission charge at Telecom Australia commercial rates plus a 7c charge per kilocharacter for Austpac.

Additionally, there are the transaction charges. Business accounts will be charged at a single tariff rate of 89c per kilocharacter; a corporate account will have three tariff levels applied. As I said earlier, it is a three-stage change. Stage 2 participants have been or are still to be connected to the ACS mainframe via a third party community network. Tradegate Australia, of which the ACS is a founding member, is supplying the infrastructure for this second phase through the PAXUS ComNet network.

According to the Customs Service's annual report for 1989-90, approximately 1,000 users are connected, with about 40 per cent of Australia's exports now being reported via the system. I note in the second reading speech of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) that over 65 per cent of our export trade is being reported electronically. The difference between this figure and the one I cited earlier obviously relates more to the time period than anything else.

In line with these changes, clause 10 provides for the advance electronic reporting of ships and aircraft and their cargo and crew. Clause 12 provides for the tightening of Customs control over the unshipment of imported goods, especially when no cargo report has been provided or where it has not been provided in advance. These clauses also repeal sections 64 and 74 of the principal Act.

This change will tighten Customs control over unshipment of imported goods and aid in targeting risky cargo. At present, reporting must be done within one day of arrival. Forward warning, as imposed under clause 10, will allow more effective surveillance of incoming aircraft and vessels, their cargo and their crew. This will be an invaluable administrative aid because Customs resources are understandably very stretched at the present time. It will allow a higher standard of intelligence gathering and subsequent surveillance activities.

The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration first report on an inquiry into aspects of the Australian Customs Service commented, following its appraisal of the work of contraband enforcement teams, that the teams thought the following would assist the effectiveness of their operation:
Mandatory earlier notification of vessels entering Australia, including such data as crew lists, would provide timely advice for the arrival of vessels and crew fitting particular profiles.

Clearly, Customs import-export control and inland revenue subprograms through the documentation examination role make a significant contribution to the interdiction of drugs and other prohibited goods.

In an Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) report on passenger and crew processing, tabled in September 1989, a number of deficiencies in passenger and crew processing were identified. Of particular importance to the discussion today was the fact that ANAO identified inadequate checks of airline crew and found, further, that there was a lack of sufficient data on the extent and nature of prohibited goods carried by passengers and crew, and this insufficiency makes it very difficult to assess the effectiveness of any control programs.

This amendment to the principal Act provides for four separate reports: first, the impending arrival report for ships and aircraft; an arrival report for ships only; a cargo report for ships and aircraft; and a crew and passenger report for ships only.

Let me deal briefly with the other amendments to the Customs Act. There are, in addition, three sets of amendments to the principal Act which deal with offences relating to the control of narcotic goods. The intention here is to correct deficiencies identified by the courts and the Director of Public Prosecutions.

Clauses 39 to 47 of part 3 seek to amend the Excise Act 1901 in relation to entry of goods for home consumption, delivery for export and delivery of certain goods for home consumption without entry. These changes are consequent upon the change to the EXIT system.

Finally, I would like to deal with the amendments to the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations. This third substantial body of amendments, which is contained in clause 49 of part 4, seeks to save the prohibited import status of dangerous goods under the second schedule of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations.

Item 18 of this schedule was declared invalid by the Federal Court. As a result, goods understood to have been prohibited and therefore able to be seized by Customs are not, in fact, prohibited goods. This item was introduced by regulation in 1956 and prohibited the importation of goods which are `of a dangerous character and a menace to the community'. Goods included in this category are machine guns, land mines, toys contaminated with dangerous levels of lead, flick knives and other unsafe children's toys.

This clause, therefore, relates to the period 13 December 1956 to 11 October 1990. It covers goods seized by Customs during that period which were believed to be prohibited imports and which Customs believed it had the power to seize. The period from 11 October 1990 is covered by statutory rule No. 324, previously moved by the Government as part of its changes in this area of control of dangerous goods.

Fairly coincidentally, we have had a lot of debate about retrospective legislation this morning, before what would have been the normal luncheon break, on the preceding Bill, the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill; and this clearly involves retrospective legislation by the Government to control what were formerly thought to be prohibited goods.

The Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia do not normally look very kindly on any attempts by this Government to introduce retrospective legislation, particularly when the legislation is going to be retrospective by so many years, as in this case. But we recognise that there are special circumstances that apply in this case and we will not be opposing the use of retrospectivity at this time. I say that as someone who has had a very strong record of opposition to retrospectivity, even when it was proposed on one occasion by my own Party when it was in government. It is only under the most extreme circumstances that I can personally countenance its use, and I am satisfied that in the circumstances that apply in this Bill it is justified.

We do think that this Government uses retrospective legislation far too frequently. It is really forced into that position by some of the bad legislation that it puts forward. While I did not get a chance to speak on the suspension of Standing Orders or on the imposition of the gag and the guillotine in the debate today, the one good thing about it is that a large number of the 52 Bills that are going to be jack booted through this Parliament without any debate at all are certain to be fatally flawed.

I have the view that it is not always the duty of the Opposition to save the Government from its own stupidity and inaccuracies with legislation. The Christmas present that it will get will be a heap of unworkable Bills among these 52 that will be run through in the next 10 days. The community will make its judgment on that. But the community deserves it because it elected this Government.

Returning to this Bill, we recognise the fundamental problems which would arise if all the goods which have been collected since 1956 had to be returned to their owners; in many cases those goods would have been destroyed or disposed of. It would simply be quite impossible to do that. There is also the other point, that it would be highly undesirable to return to the people who sought to import them in the first place instruments that are lethal to the human race. I am not saying that all the instruments seized under this section of the Act since 1956 fall into that category; quite clearly, a large number of weapons, rifles, that were imported for legitimate target shooting and sporting purposes have been seized and apprehended and lost to their owners through that, and it is regrettable that that did occur. But overall there were a large number of dangerous items that have no part in community hands. Taking the whole thing together, we are left with a situation where we simply cannot make restitution for what has occurred.

The Bill also makes three sets of amendments to the Customs Act-provisions dealing with offences relating to the control of narcotics goods. The intention here is to correct deficiencies identified by the courts and the Director of Public Prosecutions.

This is a very substantial Bill in that it legitimises the use of EXIT, which is going to be a new scheme which will cover pretty well all the exports from this country-which, hopefully, will be an increasing task in the years to come as we try to work our way out of the economic mess that the Hawke-Keating regime has got us into. The Bill also involves retrospective powers, which I have discussed. It changes ship reporting procedures and various other amendments.
The Liberal Party and the National Party support this Bill and wish it a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank Senator MacGibbon for the support that he has given on behalf of the Opposition. As he said, the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 is a major but not controversial piece of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: A matter of note is the retrospective aspect of the legislation which will apply to the Owen gun case. As Senator MacGibbon pointed out, it is an irony that during this lunchtime sitting we should be dealing with a controversial matter. What has been highlighted is that nobody in this Parliament likes retrospective legislation and we all have to think about where we should draw the line. This is a very appropriately agreed example. I agree with the remarks made by Senator MacGibbon. The other aspect of this matter is more controversial and is a proper matter for debate in the Parliament. But on this occasion I welcome the Opposition's support for the Bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Sitting suspended from 1.37 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to the November labour force statistics released today showing a massive jump in the unemployment rate to 8.2 per cent, seasonally adjusted up from 7.6 per cent last month. Given that a jump of this magnitude in a single month has not been experienced for more than four years, I ask: has the Government now revised upwards its unemployment forecasts for the remainder of this year? Does the Government now expect unemployment to go to over 10 per cent? If not, what is the Government's forecast? How does the Government plan to reduce unemployment and reverse the economic damage and personal hardship it has caused through the engineered recession which the Treasurer has said we had to have?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I anticipated a question couched somewhat in the terms in which Senator Short has put his question. Let me say first of all that the unemployment figures released today are of concern to the Government. It was anticipated that unemployment would rise in the latter portion of this year-certainly in this quarter-and that is a matter of regret. As the Statistician's figures point out, this is the highest unemployment level since October 1983 when, in turn, we had the highest unemployment figure since the people opposite left office, when it was 10.3 per cent seasonally adjusted.
—We had a drought that year.

—`We had a drought', says the good senator. There was a drought, but the unemployment problems were upon the previous Government long before the drought. I just make the point that very little of the current unemployment figure is attributable at this stage to a downturn in the rural sector, and, of course, it was not then.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of Senator Short's question about revising forecasts, let me say that the forecast is a Budget forecast and it is not normally the practice in the course of a year to revise forecasts about any of these matters. After all, it gives the Opposition the opportunity to say, if it is true, that the Government did not meet its Budget forecast. I do not think a government should be in a process of continual revision of forecasts about anything of this kind.

I am asked additionally whether it is anticipated that unemployment will reach double digit figures. It is extraordinarily difficult to indulge in any speculations about that sort of matter. We believe that some factors are in place that will help moderate adverse labour market conditions. I guess the main point there is the postponement of any general wage increase, a factor which greatly exacerbated unemployment during the period in government of those opposite, and which will not happen now. Certainly, I think Ministers think that the current economic downturn is likely to be a little more protracted than originally thought. However, I do not think there is any point in trying to make a forecast arising from that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I noted that the Minister said that the figures are of concern to the Government. If that is so, does the Minister agree that one important method of keeping people in jobs is to allow employers and employees to negotiate conditions which will allow them to get through this engineered disastrous recession? If so, could he explain why the Government has refused to support such negotiations?
—Senator Cook gave an answer to a question about that identical subject matter yesterday and that answer is recorded in the Hansard.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade been drawn to media reports claiming that a shortage of milk in Iraq caused by the imposition of United Nations (UN) sanctions is causing severe hardship including, it is claimed, the death of children? Can the Minister comment on the validity of these claims and on arrangements under UN resolutions for dealing with such shortages should they be real?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of media reports about Iraqi claims of milk shortages causing hardship, including the deaths of babies. As some honourable senators would have heard on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio this morning, our Ambassador, Peter Lloyd, said that he has been doing his best to check out what information is available on death rates of infants. While it is impossible to draw any conclusive opinions at this stage, at least one set of available figures that has turned up indicates that, comparing the 1985 figures for infant deaths with those that are currently claimed to be running, the figures are about the same. To that extent, there is no evidence of any variation from normality.

ANSWER.PARA: As I said in response to a question from Senator Bourne in this place on 28 November, most assessments of the general situation in Iraq indicate that the main impact of sanctions has been on Iraqi infrastructure and industrial production rather than on food or medical supplies. Certain foodstuffs have been rationed to ward off serious shortages and prices of some products have apparently risen. Otherwise, at this stage food supplies still appear adequate.

Security Council resolution 666 provides a framework for the provision of food under UN auspices if and when the humanitarian circumstances exemption to sanctions is determined by the UN Security Council to exist. If the Iraqi allegations were well founded, it would be expected that the Iraqi Government would, under those circumstances, be prepared to facilitate the procedures provided for in that Security Council resolution to verify that the hardships that it is claiming do in fact exist. The fundamental point to bear in mind in this respect is that Iraq has not allowed the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC), other recognised international humanitarian agencies or the UN Secretary General's special representative to visit Iraq to assess the situation.

The Iraqi authorities recently confirmed to our Embassy in Baghdad that there is still a firm policy that the ICRC cannot expand its role in Iraq to address the food and medical supplies problems which it claims sanctions have caused. The authorities also continue to reject any inter- action with the UN sanctions committee.

Avenues are available to the Iraqi Government to substantiate its claims and, if necessary, for action to be taken to address the situation. But Iraq has not chosen to use them. In view of such intransigence it really is very difficult not to conclude that the Iraqi Government's claims about the adverse impact of sanctions on children and other vulnerable groups in Iraq are yet another propaganda ploy by the Iraqis.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. It concerns the leadership of the Government. I refer the Minister to reports that Labor members of parliament and Ministers expressed surprise and gave an overwhelmingly sceptical reaction in the Labor Caucus yesterday to the Prime Minister's announcement of his five-year leadership plan, and that some senior Labor figures branded the Hawke commitment as absurd. I also refer to reports that ministerial colleagues, Mr Howe and Senator Cook, have strongly endorsed the Prime Minister's decision. As other Ministers have been prepared publicly to state their views, can the Minister indicate whether the Treasurer also strongly supports Mr Hawke's commitment to his five-year leadership plan?
—London is off?
—Is that the name of some novel? I do not know what the honourable senator is talking about.
—Order! I point out to honourable senators that all of this time comes off the time allotted for Question Time.

—There is understandable desperation on the part of some Opposition senators to exercise some influence over something or other, even if it is only by way of silly interjections. A journalist may report that some members of the Labor Caucus are surprised about something or other, but their being surprised about something is a very sub- jective judgment about which I have no observations to make. In respect of the Treasurer publicly stating his position with regard to the Prime Minister's announcement made the day before yesterday, I have not discussed that matter with the Treasurer and I do not see that, for the purposes of Question Time, it is a matter which I should in any way bother to consult with the Treasurer about.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has his attention been drawn to information showing the economic impact of the union bashing policies adopted by the Thatcher Government of Britain and endorsed by the Opposition in Australia? Does the Minister have any information which would enable us to compare the economic policy results of the confrontationist approach of the British Government with the approach based on the accord which has been followed since 1983 by the Hawke Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to the question from Senator Childs, it just so happens that I have. Given that Margaret Thatcher is the pin-up girl of the New Right and a model for the Liberal Party in Australia, it is interesting to make the comparison. Margaret Thatcher was first elected as Prime Minister in the United Kingdom in May 1979. The first four years of her Government coincided with the last years of the Fraser Government in Australia-a Government which presided over inflation that reached 11.5 per cent in 1982-83, wages growth which reached 17 per cent, unemployment--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The question is out of order in that the Minister does not have responsibility, so far as I am aware, for this area of British government. If he cared to rephrase it and say that his accord had led to the recession here, the question would clearly be in order.

—Order! I think Senator Bishop has a point about the way that the question was worded. I ask the Minister to deal with that part of the question that compared the Opposition's policies with the Government's and whether the Government would adopt those policies.

—I was making the point that many people in the Opposition regard the Thatcher Government as a model. Looking at the results of the model in the British system and the Hawke Government's period of office provides an interesting comparison.

—Mr President, again on a point of order: just as the British Government's policy is not within the Minister's portfolio or responsibility, neither is that of the Opposition. If he wishes to direct his attention to the mishandling of the Government's own policy, it would be in order.

—On the point of order, Mr President, it is quite in order for Senator Cook to measure this Government's performance against that of any other government at Question Time and to use comparisons therein. It would not be in order for Senator Cook simply to discuss Thatcher policies here, but by using that as an example and a comparison, Senator Cook is totally in order.

—Mr President, on the point of order, the Standing Orders are quite clear that the Minister is not allowed to debate the point. If he wishes to compare our policies on employment with his failed policies, we are ready at any time, but Question Time is not the time to do it.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is no point of order. The Minister is quite entitled to be asked a question on Opposition policies and whether the Government would implement them; he is also entitled to comment on them. That has been--

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Hill interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. It is in order for him to be asked whether the Government would implement them.

—As I was saying, during the first four years of the Thatcher Government in Britain, the Fraser Government was in power in Australia. Unemployment here was recorded in double digits, with a recession in 1982-83 when economic growth declined by 1.4 per cent. Despite the horrific--

—On a point of order, Mr President: on 19 February 1987, on a point of order taken by Senator Chaney, you ruled that, as the majority of a question referred to Opposition policies, you would allow it on the basis that the Minister answer only the part of the question that dealt with her, that is, Senator Ryan's, portfolio-in this case, it is his, Senator Cook's, portfolio-and the Government's policy. That was your ruling on 19 February 1987, and I ask you to follow your own precedent.

—On the point of order, Mr President, if the Opposition subcommittee on procedure, which has just been formed, would allow Senator Cook to develop his arguments beyond about four words, the chamber might then hear whether he is being relevant to the question. I know the Opposition is a bit gingered-up but Senator Cook is entitled to comment on and compare Opposition policy with Government policy. He is not entitled to concentrate just on Opposition policy. That is understood and is what the ruling in 1987 is about.

—I will make my third try. It seems that Margaret Thatcher is on the nose on the other side. Despite the horrific economic record in the latter years of the Fraser Government, because of the Hawke Government's achievements, Australia still compares favourably with the first 10 years of the Thatcher period. Comparing the period 1979 to 1988, the latest period for which Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) figures-the recognised international measure-are available, real gross domestic product (GDP) in Australia grew by an average of 3.1 per cent compared with 2.2 per cent in the United Kingdom; employment rose in Australia by an average of 2.2 per cent annually compared with 1.5 per cent in the United Kingdom; the volume of exports of goods and services in Australia increased by an average of 4.5 per cent whereas in the United Kingdom the increase was 2.7 per cent; and unemployment was at an average rate of 7.7 per cent in Australia while it was 10.3 per cent in the United Kingdom.

ANSWER.PARA: The legacy of the Thatcher years includes a current inflation rate of 10.9 per cent compared with Australia's 6 per cent and an increase in wages growth of 10.3 per cent compared with Australia's rise of 6.8 per cent in the year to August 1990. Despite the disastrous record this Government inherited from the previous Government, our figures by comparison to those of the Thatcher period turn out to be vastly superior. Given that the Thatcher Government is the pin-up government for the Opposition-the model it would introduce into the Australian economy-it enables ordinary Australian voters to make a judgment about who is best at managing this economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications to a recent paper by Ann Moyal entitled, `Women and the Telephone in Australia'. Is the Minister aware that women interviewed by Ann Moyal stated they would prefer an increase of 2c on local telephone calls to the introduction of timed local calls? Secondly, is the Minister aware that Aboriginal women in remote areas display special telephone needs arising not only from both domestic violence and social change but also because they face problems of access to telephones? Finally, is the Minister aware that Australian women in general are concerned that the direction of telecommunications policy development stresses the interests of business at the expense of domestic telephone users?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The thrust of the whole series of questions simply was whether I am aware of all of the matters that Senator Kernot has raised. I am happy to advise Senator Kernot that, yes, I am. I am particularly aware of concerns -indeed, they have been expressed to me by Aboriginal women in particular-that Aboriginal women need access to telephones because of the difficult circumstances that some of them live in. I must say that Telecom Australia has made enormous progress, certainly in remote Australia in recent years, in the installation of direct dial phones. In remote Aboriginal communities, the situation has improved enormously in recent years.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the specific matters raised in Senator Kernot's question about timed telephone calls, as a result of a conversation I had with her on this matter prior to Question Time, I have in fact directed her concerns to Minister Beazley, and I will respond to the honourable senator as soon as I get a response from him.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister seen a recent article in the London Economist magazine about the development of plastic bank notes by the Reserve Bank of Australia? Is the Reserve Bank assisting the Australian current account by printing bank notes for other countries, and does the Reserve Bank have a technological lead in the production of plastic bank notes, as assessed by the Economist magazine?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The article in the Economist has been drawn to my attention. That article commented on the developments within the Reserve Bank of Australia relating to the new series of Australian currency notes which will be made of plastic and on the success which the bank has had in producing plastic notes for other countries. Note printing in Australia is done by a division of the Reserve Bank. That operation has already printed currency notes for three countries in the Asia-Pacific region. The export program will be intensified in 1991.

ANSWER.PARA: The technology embodied in the Australian $10 note issued in 1988 and other plastic notes printed by Note Printing Australia represents a world first in currency note printing. The processes are more advanced than those used in plastic notes that have been produced by the Isle of Man and Tahiti, referred to in the article in the Economist. The Reserve Bank of Australia holds the patents to the processes for the manufacture of the plastic note, including the optically variable device which provides an enhanced deterrence to counterfeiting. I add the additional piece of information that that technology was, as I recall it, developed by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation in conjunction with the Reserve Bank.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I draw the honourable senator's attention to today's youth unemployment statistics, which reveal the worst ever monthly rise in youth unemployment, from 20.1 per cent to 23.2 per cent, resulting in the worst ever 12-monthly rise in youth unemployment of more than half-that is, from 14.8 per cent to 23.2 per cent-in the number of people aged between 15 and 19 years looking for full time work, so that almost one in every four young job seekers cannot get work even before the worst of the recession hits this year's school leavers. I ask the Minister: as these record rises in youth unemployment far exceed rises brought on by the 1982 drought-affected recession--
—Rubbish!

—That interjection is simply untrue. I repeat: as these record rises in youth unemployment far exceed rises brought on by the 1982 drought-affected recession and as the Treasurer says that his recession, which Australia had to have, is totally under control, how many more young people will have to become unemployed to achieve the economic objectives of this Government's engineered recession?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Listening to that question, I was reminded of Walter Bagehot's great reference to drunks using lampposts for support rather than illumination. Statistics are sometimes used like that too. It is very interesting to note that Senator Baume's main concern is about the rate of the rise in youth unemployment, not the figures or the outcomes in terms of--
—The outcome is appalling. I am concerned about it.

—Those over there get upset if I make comparisons with 1982-1983. Senator Michael Baume has done it himself in his question. His question refers to the fact that there was not such a significant rate of rise in unemployment for young people in 1982-1983. What he does not mention are the actual figures in terms of youth unemployment that were left to us by the Government of which Senator Baume was a member at the end of that period. Senator Baume knows that the aggregate figures--
—Will you give a guarantee you won't reach it?
—That is not the question. Of course, Senator Baume does not refer to the aggregate figures for youth unemployment. I gave an answer about unemployment earlier in which I expressed--
—It is 23 per cent.

—Yes, Senator Hill, that is what he said. Look at the figures for your period in government. If Opposition senators cannot put their questions together properly, I do not see why they should be allowed to be coached by the so-called Leader of the Opposition in the course of running. I am answering a question which I was asked by Senator Michael Baume. I am answering it, if the Opposition does not mind, in my own way. There is a difference in the aggregate figures which is important.

ANSWER.PARA: Earlier I gave an answer about unemployment generally in terms of the Government's concern about the figures. That concern extends equally, if not with more force, to those categorised as youth unemployed. In that earlier answer to a question from Senator Hill, I refused to indulge in any forecasting about what the unemployment figures are likely to reach, except to say, as I have said on numerous occasions in the Senate, that the Government expected that unemployment would rise in the last quarter of this year and probably into the early portion of next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. In that case I ask the Minister: will he give an absolute assurance that the worst ever Fraser figure of 26 per cent-and you are already, Minister, at 23.2 per cent-will not be reached? I ask for this guarantee because this recession is, according to the Treasurer, deliberately engineered and under his control.
—Good question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —`Good question,' says Senator Walters. That is an endorsement for the honourable senator! This is not a supplementary question. This might have been an original question; it is not a supplementary question. Let me say that, if the honourable senator had listened to my answer to his first question, which he may not have listened to because he found it unpalatable, he would have recognised that the answer to this question is no. I said at the end of my answer to his first question that I was not going to forecast, and I am not going to forecast.

ANSWER.PARA: So far as the glib line tacked on the end about a so-called engineered recession is concerned, the Government has persistently said-and I have said in this chamber in answer to numerous questions-that the Government was concerned to reduce demand in the Australian economy, that the Government was very concerned about the high rate of growth which we had in 1987-88 and 1988-89, and that we had to take steps to deal with that situation. The Opposition, of course, would be inexperienced about having a high rate of growth and inexperienced about coming out of it. The answer to Senator Baume's question is no.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NUCLEAR TEST BAN TREATY AMENDMENT CONFERENCE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and relates to the partial test ban treaty amendment conference to be held in New York in January. I ask the Minister: what is the purpose of this conference, who will lead the Australian delegation, and will there be any Australian non-government organisation (NGO) representatives invited to join that delegation? I further ask the Minister: what will be the Australian Government's approach to the issues on the agenda of the conference? If there is a disagreement about extending the partial test ban treaty into a comprehensive nuclear test ban, would there be value in supporting adjournment of the conference to allow time for further work on such issues as verification of a nuclear test ban and the use of sanctions to enforce a ban?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of this amendment conference which is being held-as Senator Vallentine says-in New York from 7 to 18 January is to convert the Partial Test Ban Treaty which prohibits nuclear testing in the atmosphere, outer space and underwater into a comprehensive test ban treaty, thereby prohibiting underground tests as well. The Australian delegation will be led by a senior officer of my Department, Mr Alan Edwards, Assistant Secretary of the Peace, Arms Control and Disarmament Branch. I have also invited Professor Ian Maddocks, Chairman of the National Consultative Committee on Peace and Disarmament, to join the Australian delegation to represent NGO views. That is the Committee of which Senator Vallentine is a member. If that does not demonstrate charity and a willingness to embrace a diversity of views on the part of the Government, I do not know what does.

ANSWER.PARA: We will be seeking to participate actively and constructively to ensure that the amendment conference makes a substantive contribution to the objective of the conclusion of an effective and fully verifiable comprehensive test ban treaty. We do not, however, expect this amendment conference to achieve a short cut to such a comprehensive treaty. All present indications are that quite substantial disagreement continues to exist about converting the partial treaty to a comprehensive one, and we do not expect the amendment being sought to be agreed to.

The depository powers of the partial treaty, the United States of America, the United Kingdom and the Soviet Union, have a veto over any amendment to the treaty, and we expect that if the amendment is put to a vote the United States and the United Kingdom will vote against it. We hope, however, that the amendment conference can make progress on the nuclear testing issues. In particular, we will be seeking to further the development of work on the verification of a comprehensive test ban treaty. We and New Zealand are submitting a joint paper on verification for consideration at the amendment conference.

The Government does not believe that the conference should be extended or adjourned. Although we will do our best to make a success of the conference, we believe that the working body in Geneva, the Conference on Disarmament, is the appropriate forum for the detailed work required for the early conclusion of a comprehensive treaty, including verification, scope and compliance. The re-establishment this year in the Geneva Conference on Disarmament of an ad hoc committee on a nuclear test ban is a very important step forward in this respect, and we would not want to do anything to prejudice the ongoing effectiveness of its work.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for the answer, in particular relating to the substance of the conference and the Australian approach to it. But I am interested to follow up the question of an NGO representative, and I am very pleased to hear that Professor Ian Maddocks is to be included in the team. However, I ask: how much notice of an NGO inclusion was given to Dr Maddocks or anybody else? How was the decision made as to the NGO representative? Was there any consultation to ensure that the NGO person could be there for the entire conference? I do not wish to suggest that Professor Maddocks would be anything other than a very suitable representative, but I understand that he is able to be there for only part of the conference and that he happened to be in the vicinity of New York anyway. I ask: how much of the accommodation expenses will be met by the Department for the inclusion of Dr Maddocks in the team?
—What clothes will he be wearing?

—I do not know, I am afraid, in response to Senator McKiernan's interjection, what clothes he will be wearing. But I can say that the suggestion was put to me only a few days ago that Professor Maddocks would be an appropriate invitee. I responded immediately to that suggestion by writing to him. I was not aware of any limitations on his time. That is an issue that I will be happy to follow up to see whether we can ensure some continuity in other ways.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, concerns Cambodia. Is it the case that Michael Costello, Deputy Secretary of the Minister's Department, spoke to Prince Sihanouk in Pyongyang on 2 November, just a few weeks before the Minister's statement on Cambodia in the Senate last Thursday? Is it the case that Mr Costello, contrary to the Minister's statement to the Senate, told Prince Sihanouk that the increasing tendency in Australia and the Western world is towards the de jure recognition of the Hun Sen regime and towards a new armed Vietnamese intervention in Cambodia to liquidate the Khmer Rouge? Were these propositions of the Deputy Secretary's own making, or were they known to the Minister? What is the Australian Government's policy on recognition of Hun Sen and on any military containment of the Khmer Rouge? Is it the policy expressed by the Minister in his statement last week, or is it the policy put by Michael Costello to Prince Sihanouk?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Costello did speak to Prince Sihanouk in Pyongyang. I am not sure whether it was 2 November, I do not have the record in front of me.
—It was 2 November.
—I am indebted to Senator Teague for that confirmation. Perhaps he would like to table the document on which he bases his question at the conclusion of my reply. I invite him to do so.

ANSWER.PARA: The conversation was preceded, of course, by substantial discussions with me about what would be put to Prince Sihanouk, and was followed by a substantial report to me on the substance of that conversation. My recollection is a little hazy as to the detail. It is the case, I think, that Mr Costello would have indicated to Prince Sihanouk a theme which has been a recurring theme in all our conversations this year; that is, that there is a body of opinion in the West, which believes, short-sightedly, that the quickest way of achieving an appropriate resolution of the Cambodian problem is for there to be de jure recognition of Hun Sen. That is a short-sighted view for all the reasons I have put at length in answer to a question from Senator Teague earlier this week and, indeed, that I spelt out in detail in my statement in the Senate on 6 December.

I do not believe there would have, or could have, been any possible conclusion conveyed to Prince Sihanouk about the imminence of some armed intervention again in the situation in Cambodia because it is not my judgment, Mr Costello's or anyone else's whose advice I take or listen to that such a response of armed intervention is remotely likely in the event of the situation deteriorating and the Khmer Rouge reassuming some authority in Cambodia.

I spelt out the reasons for that, again in my statement last week. What I say in public on these important respects on this and on all other occasions is exactly the same as what I say in private. I do not have two agendas. I do not practice deceit in any respect in that way. It is my belief that the Western world, and indeed other regional countries, would be very slow indeed to get themselves immersed in such a situation in Cambodia, bearing in mind that there were 200,000 Vietnamese there for 11 years who were utterly unable to deal conclusively with the Khmer Rouge in a situation where they were supplied by an external power.

That situation would, I fear, be the case in the future. All of which points conclusively, once again, to the fact that if the tragedy of Cambodia is to be resolved, if the civil war in Cambodia is to be resolved and if a solution is to be found which enables all the parties in Cambodia to live in harmony, each with the other, then the only solution is the United Nations' peace plan devised by Australia, assiduously pursued by Australia and now adopted by the United Nations General Assembly Permanent Five and by all the regional countries and which we are now trying, with no help at all from Senator Teague or the Opposition, to bring to a successful conclusion as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I ask the third part of my question again, which the Minister did not answer: were these propositions of the Deputy Secretary's own making, or were they known to the Minister?
—The premise of the question is that there were propositions advanced which were inconsistent with the way in which I have described the situation. I do not accept that premise.

—Is the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support aware of statements made today by the Northern Territory Minister for Transport and Works, Mr Finch, that emergency position indicating radio beacons (EPIRBS) are ineffective in locating vessels in distress? Could the Minister advise on the so-called accuracy of that statement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —When Mr Finch said this on radio in Darwin, I could not believe what I heard. As the responsible Minister for this particular area in the Northern Territory, Mr Finch's statements are not only outrageously inaccurate but they irresponsible to the point of actually effectively putting people at risk. Lives could be lost as a result of the statements he has made.

ANSWER.PARA: I have made some strenuous efforts, both inside and outside this Parliament, to stress upon all mariners the great success of this new system of EPIRBS, and the facts speak for themselves. The emergency position indicating radio beacons have directly saved in excess of 60 lives since this system was established last October.

I am astonished by the statements made by Mr Finch. I cannot understand the basis for them. In fact, I asked my staff this morning to dig out the statement by Mr Finch in the Northern Territory News of the time boasting about the fact that Alice Springs was going to be used as the base for the ground station for the system, and saying:
NT Transport and Works Minister, Mr Fred Finch, said beacons would cost boat owners about $150 to install-``a very small price to pay for safety''.

There are State governments around Australia who are now moving to make the carrying of these emergency beacons mandatory-I would have hoped that would have included the Northern Territory-if people cannot be persuaded to carry them voluntarily, because, as I said in this House yesterday, these beacons dramatically save lives. The three most spectacular recent rescues of people using EPIRBS were all made off the coast of northern Australia in recent weeks-two of them in one day. So I do not know where the Minister has been on this issue. We are trying to persuade people to use them, not publicly persuade people not to use them on the grounds that they are ineffective. That statement is absolute nonsense.

As I said in the chamber the other day, and a recent event in the Northern Territory due to a cyclone has demonstrated this, not only does the failure to provide oneself with a $200 beacon endanger one's own life, but also, as shown in the case of this recent rescue in the Territory, it means that rescuers, who place their own lives at significant risk-as they did in that case, flying around in cyclonic weather conditions-have to spend several more hours searching for the vessel than they would have to if the vessel had an EPIRB. So the carrying of these EPIRBS does not just save the lives of the people in the boat; it also exists to preserve the lives of people who might go out and rescue afterwards.

I absolutely reject the statements made by Mr Finch. They really were very irresponsible. I hope he retracts them, and I hope that he encourages people in the Northern Territory to actually use these beacons and not to not carry them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. It concerns the request by the Palestine Liberation Organisation for an in-principle agreement to allow officials from PLO headquarters in Tunis and other PLO offices overseas to join the staff of the PLO office in Canberra. Approximately when was such a request received from the PLO? If it is still under consideration, as the Minister's office has advised in the last week or so, when might we expect a Government decision on the matter? Is there any possibility that the Government might agree to arrangements whereby the PLO could claim to have a charge d'affaires who is not an Australian citizen possibly on a diplomatic passport here in Australia? If the PLO request were acceded to, and if such an appointment were made, would it alter the status of the PLO and the PLO office in Australia in a formal way? If so, what formal status would the PLO office have?

—I cannot recall when the request was made. It was some considerable time ago. I have certainly been sitting on the request for some considerable time. I am in no hurry to respond to that request for reasons that should be reasonably obvious, the way the PLO has been behaving in recent times. Mr Kazak has been told on a number of occasions that there is no inhibition or constraint on employing Australian citizens in the office because the office has no official status, and there is no inhibition that we can legitimately place upon him in that respect. But there is a degree of significance attached to anyone coming from overseas for that. I am not sure that anything would technically, formally or automatically follow from allowing someone in from overseas for that purpose without any associated formal accreditation, but that would be a gesture of some significance and one that for the moment I am not prepared to make.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I preface my question with an expression of appreciation for the Minister's ready willingness to undertake inquiries into the disappearance in Dili, East Timor, of two students, Emilio Pereira, 24, and Narario Magno, 25. I ask the Minister whether he is aware of reports emanating from East Timor that after Pope John Paul II's visit, a large number of pro-independence protesters were arrested and tortured? How many reports of such human rights violations and related requests for assistance has he received since October 1989? Can the Minister advise what action the Australian Government is taking to assist people persecuted in this manner? Lastly, can the Minister advise how many of these people he has been able to assist?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say at the outset that Australia supports the universal observance of internationally accepted standards of human rights. We are concerned about abuses of human rights wherever they occur. It is our practice to make representations about such abuses-or possible abuses-not on a selective basis but in every country where we judge it productive to do so. In the case of East Timor, it is sadly clear that there has been something of a deterioration in the human rights situation over recent months, although it must be said that the situation has vastly improved on that which prevailed in 1989 and, in general, it is significantly better than at any time since 1975.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the more specific questions that have been asked, I am of course aware of the reports which emanated from East Timor after the visit of Pope John Paul II in October 1989 that a large number of pro-independence protesters were arrested and tortured. Those reports developed some currency at the time and have generated quite a lot since. But there was no conclusive evidence advanced to support what were very serious allegations. The Australian Ambassador to Indonesia led a team from the embassy in Jakarta to East Timor two weeks after the visit of the Pope, and he was specifically tasked by me to report on those allegations of human rights abuses following the papal visit. The Ambassador did have very wide-ranging discussions with Government officials, military authorities and prominent church and civilian figures in East Timor. The Indonesian Government did not hinder the latter discussions or act against those involved-a point which has been confirmed on subsequent visits to the province.

The Ambassador reported to me that he had not seen or heard any evidence to support reports of torture; that approximately 15 youths had been detained by local authorities for questioning following the demonstration and there was evidence that three of them may well have been beaten while in custody. The Indonesian authorities in Dili advised on 27 October that all persons detained from among the students who were involved in the demonstration at the papal mass had been released. That is as much as I can say on that question.

As to the second question about the number of representations on these matters that I and my Department have received, there has certainly been quite a regular flow of such representations since the papal visit in October 1989. Those reports come from a variety of sources, including parliamentary colleagues, ministerial correspondence and meetings with human rights groups. It is simply not possible to give an exact figure; all I can say is that it is quite a substantial number and quite a continuing flow.

As to how we react when confronted with these suggestions of abuse, as I have already said, we do maintain a close interest in developments in East Timor as elsewhere when these questions arise. We have certainly continued to raise with Indonesian authorities these questions on human rights in the province. I have raised them very regularly during my contacts with the Indonesian Foreign Minister, Ali Alatas. The Australian Embassy in Jakarta also regularly raises particular cases and, as I said, visits East Timor as often as possible. For example, the Australian Ambassador has registered Australian concerns about the human rights situation in East Timor with the Indonesian Government on three occasions in the last six weeks alone.

As to the last question, it is obviously very difficult to quantify the kind of success that flows from these representations and action. But we can, I think, claim fairly that we have very much raised the level of awareness in the Indonesian Government of the existence of such problems in East Timor and, certainly, the concerns held in Australia and the wider international community about their continued occurrence. Personally, I have no doubt that this enhanced awareness on the part of the Indonesian authorities generally has had a directly beneficial impact on the situation of those in the province who have either been victims or would have been victims of human rights abuses if we had not contributed to that consciousness-raising process. Further, I believe strongly that the substantial improvement in the bilateral relationship generally, which has occurred over the last couple of years, has greatly increased the preparedness of the Indonesian authorities to undertake a dialogue with us on human rights and investigate, on a regular and substantial basis, matters that we may raise with them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the Minister aware of the proposal before the Foreign Investment Review Board to sell 50 per cent of Elders meat division to Con Agra and a further 5 per cent to the D.R. Johnson Group which owns the Gyra meatworks in 50 per cent partnership with Con Agra? This would effectively give control of Australia's largest meat processing operation to an overseas company and place in overseas hands 33 per cent of the national cattle slaughter and 53 per cent of the Queensland slaughter. Is the Minister aware that an Australian consortium has been formed-Australian Beef Investments-which is eager to take a stake in the purchase of Elders meatholdings but has not been able to obtain sufficient information on which to base an offer? Will the Minister ensure that Australian interests have a proper opportunity to negotiate some stake in ownership and have an influence in the purchase of Elders meat division and that the Australian interests be able to provide proper safeguards in the national interest?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware, of course, that the Foreign Investment Review Board has the Con Agra proposal under consideration. I know of that because the Australian Beef Investments consortium to which Senator Boswell referred has written to several Ministers-including Mr Kerin and myself-about setting out their views about the proposed bid for this portion of the Elders business. I am not entirely aware of the circumstances behind the Australian Beef Investments consortium claim that it has not been able to obtain sufficient information.

ANSWER.PARA: I am not able to reveal details of the Con Agra proposal because such proposals which go to the Foreign Investment Review Board are commercial-in-confidence. I can say, however, that the Board will be making its decision shortly. I can assure Senator Boswell that the observations he has raised about concentration in the meat processing industry will be one of the important factors to be taken into account in the Government's consideration of this proposal.

I might add, on another note, that when one looks at the number of corporate failures that have taken place in the 1980s, the failure of Elders is, in some ways, the greatest of them all. Elders was a great Australian company, a great Australian pastoral house, with a number of other great businesses. Senator Boswell, as Leader of the National Party of Australia, will agree with me that in this period of corporate failures and concern about corporate behaviour it is a sad thing that throughout the decade of the 1980s that once great company was presided over by the President of the Liberal Party. In terms of setting standards--

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on!
—I would have thought Senator Boswell would have agreed with this.
—I asked you a serious question.
—This is a serious answer. Throughout that period--
—What about Bond?

—Senator Walters, when people look back at that period, at the reasons for big corporation business failures, why they happened and in what circumstances they started, and when they look back with concerns about corporate behaviour--
—They will remember Hawke's mate, Bondy.

—No. This is perhaps the greatest tragedy of them all, because Elders started as a great company. Bond and these people did not start with great companies; they were great acquirers. They did not start with great Australian companies which they destroyed, and it is a very sad fact for this country.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is there any truth in the claim by Mr Tom Uren in his letter to the Australian on 12 December 1990 that Mr Clinton Condon of the Australian Wheat Board was asked by Mr Kerin and Mr Hawke to go to Baghdad to seek the release of the four Australian Wheat Board staff held hostage?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is one aspect of Mr Uren's visit to Iraq that was not covered by my colleague Senator Robert Ray in his answer yesterday. It is probably the only aspect that was not covered. It is important to address this because if Mr Uren's claim is left unanswered, it does expose the Government to the charge of acting inconsistently and indeed hypocritically on the hostage issue, given our public stance of no official missions and no encouragement of any private missions.

ANSWER.PARA: The truth is that Mr Condon's visit was not in any way at the request, direction or instigation of the Government. The initiative for the visit came, in the first place, from the Iraqi grain board and then from Mr Condon himself responding to that invitation. Mr Condon did seek advice from the Government on policy implications and he was told, through Mr Kerin, that we would not stand in his way on the basis that he would not be engaging, of course, in any commercial negotiations, and that he would take such opportunities as arose to make the case for the release of all hostages, not just the Australian Wheat Board staff. Mr Condon's position is explained clearly in a letter he has written to the press today-the Australian and the Age-in response to those reports, and I seek leave to incorporate the text of that letter in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
AUSTRALIAN WHEAT BOARD
(Ceres House
528 Lonsdale Street
Melbourne 3000
Telephone: (03) 605 1555
Office of the Chairman
Clinton E. Condon
The Editor
The Australian
Dear Sir,
Following remarks made by Mr Tom Uren (Australian, 12.12.90), I wish to clarify references to my role in the release of Australians held hostage in Iraq.

The invitation to go to Iraq was issued by the Iraq Grain Board while I was on business in the Middle East. We had been having ongoing discussions with our contacts at the IGB about securing the release of the hostages and they believed it would be valuable if I could discuss the situation personally. Once the invitation was issued, as a formality, I contacted the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, John Kerin, and made him aware of the situation.

That was the entire contact I had with the Government. AWB staff in Melbourne, kept the Department of Foreign Affairs informed about any developments while I was away, as no doubt did embassy officials in Baghdad and Amman. At no time however was there any request, formal or informal, suggesting that the Government wished me to conduct discussions on their behalf. Obviously, on humanitarian grounds, I emphasised that I believed all hostages, not just those who were Australian or who were associated with the Australian grain industry, should be released.
I trust this clears up any misunderstanding that may have arisen.
Yours faithfully,
Clinton Condon

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. I refer to the Prime Minister's decision to review the Cabinet decision that the Australian Maritime Sea Safety Centre remain in Canberra. Who is conducting the review? When will the terms of reference be disclosed? When will they be answered? The real point of it all is: when will the employees of the Sea Safety Centre have certainty as to their future?

—That certainty is already there. The Sea Safety Centre will not be going to Newcastle, as I have made clear in the Senate. It was not an easy decision to come to, as I know Senator Reid is well aware.
—It was pretty easy before the election.

—In response, very briefly, to that interjection, the fact is that it was cost and location that determined the original decision, and it was cost and location that determined the subsequent decision. That certainty has arrived. The review has been concluded. It did not make the Canberra Times, I know, but considerable publicity was given to that in the Newcastle Herald in recent days. The review has been completed. The decision is final. In fact, the staff are aware of that. That has been communicated to the head of the Sea Safety Centre and the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. The unit will be remaining in Canberra.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. The Minister is undoubtedly aware that, in conjunction with International Human Rights Day, the Vietnamese community staged protests to mark continuing human rights violations in Vietnam. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the current human rights situation in Vietnam and what Australia is doing to help improve the situation? Secondly and more specifically, can the Minister inform the Senate of the up-to-date situation regarding two Vietnamese Buddhist leaders, the Most Venerable Thich Nhuen Quang and the Most Venerable Thich Quang Do? I understand that these people are the United Vietnamese Buddhist Church's National Council Deputy Chairman and General Secretary respectively, and that they have apparently been kept in custody by Vietnamese authorities without charge since 1982.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia has developed a dialogue on human rights issues with Vietnam and has raised, and continues to raise, individual cases with the Vietnamese authorities. As recently as 10 December, a couple of days ago, Australia raised specific human rights cases with Vietnam's ministry of foreign affairs. However, I have to say that, although our dialogue is more substantial, I think, than that enjoyed by any other country in this respect, we are disappointed at the limited responses to our representations.

ANSWER.PARA: Although a series of reforms and policy changes affecting human rights in Vietnam has occurred in recent years, we do remain concerned about the human rights situation in Vietnam. Judicial procedures often fall short of internationally recognised standards, and regulations providing for detention without trial remain in force. I am also very well aware that Amnesty International continues to report allegations of torture and ill-treatment in detention.

Concerning the two individuals mentioned by Senator McMullan, the Most Venerable Thich Quang Do and the Most Venerable Thich Nhuen Quang, the Australian embassy in Hanoi was advised by the Vietnamese authorities in mid-1989 that both had been released and were freely practising their religion in Nghia Binh and Thai Binh provinces respectively. We certainly have nothing to suggest that that is an inaccurate response. At least in respect of them, the news is good.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN NAVY FRIGATES: SPARE PARTS

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Defence. Is the Royal Australian Navy experiencing any problems in obtaining spare parts for the guided missile frigates which have been, or are now, deployed in the Gulf? Are sufficient spare parts available to meet the Navy's requirements? Is the Government delaying payment to companies for the supply of spare parts?

—The situation with spare parts and the frigates is satisfactory. From time to time, certain parts that have to be purchased from overseas simply are not available and there is some sort of time lag. On the whole, from my discussions with the captains and commanders of those ships, the situation was going very satisfactorily. As to the question of whether there are delays, there has never been a case when there have not been delays in the Department of Defence paying bills, simply because the bureaucracy is so large. If Senator Chapman has any specific examples, I would be happy to have them followed up.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to concerns expressed around the chamber about youth unemployment, the bleak prospects for school leavers, and the fact that 110,700 people have lost their jobs since July. Is the Minister aware that two years ago the Treasurer made a boast that in Australia families now have two or three incomes? Is the Minister also aware that his colleague Minister Dawkins said today that a cause of the current unemployment rate is that `the participation rate is extremely high'? Besides taking action to relieve enormous interest rates burdens on industries, individuals and families, what steps does the Government intend to take to financially recognise the value of homemakers' work and to give a true economic freedom of choice to those who, through economic pressure, have been forced out into the paid work force?

—Senator Harradine has referred to the figures relating to youth unemployment, which have been mentioned already in the course of Question Time in the Senate. I do recall the Treasurer saying, two or three years ago, that many families were enjoying two or three incomes. I was not familiar with Mr Dawkins's remark about the participation rate, but if one looks at today's figures one will see that the participation rate has scarcely declined at all. I think the point about unemployment figures now compared with eight or 10 years ago is that, if we had the same participation rates in the work force eight or 10 years ago as we have now, the unemployment figure would be considerably lower.
—It would be 2.9 per cent, in fact.
—I do not know whether Senator Cook's computer-like mind has brought that figure up to date with today's rates--
—It has.

—It has, and that is the figure in respect of the rate which would apply if the participation rates were the same as a few years ago. Implicit in Senator Harradine's question is his notion that there is some degree of social conscription in those high participation rate figures. That is a matter which is hotly debated and, if I might say so, not supported by the evidence. There is no doubt that in many countries in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development participation rates have grown considerably in the past few years. As Senator Vanstone once said, correcting some people in her Party, that was a proper and sensible thing to happen in the view of the Opposition. In terms of the last part of Senator Harradine's question, I can only put it to the Treasurer, whom I represent. I will do that, and try to provide a more detailed answer.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The inference was not social conscription; it was economic conscription. I simply ask the Minister: what steps has the Government taken to identify the large number of homemakers who have been forced, through economic reasons, out into the paid work force? Is it not a desirable feature, or policy, to see that they are given a true economic freedom of choice as to whether they enter the paid work force or do the job that they want to do?

—The supplementary question seeks to correct my prose rather than the content of my answer. I follow what Senator Harradine is saying; I understood what he was saying in the first place. His suggestion was that people are being forced to work. It was suggested throughout his question that that is due to difficult economic circumstances. The increase in the participation of women in the work force has taken place irrespective of the economic circumstances which have applied. Three or four years ago the economic circumstances in this country were very good. I undertook to try to get a further answer for Senator Harradine. I will do that and provide it as soon as possible.

—In Question Time earlier today Senator Teague asked me about Mr Costello's discussions with Prince Sihanouk in Phnom Penh. I am now able to say that I have had the matter checked both as to the record of conversation and as to Mr Costello's recollection of that conversation. I am able to say this: the conversation did take place on 2 November; on the question of the recognition of Hun Sen, the substance of the conversation was essentially as I described it in my answer; and there is no question whatever of Mr Costello having raised the issue of Vietnamese reinvasion or some Western intervention in the future or of having put it in the terms that Senator Teague described. There is no substance at all in that suggestion. I repeat my request that Senator Teague nonetheless table the document from which he was quoting. I make it clear that leave will be granted from this side of the House for him to do so if he is willing to.
—That is a matter for Senator Teague.
—First, I note that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade in his comments mentioned Phnom Penh when he meant Pyongyang.
—I am sorry, yes.
—Secondly, I was not quoting from any document. Nevertheless I have information which led me to ask my question today.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Government and Senator Coates, who is the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, for making these arrangements. Earlier this day I expressed concern at the guillotine process being applied to a very important Bill, perhaps one of the most important for many years to come before this Parliament. The 1 1/2 hours allocated was insufficient.
