SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table documents that I referred to earlier this day in raising a matter of public interest. The documents have now been perused by the Government and the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

The Australian Taxation Office taxation statistics 1988-89 is of course an annual presentation to the Parliament. It is a very voluminous document but therefore a very comprehensive one in terms of the taxation statistics for the nation. It gives some very interesting data about the operations of the Taxation Office.

The document and the statistics give a very clear indication of just how complex the tax administration and collection procedures of the Government have become. One of the great concerns for pretty well all Australians nowadays is both the bulk and the complexity of the tax legislation that confronts us. One of the clearest indications of that is the fact, so I am told, that about 70 per cent of all Australian taxpayers-although this may change with self-assessment procedures-in order to understand their taxation position, have required tax accountants to prepare their taxation returns. I am not sure whether that figure is accurate, but certainly an increasing number of taxpayers have had difficulty with the taxation system.

It is interesting that the Institute of Chartered Accountants, in a report released just a few days ago, was highly critical of several practices of the Commissioner of Taxation. Some examples are worth mentioning as they relate very closely to the statistics that the Australian Statistician collects. The report of the Institute is a very small one. I recommend that honourable senators read it. On page 5 of that report the Institute comments on the performance of the Australian Tax Office and expresses its concern that a very high level of administrative error, which is extremely expensive to correct, is made by the Tax Office. In the end that cost is usually borne by the taxpayer concerned.

The Institute also draws attention on page six of its report to the fact that the Commissioner refuses to accept that the Tax Office is culpable for the per annum component of incorrect return penalties. The Tax Office seems to see penalty tax as a revenue measure rather than as a compliance instrument. That is a matter for serious concern if the Institute is correct, and I hope that the Commissioner will look at it.

The Institute has also commented on the increasing complexity of tax legislation, particularly with respect to the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax and the provisional tax provisions. They radically increase the cost of compliance, forcing a greater workload upon tax agents. There is also reference to the delays in legislation and the odious practice of legislation by press release, which is a compliance nightmare in any area as complex as taxation. This clearly demonstrates, particularly in the area of indirect tax, that there is a great deal to be said-from the point of view of tax simplicity alone let alone all the other reasons-for having a goods and services tax of the type now being proposed by the Liberal and National parties. Such a tax will greatly simplify the tax system. It will reduce compliance and administrative costs; it will remove an array of inefficiencies caused by the wholesale sales tax, including the distortions to consumer choice, producer inputs and company structures; it will remove major burdens from our export and import competing industries; and it will enhance the integrity of the tax system by making inroads into the economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to speak on the Australian Taxation Office taxation statistics for 1988-89 which have been tabled today. In particular, I refer to table 6.5 on page 284 of that report, which dissects the sales that led to the collection of $10,000m in sales tax in that year of record. One of the things that comes out of that table is that, while the sales tax is imposed at rates of 10 per cent, 20 per cent, 30 per cent and 50 per cent in the case of luxury goods, at the moment there is no tax on food in Australia. The food area is completely exempt from tax, with some very minor exceptions. When one looks at that table and goes through the great detail of thousands of millions of dollars of sales of items in Australia one can see that, as well as there being no tax levied on food, no tax levied on clothing or footwear is documented in that table. I think it is very important to note that the present sales tax in Australia, which is levied at those four rates, basically exempts most food items and totally exempts clothing and footwear items from tax.

SPEECH.PARA: By the same token, tax is levied at a higher rate on luxury goods, such as expensive motor cars, which are taxed at 50 per cent. Tax is levied at a higher rate on things such as diamonds, jewellery and furs-luxury goods which are presently taxed at 30 per cent. Dr Hewson and Mr Reith, the Leader and Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party in the other place, want to replace the tax system that I am now talking about with a goods and services tax. Senator Short has tried to put forward some of the reasons for that particular tax today. The reality is that the areas which I have documented-food, clothing and footwear-will be slugged by the Liberal's proposed tax if they ever get into government.

The farming sector of Australia-the food producing industries-will be hit by a 15 per cent tax. If the Liberals bring in a tax levied at that rate the price of food, clothing and footwear will then increase by 15 per cent. I am surprised that members of the National Party of Australia who claim to represent the agricultural and rural sectors have not yet woken up to this tax and what it would do to the food producing industries of Australia when previously and currently tax exempt food items have a goods and services consumption tax imposed upon them. The reality is that staple items such as bread, groceries, fruit and vegetables and meat as well as all other food items will face this goods and services tax. If it is levied at 15 per cent, that is the price rise that will occur on those particular items.

The same applies to clothing. At the moment items such as general clothing, school uniforms and children's shoes are all tax free in this country. If the Liberals get into office and levy a 15 per cent consumption tax on those items their price will increase by 15 per cent. They will put a tax on the basic necessities, but meanwhile the price of luxury goods will be brought down in Australia.

As I have pointed out with regard to table 6.5 of this report, it is only the luxury goods in this community that are taxed at 30 per cent or 50 per cent. One needs only to look at the price of luxury motor vehicles, for example. At present under this Government a motor vehicle retailing for over $97,400 is taxed at a 50 per cent rate of sales tax. Under Dr Hewson and Senator Short that particular tax will probably decrease to about 15 per cent. So there will be a tremendous boost to the purchases of luxury cars under this Opposition if it ever gets into government, and the price of those particular vehicles will fall by about $20,000 at the same time as the price of fruit and vegetables, milk and bread goes up.

The people opposite want to boost luxuries. They want a Rolls Royce-or a limousine-led recovery in Australia as they replace the present equitable and fair sales tax with an unfair general goods and services tax at a rate of 15 per cent. They will give a tremendous boost to imported luxury goods-most luxury goods are imported into this country. I ask them: how will that improve the current account deficit and the balance of payments? How will a boost to luxury goods boost the balance of payments?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the major problems facing taxpayers nowadays is coping with the new idea of self-assessment, which has been introduced by the Government and the Australian Taxation Office (ATO). The other big problem facing companies nowadays, and indeed all taxpayers, is the problem of being certain of what the tax law really means and how it applies to their own particular affairs. There is also concern about the application of that law, because nowadays it appears to be a moving feast as some precedents which have been established over many years are suddenly being thrown out the door. The justification given for this by the Administration is that law evolves over time and people's understanding of the meaning of law constantly changes. But that is really not good enough in terms of certainty of taxation law.

SPEECH.PARA: The other big problem facing people is the problem of compliance-especially the cost of compliance which has been growing quite dramatically in recent times. In light of that and the statistics now before this Senate, I draw the Senate's attention to the need to start revising some of this voluminous information that is currently placed before it. This information is prepared not without considerable cost, both to the Taxation Office and also, more importantly, to taxpayers.

Perhaps the time has come to re-evaluate the significance of some of the collections that are contained in this report that is before us today. For example, does it really tell people a lot about the collection of income according to districts, parts or areas of cities or towns? Also, while it might be important to know the level of income derived from sheep and cattle grazing, sugar growing or vegetable production, for example, I wonder whether it really is significant to be informed about that income from the various forms in which business is conducted, whether it be as partnerships or corporations, et cetera. Surely what is really needed is the overall figure. Whether a person conducts a sheep and grazing business in corporate, partnership or sole trading form is really not important. We should be interested in the total amount of money derived from sheep or cattle grazing and the like.

I further take this opportunity to ask the Australian Taxation Office to look a little more closely at its own internal operations. I say that in a constructive rather than critical sense because I think it is important that such an examination should reflect the high professional capabilities of Australian Taxation officers and the need to lift the public perception of the Taxation Office. I know that the McKinsey report and the Institute of Chartered Accountants in Australia have addressed this issue, but I think it is time that the ATO devoted more resources to improving its public perception.

Time is overdue for the Government to ensure that there is proper balance between taxpayers' rights and responsibilities vis-a-vis the Commissioner of Taxation. We all know and acknowledge the rorts that took place during the 1960s and 1970s and the problems of the High Court of Australia in taxation matters. But perhaps we have now gone too far in the other direction and have put at risk the rights of honest taxpayers, rather than the rights of those who, in the past, have been scheming to their own advantage.

I refer to the continual erosion of taxpayers' rights. Yesterday or the day before, regulations provided before this Parliament denied taxpayers some further rights. I know that the regulations reflect the 1986 change to legislation, but now if a person is lodging an objection he or she must lodge it with the Taxation Office within the prescribed time not post it within the prescribed time. It is no longer good enough to be able to prove post, by post, certification or substantiation of the objection.

That is just another example of extra costs, and I believe that we could save money and a lot of time in the preparation of the additional information that must go on the back of the return. I think a lot of money is spent just for the purpose of preparing that document, and some of that material is not relevant. We must collect information, not data.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN NUCLEAR SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY ORGANISATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I wish to address the annual report of the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO), noting that here is clearly an opportunity to redirect government funding for energy research, expressing my concern over the future of the two reactors which will need decommissioning before long, if not immediately, and raising again concerns about the disposal of radioactive waste, which does not rate a mention in the report.

The report also contains nothing about the controversial export of fuel rods to the disgraced Hanford facility in the United States of America (USA) for reprocessing. These will be transported in casks of controversial manufacturing standard through suburban Sydney to get to the port for shipment. There have been no answers to all the questions outstanding on this issue nor to the questions relating to medium and low level waste. No mention is not good enough in an annual report of this nature. I am also concerned about the new collaborative program with the Korea Atomic Energy Research Institute and the conclusion of a memorandum of understanding with the China Institute of Atomic Energy and the China National Nuclear Corporation. Likewise I note that ANSTO represented Australia at the First International Conference for Nuclear Cooperation in Asia which was held in Tokyo in March this year, and that the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) is involved in the administration of funding bilateral nuclear assistance programs in the region.

The Chairman's report deserves to be strongly criticised following his comment that public attitudes and perceptions relative to nuclear matters remain very negative, and he blames the media for concentrating on the negative aspects of nuclear science and technology. That is hardly surprising. I would turn such comments around by asking how we can justify the continued funding of Lucas Heights while there are legitimate concerns about every aspect of the nuclear fuel cycle and while 46 per cent of Australians remain opposed to the mining and export of uranium and only 35 per cent are in favour of it.

With the Gulf crisis forcing us once more to think about the price of oil and the over-consumption in which we indulge, it might make more sense to decommission the two reactors at Lucas Heights and use the money from its nuclear component to develop alternative energy research. The report informs the Government and the public about the money earned from exports arising from ANSTO's work. Equally we could export products developed and manufactured in Australia relating to renewable energy resources. The world desperately needs further development of renewable energy resources as well as a reduction of oil consumption by the advanced industrialised countries. It is a furphy to argue that nuclear power is the alternative as oil is rarely used to generate electricity and never to propel transportation systems such as private cars, locomotives, trams or buses.

The report does not seem to mention the future cost of maintaining the reactors or what the decommissioning costs will be. These are costs the nuclear industry world wide never wants to admit to. It is clear that Lucas Heights is not a suitable site for such a facility as the southern suburbs of Sydney sprawl even closer and there are frequent allegations of contamination of the water systems around Lucas Heights. Again there is no mention of anything controversial like that in this report. The Chairman might criticise the media for concentrating on the negative aspects of nuclear science and technology, but he makes no attempt to refute allegations of the `wall of secrecy' made by Dr Arthur Tucker, who retired in 1985 after 21 years as the medical officer at Lucas Heights.

It is this kind of obsessive secrecy which has laid the nuclear industry open to similar criticism around the world. The more that is revealed, the more reason the world has to be alarmed about nuclear power. There has been escalating criticism of Soviet nuclear power programs since glasnost and perestroika allowed for such open debate, while in the United States there is growing evidence of the appalling long term damage caused around nuclear sites such as the Hanford reservation in Washington and the Rocky Flats plutonium facility in Colorado. There is also growing criticism of nuclear power in Asia, despite the repressive nature of many of the regimes there which are prepared to allow neither full and open debate on issues such as nuclear power nor access to information. That is why I expressed concern about ANSTO's links with Korea and China, where there has been criticism of nuclear power programs despite the disapproval of the authorities to that criticism.

I am not critical of all the work carried out at ANSTO's facility at Lucas Heights. For example, I applaud the acquisition of the cyclotron facility at the Royal Prince Alfred Hospital in Sydney. I urge that the next ANSTO report deal with issues such as commissioning dates and costs and the disposal of radioactive waste, and I urge the Government to phase out the dominant nuclear role of ANSTO and replace it with a body committed to developing renewable energy resources.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to speak to the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation report for 1989-90 and to pick up one of the aspects of ANSTO touched upon by Senator Vallentine a moment ago. I refer to the development of synroc by ANSTO, a proposal developed initially with the Australian National University. Honourable senators will recall the enormous publicity and ballyhoo that surrounded the proposal in the late 1970s and early 1980s. The Australian public and indeed many people around the world could be forgiven for believing that synroc was an up and running technology, which could be slotted straight into the long term storage of radioactive wastes. Those of us who followed the developments more closely knew very well that synroc had not been tested with fully radioactive material. We find in this annual report, on page 66, that the construction of the synroc demonstration plant commenced in 1982-83:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . on a non-radioactive demonstration plant to demonstrate the SYNROC fabrication process as a medium for the immobilisation and disposal of high-level radioactive waste.

The report goes on to describe the way in which that plant is simply designed to make synroc, a simulated rock, but a substance that will not contain radioactive material. We read also that synroc in 1989-90 cost $1.5m and the year before it cost $1.9m, but on page 66 we read that the synroc demonstration plant, in 1990 dollars, cost $8.8m. If we go back to the section on advanced materials on page 15, we find that again there is an admission that the plant is simply a simulation plant. It is not as yet designed to make synroc containing any radioactive material at all. Rather alarmingly, one finds:

. . . the Synroc Demonstration Plant has processed, cumulatively, 5.2 tonnes of Synroc. It is now operated in short campaigns designed to provide information for the conceptual active plant design study.

That study is scheduled for completion in June 1991. We go on with the development of a proposal actually to put proper radioactive material into synroc to see how it stands up under those conditions. We read also that the non-radioactive containing synroc is being tested, and the report refers to the `study of the long term durability in hot ground water of Synroc containing radioactive material'. Yet the material which has been made so far in the synroc plant does not contain radioactivity.

The importance of this is that a scientist who is now retired but who still works in the Department of Physics in the University of Adelaide demonstrated some time ago that materials such as glass and indeed synroc when exposed to high levels of radiation and subsequently to moisture underwent quite rapid deterioration. A significant question mark hangs over the viability of synroc to contain high levels of very radioactive material over long periods of time, and that is what is being expected of it.

We have many millions of dollars being spent on this technology, which is as yet unproved in the long term, but at the same time we have insufficient money being spent on alternative energy technologies. I make a plea again and back up Senator Vallentine's plea that this Government substantially shift its priorities and put money into those things which are viable and can make a very significant contribution to energy in this country.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

On page 7 of the annual report of the Grape and Wine Research Council is a reference to the major revenue raising of the Grape and Wine Research Council. That is derived from what was a 50c per tonne levy on grape growers in this country, a levy which increased to $2 per tonne from 1 January 1990.

One of the impressive aspects of this report is that it does outline in very great detail the various research projects that have been undertaken by the Council and a total expenditure in the last year of some $1,472,000. Details of that are located on page 23. The report outlines in considerable detail some 50 projects that are being undertaken by the Council, and I place on record the good work that this Council does in trying to foster the development of a very important industry in this country.

However, I have two concerns about the report and the projects being carried out by the Council. Firstly, if we look at the various aims and objectives and the plan of the Council, they do not, in my view, place sufficient emphasis on the need to ensure research projects that encourage the export orientation of grapes and wine in this country.

Some weeks ago I spoke on the annual report of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation, and I highlighted to the Senate the absolutely disgraceful levels of importation of overseas beverages, particularly French champagne and mineral water. Over the last 10 years, imports of these beverages have soared from $9m or $10m to some $50m. I think it appropriate that the Grape and Wine Research Council places greater emphasis on ensuring an export orientation of our wine and, particularly, champagne industry.

The other aspect of the report of which I am a little critical is that, despite the fact that the Council had at its disposal some $1,400,000 in grape levy funds from growers, it spent a miserable $10,742 in my home State of Tasmania-that is detailed on page 41-on one project out of some 50 projects that were undertaken over the last year. The project was carried out only in part in Tasmania; some part of the project was carried out also in the Eden Valley in South Australia.

A very small proportion of the total expenditure of the Council is spent in Tasmania. I certainly believe that it would be more appropriate, as I drew to the attention of the Senate in my speech on the annual report of the Wine and Brandy Corporation-given the doubling in the output of wine production in Tasmania over the last year, the need to reorientate our economy towards export industries and the rapid expansion of the production of wines in Tasmania which, I might say, are the finest wines in the world-to spend much more than $10,742 in Tasmania. I will certainly be writing to the Council and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin).

TALK.START.PARA: —You haven't been drinking, have you?
—No, unfortunately, I have not touched a drop of that fine Irish whisky that was sent to me the other day.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON THE FAMILY LAW ACT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Brownhill, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a joint select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act 1975, be appointed to inquire into and report upon the following matters:
The practice and application of the following aspects of the Family Law Act 1975:
(a) whether Parts II and III of the Act have been found to provide adequately for effective counselling and independent mediation;

(b) whether Part VII of the Act has been found to provide for fair and equitable resolution of custody and access matters and, in particular, whether the interests of children are being effectively safeguarded;
(c) whether Part VIII of the Act has been found to be effective in arriving at fair and equitable maintenance property settlements;

(d) whether the enforcement provisions of Part XIII of the Act have proven in practice to be effective and how the operation of this Part has been affected by the introduction of the Child Support Agency Scheme; and
(e) whether, in the abovementioned Parts of the Act, excessive discretion has been conferred upon the Family Court and, if so, how that discretion may be better defined.
(2) That the committee confine its inquiry and report to the terms of the Family Law Act 1975 and associated relevant policy matters.
(3) That provisions relating to the powers, procedures and composition of the committee be contained in a subsequent resolution.

This is a motion, of which notice was given by Senator Brownhill on 29 May of this year, that a joint select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act 1975, be appointed to inquire into and report upon a number of different matters. Senator Brownhill's motion refers to whether parts II and III of the Family Law Act have been found to provide adequately for effective counselling and independent mediation; whether part VII of the Act has been found to provide for fair and equitable resolution of custody and access matters and, in particular, whether the interests of children are being effectively safeguarded; whether part VIII of the Act has been found to be effective in arriving at fair and equitable maintenance and property settlements; whether the enforcement provisions of part XIII of the Act have proven in practice to be effective and how the operation of this part has been affected by the introduction of the Child Support Agency scheme; and whether, in the abovementioned parts of the Act, excessive discretion has been conferred upon the Family Court and, if so, how that discretion may be better defined.

Senator Brownhill, having put down that motion, was then required by the Senate to undertake responsibilities outside the country. He is currently representing Australia as a parliamentary adviser to our delegation to the United Nations. I assure the Senate that Senator Brownhill has been in constant contact with us from New York regarding the progress of his motion. If one reads his speeches to the Senate on the adjournment on 21 December of last year and 21 May of this year one will understand Senator Brownhill's very deep and genuine concern about aspects of the Family Law Act and matters of administration and practice concerning family law in this country. It seems that in fact a very large number of those persons within Australia who have been disappointed by aspects of family law or family practice have adopted Senator Brownhill to voice their concerns.

Mr Acting Deputy President, you will be aware that the Parliament has made a major contribution to the development of family law in this country through several previous joint parliamentary committees. I think it is not disputed that those committees have provided valuable input in this very difficult and often stressful area of law and administration.

What Senator Brownhill said was that there are now on the record so many examples of failure or inadequacy in relation to the current legislation or practice-I am not going to go through all the examples that he has put down in the adjournment debates, because under this arrangement we do not have time-that it is incumbent upon the Parliament to meet its reasonable responsibility, and that is to review again aspects of both the law and practice. The honourable senator gave a guideline in the form of the detail of his motion that I read a moment ago.

The Opposition has supported the concept of an inquiry into family law for a long time now. It was a policy which the Opposition had when it went to the last election. In particular, the Opposition said that there should be a public inquiry by virtue of a parliamentary committee to look at three aspects: applications before the Court concerning custody and access-the fact that they can be needlessly protracted and extremely expensive; enforcement of court orders, when a party deliberately flouts an order, when it is found to be frequently both ineffective and an unsustainable financial burden to the parties seeking enforcement; and the fact that property disputes can be delayed for up to three years before being heard. The Opposition says in its policy statement that such delays can impose real hardship on both parties to a dissolved marriage.

Having put down this motion in this chamber and the shadow Attorney-General, Mr Peacock, having put down a motion in similar terms in the other chamber and having stated in his address in support of the motion that our preference would be an adoption of the previous methodology in this area-that is, that there be a joint parliamentary committee rather than just a committee of the Senate-the Opposition naturally enough entered into a process of negotiation with the Australian Democrats and the Government.

Senator Spindler will be speaking in this debate today and he will no doubt indicate that the Australian Democrats took the alternative approach of putting to the Government a series of specific concerns that the Democrats had to see whether the Government would be prepared to meet those concerns. I think the Democrats were looking at that as an alternative to another parliamentary inquiry. I understand Senator Spindler will indicate that in some areas the Government has been prepared to come to the party but in other areas it has not.

Senator Spindler informs me, and will no doubt inform the Senate, that the Australian Democrats believe, on balance, that a parliamentary inquiry is now warranted. The Democrats want to provide an input into the detailed terms of reference of that inquiry because there is no point in inquiring into the aspects of their concerns that the Government has already been prepared to accept.

What the Opposition will be seeking at the end of the debate today is an adjournment of the debate on Senator Brownhill's motion. Our position obviously has been on the table: we want a parliamentary committee. The Democrats, as I understand it, are going to indicate that they accept there should be a parliamentary committee. Hopefully, in the next month or so, particularly upon the return of Senator Brownhill, detailed negotiations can take place between the Opposition parties, Senator Spindler on behalf of the Australian Democrats and, by then, I hope the Government-Senator Tate-to look at the terms of reference.

We presume that, once the Government is aware-as it is going to be aware today-that a parliamentary committee is going to be set up, it will also want to look at the alternative structures of such committees. I repeat, for the benefit of the Government, that we think the previous precedent should be adhered to and it should preferably be another joint committee. We presume also that the Government would then want to participate with us in determining the most appropriate terms of reference for that inquiry.

There are specific issues that can be put in a more precise form in terms of reference than currently appear in Senator Brownhill's motion. That would facilitate those within the community and the specialists-lawyers, academics and others who practise within the field-to give very specific advice and to help the Parliament in its law reform process. There is also the difficulty that the terms of reference must not be so specific that those in the community who feel they have had a particularly bad experience through the application of the law or practice are excluded from participating in this process. Part of democracy is to ensure that there is adequate opportunity for the community to participate in the development of the laws that ultimately govern aspects of their lives.

As you would know, Mr Acting Deputy President, there is probably no more difficult an area in which so much stress is created within the law as in the area of family law. Unfortunately, family break-ups so often bring with them tremendous emotional stress. When that emotional stress has to be handled through a regulatory mechanism, which of course there has to be under any family law regime, there are times when the law is found to be inadequate or frustrating. It is important that members of the community who feel that they have suffered have the opportunity to express their concerns and frustrations.

I hope that at the end of this half-hour debate the result will be that consideration of Senator Brownhill's motion will be adjourned; that over the next month or so, we can sit down with the Government and the Australian Democrats and determine the terms of reference. I hope this will result in a joint parliamentary committee and that upon returning to the Parliament at the beginning of the next session in the early weeks of February, in both Houses of the Parliament, by agreement of all parties, there is put down a motion setting up a joint committee to investigate these areas of family law. I think that would help us meet our responsibility to the Australian public.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Spindler has generously allowed me five minutes to put a position and support Senator Brownhill's motion. I know that today would be a very happy day for Senator Brownhill because he has taken a great deal of interest in this issue. I believe it was Senator Brownhill who initiated, through the Liberal-National Party coalition, the first resolution to put down a notice of motion. It has now come to my attention that the Australian Democrats are going to support the motion in principle, but they will seek some input into the terms of reference. The main thing is that we are going to get a Senate inquiry into the problems caused by the Family Law Act as it stands.

SPEECH.PARA: It is appropriate that this matter has come before the Senate today. It is very important for the National Party. One of the major planks in our policy is that the family is the basic unit of society and all legislation should stem from and be based on that premise. I am pleased for Senator Brownhill, who is overseas on parliamentary duties at the moment. I am very glad that when the honourable senator comes back he will have this inquiry on foot.

Nothing hurts families more than break-ups. There is a great deal of hurt when people finally decide to break up. Although we would like it to do so we know that this inquiry will not address all the problems that are faced as a result of marriage break-ups. However, we do believe it is a step in the direction that will alleviate some of the hurt that, unfortunately, people have to go through when their marriages break up and afterwards. Mr Acting Deputy President, I agreed to take three or four minutes. I will stick to that agreement with Senator Spindler. I thank the Democrats for their support of this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter arose with the notice of motion given by Senator Brownhill, which was described in some detail by Senator Hill and Senator Boswell. The Australian Democrats at the time supported it in principle but deferred the decision because we felt that it was not necessarily in the best interests of those people who were concerned and hurt by the operation of the Family Law Act to enter into a 12-month period of a parliamentary inquiry, at the end of which no action may be taken, although a report may be produced that would once again gather dust on the shelves, or at least it would take some months before we could get any results. We thought it would be advantageous for all parties if we first tried to get the Government to take some action in those areas we had identified in consultation with people and groups who approached us with concerns in the family law area.

SPEECH.PARA: I will list some of the details of the concessions that the Government has agreed to and has made. We believe they have warranted the three months delay, but we do not believe they are substantial enough to prevent a parliamentary inquiry to ensure that the issues are properly canvassed and that action is then expedited. I am pleased that this matter has not been made a political football and that it has been possible to reach agreement with the Opposition parties to develop a set of terms of reference for this inquiry which I think will make it a constructive one and one that can bring some real relief to people concerned.

There were some 14 matters to which we drew the attention of the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy). Several have yielded some positive responses. One of the important matters that we put to him was mediation centres. We asked for a 20 per cent increase in funding. The Attorney-General was able to demonstrate that in the current year the Government was instituting a program on the basis of a 103.8 per cent increase on top of the grants made in 1989-90 for eight existing family mediation services and for new services in Tasmania, the Australian Capital Territory and New South Wales. We were pleased with that response. We have also got a commitment to continue that level of funding in real terms at least, with some possibility of an absolute increase.

The second request was for a duty lawyer to attend at family courts. We had specified five registries as ones of priority, namely, Sydney, Brisbane, Adelaide, Melbourne and Parramatta, and possibly Dandenong. This is an area where the Attorney-General was not able to give us any firm commitments. Therefore, that remains very much on the agenda.

The third matter was the funding for a family assistance bureau to be attached to the Family Court. Following extensive discussions, we reached the conclusion that the `Network' system being used in Victoria, attached to the Melbourne Family Court, was a useful model. Our approaches coincided with some doubt about the funding of Network. We were able to obtain an assurance from the Attorney-General only a fortnight ago that the funding for Network will be continued, with funding assured until 1992 and 1993. We are disappointed that he was unable to make a commitment to extend that service to the other States.

In the matter of Family Court judges, we asked for six. The Attorney-General was prepared to appoint two, one in Victoria and one in New South Wales. It is a start. While we take some cognisance of the arguments put forward by the Attorney-General, namely, that better management of cases and mediation services and alternative dispute resolution will reduce the load on Family Court judges, we believe that, if the system is to work to the satisfaction of people who are going through an extremely traumatic stage in their lives, the Government must agree to provide a further increase in Family Court judges.

The next item is matrimonial property. The Democrats basically agree with the Australian Law Reform Commission's proposals and suggested that we should move towards implementation of those proposals. We are conscious, however, that there are some problems as yet unresolved, particularly in the area of how to deal with superannuation when a couple divorces, and some problems where a business or farm is involved. These problems are still awaiting resolution. We have assurances that the Government will move in this area as quickly as possible. We understand that a draft paper has been under consideration by the Attorney-General. We expect to receive some response as quickly as possible on that matter.

Another area on which we approached the Attorney-General was marriage education. Our proposal here was that the Government should increase funding for marriage education by at least 20 per cent. The Attorney-General was able to demonstrate that he has met a commitment to increases of 93 per cent in 1990-91 to peak bodies and 54 per cent to existing marriage education services. We are pleased with that because it is an extremely important area. Clearly, prevention is much better than cure, as anyone who has gone through the family law system could testify.

We have also been given firm assurances that funding for the Family Law Council and the Institute of Family Studies will be maintained in real terms. That is the extent of the firm commitments which the Government was able to give to us. We believe there are quite a number of other areas which, though difficult, require resolution. It is for that reason-since we were not able to get firm assurances in the other areas-that we believe a parliamentary inquiry is now required and justified to give some impetus to the necessary reforms in the family law area.

One of the most important areas is that of child sexual abuse. While the Senate will be dealing with a Bill which will enact some amendments in that area, it is far from being a complete solution. We have obtained an assurance from the Attorney-General that there will be a review by the Family Law Council after 12 months operation of those amendments, provided they are passed by the Senate.

There are other issues that are difficult but require a determined effort to resolve. They include the independent representation of children; the supervised access situation where it has proved difficult for parents to agree to have access to children in a civilised manner; and the videotaping of counselling interviews. With the latter matter, we were met with the concern that costs would escalate, that the extent of videotaping could be doubtful and that, in some cases, the legal process may be prejudiced by the videotaping of counselling interviews and, therefore, the evidentiary process could suffer.

We do not necessarily accept all these arguments, nor do we accept the wait and see answer that we received to one other request, which was to drop the cost of transcripts of court proceedings from $7.50 a page to $2 a page, which we believe the Family Court should charge.

We believe that the Family Court has a particular constituency which is quite different from that of any other court, and we believe there is a case to make a distinction between that and other courts. That is the extent at the moment of the issues that were discussed with the Attorney-General.

I once again put on record my satisfaction at the fact that we are able to tackle these issues in a constructive manner and that we are not making them into a political football. If we did, we would do great harm and disservice to the people who are going through a traumatic period in their lives. I understand that Senator Harradine would like to say a few words, and I am pleased to give up my remaining time so that he may do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a motion by Senator Hill, moved on behalf of Senator Brownhill, for the establishment of a select committee to be known as the Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act 1975. My view is that if the Committee gets off the ground it will certainly have very important tasks to perform. There is probably no other piece of Commonwealth legislation which has produced such continuing animosity from ordinary people who have come under its operation.

SPEECH.PARA: The question is: if we are to have a parliamentary inquiry into the Family Law Act, do the proposed terms of reference permit a consideration of those subject areas of concern to many people? Since the Family Law Act came into operation there have been over 600,000 divorces and something like three quarters of a million children have been directly affected. The Committee should operate against that background. The parameters of the proposed inquiry are drawn and relate to certain matters. I should like to pose a couple of questions. For example, will paragraph (1) (a) permit a thorough examination of the reconciliation and counselling, bearing in mind that the consideration of reconciliation is one of the basic principles under section 43 of the Act, to which the court is supposed to have regard?

Will the implementation of all of the principles contained in section 43 be a matter for consideration by the committee for the purposes of ensuring their implementation? One should have thought so because paragraph (2) of the terms of reference refers to `associated relevant policy' and states:
That the Committee confine its inquiry and report to the terms of the Family Law Act 1975 and associated relevant policy matters.
Clearly, section 43 of the Act deals with relevant policy matters, and that deals, inter alia, with the point that was raised by Senator Boswell. It states:
(a) the need to preserve and protect the institution of marriage as the union of a man and woman to the exclusion of all others voluntarily entered into for life;

(b) the need to give the widest possible protection and assistance to the family as the natural and fundamental group unit of society, particularly while it is responsible for the care and education of dependent children;
(c) the need to protect the rights of children and to promote their welfare; and
(d) the means available for assisting parties to a marriage to consider reconciliation or the improvement of their relationship to each other and to the children of the marriage.

Clearly, that is an essential feature of any inquiry and to see whether those principles are being given proper effect to in other areas of the legislation. I am advised by practitioners in the family law area that the equitable and just treatment of spouses, the counselling and mediation procedures and the difficulty about property settlements are all areas warranting investigation. To the extent that the motion covers these areas and the others that I have mentioned, it will certainly be helpful.

I, together with, I suppose, every one of us in this chamber, and probably everyone in the House of Representatives-probably more particularly in the House of Representatives-have received constant representations from constituents concerning the operation of the family law legislation. As I said, it is a piece of legislation which has produced continuing animosity from ordinary people, more so than any other that I can think of. I hope that this committee will get off the ground and serves good purpose.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION ELECTION RULES

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the President, I present to the Senate a copy of the reasons for judgment of the Federal Court of Australia in Thorpe v. Minister for Aboriginal Affairs relating to matter of the tabling of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission election rules, which were the subject of debate in the Senate on 6 and 7 November 1990.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I wish very briefly to speak to that motion. In the judgment which has been tabled, one of the learned judges, Mr Justice Northrop, had this to say about the failure of the Government to apply proper procedures to this election:

There is no material before the Court explaining why the Regional Council election rules were not laid before the Senate in conformity with the requirements of s.48 of the Acts Interpretation Act. Nevertheless, this failure illustrates an arrogance by the Executive-
that is, by this Government-

which borders on contempt for the Parliament. The failure is very serious. It is to be condemned. It cannot be condoned. It is a fact which has occurred but it is not for this Court to investigate why it occurred.

There can be no more serious comments by a learned judge about the impropriety-the misbehaviour-of a government than those remarks. `It cannot be condoned', he said. `The failure is very serious. It is to be condemned'. When His Honour said, `it is not for this Court to investigate why it occurred', he was clearly indicating to the Senate, to the Parliament, that the Parliament should very seriously examine this disgraceful behaviour by the Government; this behaviour which, as the judge said, cannot be condoned.

It is reasonable in these circumstances, when we have evidence of treating the Parliament with contempt, to ask: what is the Government doing about it and what is the Government doing about the Minister who was in charge? When the judge says that it was displaying, `an arrogance by the Executive which borders on contempt for the Parliament', it is reasonable for us to ask: is it this Government's policy to continue the commission of a Minister whose `arrogance borders on contempt for the Parliament'? If it is not the Government's policy, what steps does the Government intend to take to replace Mr Tickner as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs?

The failure is very serious and is to be condemned, as the judge says. We want to know what steps are being taken to guarantee that the Senate will not in future be denied the opportunity legitimately to scrutinise such legislation. Quite frankly, we want to know what steps are being taken in relation to Mr Tickner's demonstrated avoidance of ministerial responsibility in this matter. We are also entitled to ask if the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) will ensure that in future all his Ministers comply with their legal obligations and suggest to them that it might not be a good idea to seek to blame departmental officials, as Mr Tickner has done in this instance. There is a thing called ministerial responsibility, and a failure to meet it in the past had very serious consequences for the Minister. Apparently those standards do not apply any more.

This Senate cannot simply ignore these very serious, critical remarks by a judge. I do not want to pursue this matter now because we are acting under a very short time pressure under a guillotine. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the President, in accordance with the provision of the Audit Act 1901, I table the following report of the Auditor-General, report number 18 of 1990-91, Specific Purposes Payments to and through the States and Northern Territory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

Like Senator Baume I, too, am under a very tight time constraint and so I want to take just a couple of minutes to say a few words about the Auditor-General's report No. 18 of 1990-91, Specific Purpose Payments to and through the States and Northern Territory. At this stage I draw the Senate's attention to some of the key findings of that important audit report. The report has come up with four key findings. The most important read as follows:

* while the arrangements for all SPPs required adequate assurance to be provided to the Commonwealth that its funds were being expended on intended purposes, delay in the provision of statements of expenditure and independent certification indicates a failing in accountability by Commonwealth departments to Parliament. For those SPPs where this assurance was required, 49% of the statements of expenditure and 70% of the independent certificates for 1988-89 payments had not been received at the time of the survey-
of which this is a report-
* in July 1990.
That is a very considerable time delay. Another key finding reads:
* 12 per cent of programs did not have clear objectives established, and
* there was a reported absence of performance indicators for 56% of SPP programs and this brings into question the value of the performance review which is reported as undertaken.

We are not talking about small funds here; we are talking about 48 per cent of the total payments that the Commonwealth makes to the States each year. That 48 per cent translates, in dollar terms, into $12.6 billion of specific purpose payments. So we are talking about a major item of government expenditure. I am sure that many honourable senators and others would be surprised at the findings that there is in so many instances a lack of proper accountability for those funds and significant delays in the reporting on their usage.

This raises various questions. First of all: how could this have occurred? There are important recommendations by the Australian Audit Office, which I think the Parliament would do very well to examine carefully, as to how a repetition of this may be prevented. It raises a couple of important issues of a conceptual nature which the coalition has been raising for some time. This will be subject to further consideration in the series of Special Premiers Conferences that are in train at the moment, in support of which the coalition has been joining the Government.

One of the critical points that come out of this is that if, in fact, 12 per cent of the specific purpose programs did not have any clear objectives, and if there was a reported absence of performance indicators for 56 per cent of the specific purpose programs, then why have specific purpose payments at all? Why not incorporate or encompass specific purpose payments-section 96 of the Constitution payments is what we are talking about-into the general purpose payments that the States receive from the Commonwealth without strings attached?

One of the great problems that the States face today is the fact that an increasing amount of funding that they receive from the Commonwealth Government is in tied form through these specific purpose payments.

TALK.START.PARA: —So that they can get political grandstanding.

—There is a great deal of politics in this-Senator Michael Baume says that there is political grandstanding-but there is also the ever increasing central control by Canberra on the purse strings of the States. That has a great deal of political and economic importance as well, because it hamstrings the operations of the States.

SPEECH.PARA: Another thing that emerges from this report is that the specific purpose payments seem to involve a great deal of administration in their carriage. This is another important reason why we should be looking at the whole question of specific purpose payments relative to general purpose payments and the whole question of duplication and overlap that arises. It is a far too detailed and important subject to go into any further today. I draw the Senate's attention to what I believe is a very important report by the Auditor-General. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
