SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly because we are conscious that if some time can be saved on the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill, bearing in mind that it had 3 1/2 hours before the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs last night, that time can be appropriated to another Bill that did not have that extra consideration. The Committee report of course was put down in the chamber this morning.

SPEECH.PARA: My first point is that to some extent that procedure served a worthwhile purpose; that is, it enabled some practitioners, some specialists, particularly representatives such as Professor Austin, who appeared for the Law Council of Australia, as well as representatives from the Law Institute of Victoria and from business and commerce, in particular the Business Council of Australia, to put their current concerns on the parliamentary record. It gave the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) the opportunity to answer some of those concerns.

This was particularly important in relation to this Bill because of the ridiculous timetable that the Government has allowed for the passage of its corporation package. I remind you, Mr Chairman, that this highly complex piece of legislation, based on a novel experiment in constitutional law-a new way of attempting to interpret federalism to produce what is perceived to be a national corporation law package-clearly requires very detailed and careful consideration.

These people were able to put their concern on the record. The Minister was given an opportunity to provide answers; some he provided last night through his officers who were present and some he will provide today. I think that Senator McMullan will cover the concerns expressed by the Law Council and the Victorian Law Institute as well as another range of legal issues raised by Perpetual Trustees WA Ltd, whose concerns came in only last night.

The time frame really was ridiculous. This package is to come into force, to be law, on 1 January next year. Here we are, half-way through December, and the legislation is only now before the Parliament. After it has passed this process it will of course receive the royal assent. The Government then moves into its regulation phase. Regulations will be critical to implement this package. Those regulations have not yet been made; we certainly have not been afforded the opportunity to see them. They have to be made, then printed and distributed, and all this has to happen within the week before Christmas.

I made the point during the second reading debate that this is quite inappropriate law making. In those circumstances it is impossible to expect legal practitioners to be properly aware of their obligations under the legislation and in a position to properly advise their clients. Even more so, it is totally impossible to expect consumers of corporate law, businesses in particular, to be properly aware of their new legal obligations.

To some extent, some aspects have been overcome by a moratorium that Mr Hartnell from the Australian Securities Commission was prepared to give in relation to aspects of the new corporate number system and the endorsement last night by the Minister of Mr Hartnell's moratorium. It is fair to say that there are still many aspects of that which are unclear. Mr Hartnell has undertaken to have published further explanations. A number of issues raised last night will be included in those explanations. Hopefully, they will be of some assistance to the business consumers. Nevertheless, it is clearly unsatisfactory, even in that aspect, that companies have to try to get on top of the extent of the moratorium that has been given during the week preceding Christmas.

The more difficult questions-the questions of law-raised by the legal bodies I mentioned have now been answered by the Government, but of course not answered in a way that they can be properly debated. That was not possible within the committee system, given the very short time frame for the hearing, given also that some of the legal concerns came before us only an hour or so before the committee hearing, and given that the responses to some of those were received from the Government only in the last hour or so.

While the committee process was useful, it could have done a better job if the Government had afforded a more appropriate time frame for the passage of this legislation. As I indicated during the second reading debate, the result will be many legal failings in the package. History demonstrates that that will be the case. The history of the Government's attempts at corporate reform over the last few years, even to the extent of the corporation law being defeated in the High Court on constitutional advice that the Government had before it had it passed this chamber, is a further demonstration of law making in this area that has not received the attention or the care that it deserves.

These issues of differing legal interpretation are now on the table; they are on the public record. The best I can say is that the professional bodies and the Government will continue arguing and presumably will come back in the new year with another amendment Bill. I suspect that it will be larger rather than smaller, containing amendments which the Government now says are necessary-amendments which may not have been necessary if the Government had put more time and care into this legislation.

Apart from the question of law there is also the question of the difficulty that comes about from the fact that, although it is designed to be a national scheme, one of the States-Western Australia-is not presently a party to it. The very major obstacles that that will present were put very clearly to the Committee last night, particularly by the Law Institute of Victoria. Most of those concerns remain unanswered and there is no doubt that in the ensuing months it will be very difficult for businesses that cover Western Australia and other States.

I also said in the second reading debate that I wished that the Commonwealth had approached Western Australia earlier in a more conciliatory way. I wished that even in the latter stages it had accepted our advice and asked the shadow spokesman, Mr Costello, to confer with the Opposition parties in Western Australia. But the Government was not prepared to do so, and we find that we are in the current impasse, the Western Australian Parliament having risen for the Christmas break and the legislation not having been passed there. I hope that an accommodation can be found with Western Australia in the near future because we have recognised as the goal of this legislation a national type scheme with aspects of cooperation.

We have argued in previous speeches we have given on earlier Bills-not in detail; the details varied over the years-that the Commonwealth should look to resolving a difficult federalism issue through goodwill and cooperation. That is what we put to the Government a long time ago. As I said, it has taken the Government years to get to the stage where it has now got the State governments to come to the party within a new cooperative venture which largely provides for a national type scheme. It is just a pity that it did not go one step further and look to embrace the party that controls the Western Australian Parliament through the upper House. But our experience is that this Government is a slow learner when it comes to cooperative federalism, and so we now have to go, unnecessarily, along another path of difficulty.

I commend the report of the Committee. I commend members of the Committee who participated, under difficult circumstances, in the debate last night. It has enabled a modestly more thorough examination of the legislation by the Senate. We have certainly done better than the House of Representatives, which was given only one hour in which to debate this total package. Through the mechanisms that are available to us in this chamber, we have been able to extend that time by some hours. I therefore reiterate in the committee stage the Opposition's support in principle for the design of the package that has been proposed. I indicate the Opposition's support, albeit that we worry about the detail and the fact that it has not been given adequate care and consideration.

I hope that our concerns are not demonstrated to be as well founded as I suspect they are. Practitioners in this field have had to work in areas of great uncertainty for too long. It is time that there was some certainty in the area of corporate law in this country. That can only help facilitate Australian business. It can help facilitate our becoming nationally and internationally competitive again in business, and that will be in the best interests of all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a brief statement at this stage on behalf of the Government. I will then seek leave to incorporate two documents, which I understand have been distributed and to which Senator Hill has referred. I think it would be useful to do that at this early stage. The statement is a brief one, but I wish to clarify one matter in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs so as to avoid any confusion in the minds of honourable senators. At the end of paragraph 13 of the report it is stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister referred to the 6 month `period of grace' that would operate immediately following the commencement of the new legislation and said Mr Hartnell, as chairman of the ASC, would exercise his discretion accordingly.

I wish to make it clear that, as honourable senators who were on the Committee will recall, the six-month period of grace refers to the moratorium on the Australian company number. The period of grace refers to the announcement by the Australian Securities Commission, with the support of the Government, that it would not enforce for six months from 1 January the requirements of section 219 (3) of the corporations law for companies to place the Australian company number on their public documents and eligible negotiable instruments.

The discretion that is referred to in that paragraph concerns the powers of the Australian Securities Commission under section 1084 of the corporations law to provide exemptions from the prospectus and other fund raising provisions in appropriate cases. Having put that statement on the record, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard two documents, the first entitled `Response to Part B of submission of Victorian Law Institute to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs' and the second entitled `Response to the submission to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs by Perpetual Trustees W.A. Ltd'.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
RESPONSE TO PART B OF SUBMISSION OF VICTORIAN LAW INSTITUTE TO SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON CONSTITUTIONAL AND LEGAL AFFAIRS CONCERNING THE CORPORATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL
The meaning of commercial documents may be altered by updating of references from the existing Law to the Corporations Law.

* The purpose of s. 80 of the Corporations Act is, amongst other things, to facilitate commercial convenience by avoiding the need for parties to alter instruments and documents to take account of the replacement of the existing co-operative scheme law as the substantive law, governing companies and related matters, by the Corporations Law.
* The provision also updates relevant references to the Corporations Law in other legislation and regulations, thus avoiding the need for substantial consequential legislative amendments.
* The effect of the provision may be modified in appropriate cases by regulation, for example to remove any unintended effects.
A 20% shareholder is deemed to have a relevant interest in all shares held by directors.

* This was a policy change included in the original drafting of clause 33 of the Corporations Bill as introduced in May 1988, and was identified as such in the Explanatory Memorandum (paras. 272-273). It is therefore not a random defect. It is designed to reflect the fact that a shareholder who holds over 20% of the voting shares in a company not only has a considerable influence over that company but is also in a position to exercise control over the directors of the company.
A company may be able to disavow a sealed contract by failing to include its company number in the seal.

* A failure to comply with the formal requirements of s.219 (1) to include the Australian company Number on the company's seal would not appear to render invalid any company document executed under such a defective seal.

* In Westpac Banking Corporation v Dawson (1990) 2 ACSR 316 the NSW Court of Appeal decided that the failure of a company to use the seal required by the provisions of the existing law which corresponds to s. 219 did not make invalid the execution of the document under seal by the company. The Court considered that such a non-compliance would go to penalty but not to validity.

* This decision is consistent with the traditional approach of the Courts to avoid, in the absence of a manifest legislative intention, rendering invalid commercial documents for regulatory infractions. In a similar case it has been held that the failure to correctly set out the name of the company on a contract as required by the company law provision corresponding to s. 219 did not render the contract void or illegal: Moreland Metal Company Ltd v Cowlishaw (1919) 19 SR (NSW) 231.
No reference to indebtedness is s.324 (3).

* Paragraphs 324 (1) (e) and 324 (2) (f) refer to a person or a body corporate in which the person is a substantial shareholder who `owes' more than $5000 to a particular company or body corporate. While these paragraphs do not specifically use the term ``indebtedness'', the references in those provisions to `owes' are clearly the references to indebtedness to which subsection 324 (3) relates. The word `owes' was used in sub-sections (1) and (2) in the interests of plainer and more effective drafting. Section lO9k of the Law indicates that changes to the style in which a provision of the Law is expressed are not intended, merely for that reason, to indicate any change of meaning.
A co-operative company cannot ascertain whether its shares are being acquired by stealth.

* Part 6.8 of the Corporations Law deals with the power of a company and the ASC to obtain information from a registered shareholder as to the beneficial ownership of the shares held by that shareholder. The equivalent co-operative scheme law provision is s.261 of the Companies Codes.

* As explained in paras. 2216-2217 of the Explanatory Memorandum to the Corporations Bill 1988, the existing provisions have been open to abuse by members and companies seeking to obtain strategically important information. In particular, the provisions had been used by shareholders or Boards of Directors in some companies whenever a minor change in the share register appeared. A package of reforms was included in the Corporations Bill to alleviate these concerns.

* The Companies Code provisions are available to any company as defined in s. 5 (1) of the Companies Code, ie any company incorporated or deemed to have been incorporated under the Companies Code. This includes several primary producer cooperative companies that were incorporated under the Uniform Companies Acts.

* The Corporations Law provisions, as a response to the abuses noted above, enable the ASC to seek this information and, as a result of a recommendation of the Joint Select Committee on the Corporations Legislation, the right of the company to seek the information was reinstated. However, because of the abuses of the existing provisions, especially in relation to unlisted companies, the provisions now only apply to listed companies or other companies declared by the Minister for the purposes of that Part.

* Any unlisted primary producer co-operative company registered under the Corporations Law may, therefore, gain access to these provisions by seeking a declaration from the Minister. However, automatic access in the legislation was restricted to listed companies as a result of the abuses of the current provisions noted above.
Substantial shareholders may not need to lodge a notice under the Corporations Law.

* A person who is a substantial shareholder for the purposes of s. 261 of the Companies Codes is not required to lodge a new substantial shareholding notice, notifying the company of his or her substantial shareholding, upon commencement of the Corporations Law, provided a notice was lodged with the company under the co-operative scheme law (s. 758 of the Corporations Law). This is because notices lodged under the co-operative scheme law are kept in a register by the company, which can be accessed by the public. There is a corresponding requirement under the Corporations Law for the company to establish and keep a register of substantial shareholding notices, and by virtue of ss. 152 (2) of the Corporations law a company that kept a register for the purposes of co-operative scheme law is deemed to have complied with the requirement under the Corporations Law to establish a new register.
* There is, therefore, no need to put substantial shareholders to the expense of having to lodge a new notice upon commencement of the Corporations law.

* However, an existing substantial shareholder will be required to lodge a notice if that person ceases to be a substantial shareholder or if the person's entitlement to voting shares increases or decreases by more than 1% since lodging a notice (sections 710 and 711 of the Corporations Law). These requirements apply to all substantial shareholders whenever they become one.
Private business trading trusts will require a prospectus and a trust deed that are appropriate to a unit trust.

* Interests in private trusts and other private business arrangements were to have been exempted from the fundraising provisions by virtue of an exemption for offers to up to 20 persons over a period of 12 months in s.66 of the Law. This exemption was made inapplicable to prescribed interests on a recommendation of the Joint Select Committee on the Corporations Legislation which was adopted by Parliament when the Corporations Act 1989 was enacted.

* In accepting this and other recommendations, the Government indicated that it would be considering the making of regulations to provide exemptions from the fundraising provisions where the interests of investors are adequately protected. Private business trading trusts are such an instance.
* The Government is presently considering regulations to address this difficulty.

* Interests in private trusts could be declared to be exempt rights and interests by a regulation pursuant to the definition of `prescribed interest' in s.9 of the Corporations Law. Accordingly, interests in such trusts would not be prescribed interests and thus none of the provisions of Pt. 7.12 of the Law concerning prospectuses and approved deeds would have any application to such trusts.
Translation from `Act' to `Law' have not been effected.
* We cannot comment on this matter as the Institute does not indicate any cases where it claims the translations have not been effected.
Attorney-General's
Department
December 1990
CORPORATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990
RESPONSE TO THE SUBMISSION TO THE SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS BY PERPETUAL TRUSTEES W.A. LTD

Note: In the letter dated 12 December 1990 from Perpetual Trustees W.A. Ltd to Senator Ian Campbell, most of the references to `the Corporations Law' should be references to `the Corporations Act', ie. the Corporations Act 1989 as proposed to be amended by the Corporations Legislation Amendment Act 1990. In reproducing below the headings used in that letter, the necessary corrections have been made.
Section 6-Insertion of new Parts 1-13 in Chapter 1
* The comment on numbering is misconceived.
- It overlooks the headings and sections 1 and 2 of the Corporations Law that are inserted on pages 33-34 of the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 (`the Bill').
Section 6-Insertion of new section 6 (2) in the Corporations Act
* This comment appears to overlook subsections 6 (3), (4) and (5).

- Those sub-sections prevent the regulations (including the regulations as applied by the laws of another jurisdiction) from affecting the rights of any person (other than the Commonwealth, a State, the Capital Territory or an authority of the Commonwealth or of a State or the Capital Territory), being rights existing at the day of notification of the regulations, from being affected in a manner prejudicial to that person. The subsections also prevent the regulations from imposing liabilities on such a person in respect of anything done or omitted to be done before the day of notification.
Section 6-Insertion of new section 13 in the Corporations Act
* This comment is misconceived.

- Subsections 13 (2) and (3) are merely definitional provisions for the purposes stated in subsection 13 (1)-ie. for the purposes of a Commonwealth Act, a law of the ACT, or an instrument made under such an Act or law. For example, if some Commonwealth Act refers to `the Corporations Law of Victoria', subsection 13 (2) provides the meaning of that expression. Any questions about constitutional validity would relate to that other Act, not to subsection 13 (2) or (3).
Section 6-Insertion of section 14 in the Corporations Act
* This comment is misconceived.
- It appears to be based on a misreading of section 14 and to show a failure to understand the basic legislative scheme.

- Sub-section 14 (1) is not a provision `deeming there to be a ``single national Corporations Law''. It states the object of section 14-ie. to help ensure that the ACT Corporations Law operates as if, together with the Corporations Laws of the other jurisdictions, it constituted a single national Corporations Law. Section 14 is one of a number of Commonwealth, State and Northern Territory provisions designed to achieve that object. In my opinion, it is clear that none of those provisions exceeds the relevant constitutional powers.

* As to the comment on sub-section 14 (2), it is true that the definition of `instrument' does not expressly include an instrument made under a law of a State or Territory other than the ACT. However, such an instrument would be included under paragraph (h) of the definition.
Section 6-Insertion of new sections 18 and 20 in the Corporations Act
* The comment expressing doubt as to the Commonwealth's constitutional power in this respect is unfounded.
- As to the Crown in right of the Capital Territory and Norfolk Island, section 122 of the Constitution clearly provides a constitutional basis.
- As to the Crown in right of the Commonwealth, sections 18 and 20 will be within the various powers supporting the activities of the Commonwealth to which the various Corporations Laws will apply.

* An alternative approach to sections 18 and 20 is to regard them as waivers of relevant Commonwealth constitutional immunities from State law, and as removing any relevant statutory impediments, so as to allow the Corporations Laws of the States and Northern Territory to operate of their own force in relation to the Crown in right of the Commonwealth, the ACT and Norfolk Island. That approach does not raise any constitutional problems.
Section 6-Insertion of new section 30 in the Corporations Act

* If the comment is intended to suggest that the delegation of legislative authority is so broad as to be invalid, then it is clearly misconceived. Similar provisions already exist in the Securities Industry Codes and the Futures Industry Codes (subsections 150 (2) and 165 (4) respectively).
* The regulations would, of course, be subject to scrutiny and disallowance by each House of the Parliament (s.48 of the Acts Interpretation Act).
Section 6-Insertion of new section 37 in the Corporations Act
* See the remarks above concerning section 14.
Section 6-Insertion of new section 42 in the Corporations Act
* The comment that the deeming provisions are `fraught with difficulty' is unfounded.

* The comment does not specify any suggested difficulties. It is clear, for example, that subsection 42 (1) enables the arrest provisions in s.8a of the Crimes Act 1914 (Commonwealth) to be used in the ACT in respect of a person who has allegedly committed an offence against the Corporations Law of a State.
Section 6-Insertion of new section 45 in the Corporations Act
* The suggestion in the comment is unfounded.

- Paragraph 45 (1) (b) should not give rise to any difficulties. It would apply, for example, where an ACT law provides that a person is disqualified from holding some ACT office if the person has committed an offence against the law of a State. Because of paragraph 45 (1) (b), a breach of the Corporations Law of a State would not result in disqualification under the ACT provision.
Section 6-Insertion of new section 52 in the Corporations Act
* The comment is misconceived.

- Subsections 52 (1), (2) and (3) would be read down within the limits of Commonwealth constitutional power (see section 15a of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901). The provisions would validly apply in relation to appeals in matters within federal jurisdiction (see sections 75-77 of the Constitution) or within ordinary or cross-vested Territory jurisdiction.
Section 6-Insertion of new section 64 in the Corporations Act
* The comment is unfounded-see the remarks above concerning section 52.
Section 11-Insertion of new section 1d in the Australian Securities Commission Act 1989
* The comment is misconceived-see the remarks above concerning section 14 in the Corporations Act.
Schedule 1-Amendments to Chapter 1 of the Corporations Law
Heading to Chapter 1
* This comment overlooks the heading inserted on page 33 of the Bill.
New section 58
* The word `to' where it last appears in the second line of subsection 58 (2) is correct: the substitution of `in', as suggested in the comment, would not make sense.

* The comment that there appear to be a number of typographical errors does not specify what they are, and merely speculates that they may have substantive effect. If any do appear, they can be corrected in due course.
New subsection 66a (4)

* The reason is that friendly societies are not expressly exempted from the definition of `corporation' in section 5 of the WA Companies Code. As to any exemptions under other WA laws, see section 6 of the model State Corporations Bill 1990.
New subsection 69a

* The reason for omitting the bodies in question is that they are not expressed to be exempt under section 552 of the WA Companies Code. As to any exemptions under other WA laws, see section 6 of the model State Corporations Bill 1990.
New section 76
* The comment is misconceived.
- Section 76 serves obvious definitional purposes concerning expressions referring to corporations incorporated `in' a jurisdiction or in Australia.
New section 100a

* The comment is not understood. Section 100a must necessarily be effective to prevent the operation of any provision of a specified kind if that provision would have operated in the absence of s.100a.
New subsection 105 (3)
* The comment is obscure.
- I see no difficulty in applying subsection 105 (3), including cases where subsection 58b (2) applies (cf. subsection 36 (2) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901).
New section 109j
* The comment is misconceived if it is intended to suggest that extrinsic material derived from State sources could not be used in appropriate cases.

- That suggestion would overlook the fact that subsection 109j (1) refers to `any material not forming part of this Law' and that subsection 109j (3) provides that the material that may be considered under subsection (2) is not limited to the materials (Commonwealth and international) of the kinds listed in subparagraphs (a) to (h).
(DENNIS ROSE)
Chief General Counsel

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is discussing the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill 1990. I wish to place it on the record immediately that the Australian Democrats support the passage of this Bill. The Bill was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, as stated previously, on Tuesday, 11 December, and the Committee meeting took place last night. It was a public hearing held in Parliament House, Canberra. Evidence was given by Mr Hartnell, the Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission (ASC); Professor Austin, Chairman, Companies Committee, Law Council of Australia; Ms Schiftan, QC, Mr Gardini and Mr O'Bryan from the Business Council of Australia; and Mr Greenwood from the Law Institute of Victoria. In addition, the Committee received written submissions from a number of organisations: the Victorian Employers Federation, the Business Council of Australia, the Australian Bankers Association, Diskrom Australia, Computer Services of Australia and Coles Myer Ltd.

SPEECH.PARA: The main issues discussed at the Committee hearing included the Australian company number, inadvertent breaches of the law-especially in the early days of its operations, the commencement date, a national business names register, difficulties in implementing a national regulatory scheme which did not include Western Australia, parliamentary accountability, the relationship of the Commonwealth and the Australian Capital Territory with regard to the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities, and the operation of the company law in the ACT.

While it was agreed that some difficulties might indeed arise in the early days of the new legislative regime, all present at the hearing were generally in favour of the proposed commencement date of 1 January. Certainly, the Australian Democrats believe that it is imperative that this be so. In particular, we would join those who rejected at the Committee hearing the submission by the Law Institute of Victoria that the legislation should be deferred until mirror legislation has been passed by all States.

Bearing in mind the situation in Western Australia, clearly that would have deferred the implementation of this important piece of legislation almost indefinitely. It is understood the companies operating in Western Australia will suffer from these arrangements, as will the Western Australian business community as a whole. It is to be hoped that the Opposition in the Legislative Council, the upper House, in Western Australia can be moved to change its stance on this issue. I trust that the bodies concerned, which stated at the Committee meeting that at least privately they have been pressing the Opposition parties in Western Australia to do so, will be given a commonsense hearing by those parties.

At the Committee hearing certain technical matters were discussed, as were the difficulties that were expected with the Australian company number and the prospectuses. In the latter case, the discussion focused on the liability of a person that is named in a prospectus straddling the two periods of corporate legislation.

Mr Hartnell said that the obligations of people named in a prospectus would be much more onerous after the introduction of this legislation and agreed that the new corporate regime would indeed set a much higher standard of disclosure. In answer to concerns expressed on that point, the responsible Minister stressed that the six-month period of grace that would operate immediately following the commencement of the new legislation would give Mr Hartnell as Chairman of the ASC the opportunity to use his discretion positively. Mr Hartnell said that he would look over the administrative arrangements which had been put in place and attempt to clarify any point about which there was confusion. In view of these concerns I am pleased that the Minister and Mr Hartnell accepted the principle that close monitoring of the legislation is necessary. This is a task that the new standing committee to be established under this legislation will undertake on behalf of the Parliament and it will report to Parliament at regular intervals. It is clear that such a complex and far-reaching piece of legislation will require some finetuning as time goes by.

In this context it is important to note that the two amendments moved by Senator Kemp, which would have reduced the discretion of the ASC, were lost. The Opposition is to be commended for not persisting with these amendments because the effective implementation of the Bill depends on some flexibility in the system.

In conclusion, I believe this is a significant development in company law in Australia. It introduces a period for the Australian business community when the country is treated as one nation rather than a conglomeration of States with differing regulations and resultant higher costs for the business community. The Australian Democrats support the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raised the question about the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) the other night. Paragraph 16 does not deal with the matters contained in the Attorney-General's letter to the Federal Attorney-General (Mr Duffy), nor does it deal with the role of the ACT Attorney attending ministerial council meetings. If not today, I hope that the Federal Attorney-General will reply in more detail to that letter and not just regard this as the end of the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not propose to speak but I will be brief because I know Senator Campbell--
—You say that every time you stand up.

—The advantage of being in the chamber is that, unlike those rigidly locked-in senators who have a fixed position before they hear a debate, I always have had an open mind. As the debate goes on I am interested to hear the different points of view and they tend, from time to time, to persuade me to one position or another.
—Some people would not believe you, but I do.
—I get swept up in the moment as I hear contributions made by Australian Democrats and by other honourable senators.

SPEECH.PARA: I will pick up a point made by Senator Hill in his contribution to the debate. He talked about a national scheme. That is the proper description-it is a national scheme; it is not a Federal scheme. In the past we had a Federal scheme. Senator Tate always took exception to that. He was always terribly offended when he read in the newspapers that the Council of Ministers was proposing a piece of legislation to amend the Act and that it was a fait accompli. I have said before that I well remember him, as Chairman of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, standing up very indignantly one day and moving a reference to that Committee because he was not satisfied that the State Attorneys-General and the Federal Attorney-General could meet to resolve the proposing of an amendment which in many ways was imposed on the Federal Parliament and about which we could do little other than agree because of the cooperative system. The truth of the matter is that it had an intrinsic virtue. That was not enough; we had to have a centralised national scheme.

I will touch on some of the logical arguments put in favour of that, but I suspect it is because the Australian Labor Party believes, and has an obsession, that all wisdom, knowledge and divine inspiration comes from Canberra. It believes that the poor, mendicant States do not have the intellectual capacity, rigour or responsibility to deal with matters such as corporate powers.

This Bill-it has something like 300 pages; I do not know how many clauses-has been foisted upon us. In the normal course of events it will come into effect on 1 January 1991. Western Australia led the way on the cooperative Federal scheme, which has worked thus far. A former Liberal Government Attorney-General, Ian Medcalf, was instrumental in stitching together a cooperative scheme which, in my view, was a model for other legislation and for other powers where there was a need for a contribution to be made by each State and Territory and the Commonwealth.

It is fair to say that this body was not sufficiently funded. We have seen from recent revelations-and I suspect from future prosecutions-that there was not sufficient diligence or dedication in terms of pursuing breaches of company law. Those breaches are no more, and no less, serious than breaches of common law or criminal law. To that extent, and because of the events of recent years, I am sure that we will see greater endeavours in that respect.

The difficulty for Western Australia and for the Western Australian Parliament is that they believe in a cooperative Federal scheme. However, the reality is that a cooperative Federal scheme can exist only if all the States are players. Western Australia now finds itself the only player on the field, the rest of the players having departed. Inevitably there will have to be a compromise in respect of the Western Australian position. If there is no such compromise by the Federal Government, that will have enormous implications and dislocations for corporations which do business in Western Australia. It is inevitable that a meeting of minds will have to take place further down the track in that respect.

The great sadness for me is that I look at States such as New South Wales, which were opposed to the scheme originally and which went to the High Court to demonstrate that the Commonwealth did not have the power, and I see that since they have been given a bag of money by the Federal Government and a head office in their own States their altruism and their belief in the devolution of power and responsibility in a federal system has flown out the window as the money has flown in.

Of course, Western Australia is now in the position where it cannot be party to a system when the rest of the players have departed from the field. It is not simply that Western Australia has been bloody-minded about this; it is simply that it has stuck rigidly to a philosophic belief that power is best exercised by those closest to the people who are most directly affected by it-in other words, a simple process of devolution of power and responsibility.

However, that is clearly not going to be the case now. I very much hope for corporate Australia that there is a sensible and satisfactory resolution as quickly as possible. Once the other States took the money and ran, withdrew from their High Court challenges and did their grubby deals with the Federal Government because dollars and cents were more important that the proper exercise of power at the appropriate places, the cooperative federalist system could no longer prevail.

I conclude by saying that this legislation is going to be a classic example of an Act that will for the next 12 months to two years require continual amending. I suspect that major parts of it will be rewritten because the Government, in its headlong rush to get this legislation passed by 1 January, has not allowed for proper parliamentary scrutiny, public scrutiny, corporate scrutiny or scrutiny by the various States which are required to be parties to it.

I only regret that we find ourselves now in this chamber with a guillotine hanging over our heads, being unable to debate the Bill clause by clause; unable to prosecute a proper, reasonable debate on this issue; unable to have the Minister go through the various clauses; and unable to know at the end of the day that we have satisfactorily discharged our responsibility as senators in the second chamber of the Parliament, ensuring that the headlong rush by the House of Representatives, which is now simply an extension of the Executive, in some way has a further check and balance on it.

Because this Government crudely and bluntly rammed through the guillotine this morning, which prevents the proper processes of a parliamentary system, this debate has been sufficiently curtailed as to deny us all a proper forum for expressing our views and for pressing the legislation to determine whether or not it requires proper amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Crichton-Browne has put the case quite well. It is not only the guillotining of the debate on this matter that has made it impossible for the chamber to give proper scrutiny to this complex package of legislation-a guillotine that was enforced upon this chamber by the Australian Democrats-it is indeed the whole way that this legislative package has arrived in the Parliament of Australia and the parliaments of the various States around Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: In the heads of agreement document that was signed in Alice Springs in June, the Federal Government and the States agreed on a legislative program to prepare the legislation and have it in the parliaments in September of this year, which would have provided many months for this Parliament, for senators, for members of the House of Representatives and for parliamentarians around Australia to have considered the quite broadly reaching consequences of this legislative package. Indeed, as I said to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs last night, had that legislative program been abided by, perhaps the situation in Western Australia would not be as it is today.

I put it to the Committee, as I said before: the situation in Western Australia cannot be blamed upon the legislative councillors in Western Australia because clearly the Legislative Council is one of the few chambers around the whole of this nation which has actually done its job. Opposition members have been prepared to say to the Federal Government and to the corrupt Government in Western Australia that they are not prepared to get a package of legislation like that, to look at it and to pass it through without proper scrutiny. They have told the doctrinaire centralists of the Australian Labor Party that they can take their legislation and shove it. That is what they should have done.

That has created problems, but they are problems that have been created by this Federal Government and by this Attorney-General (Mr Duffy), who plucked a starting date out of the air after the High Court case earlier this year, saying, `We will have it up and running by 1 January'. He had no idea then of what he was doing. He has created a political imperative which he has been unable to meet logistically.

If one saw the tired figure of the Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission, Tony Hartnell, last night having to wade through the enormous logistic problems, which I have gone through on a number of occasions in this chamber before, to try to get his organisation up and running by 1 January, one would really wonder at the logic, the principle and, indeed, the sensibility of trying to have this whole scheme up and running by 1 January.

A number of the people who made submissions to the Senate Standing Committee last night went through some detailed, complicated, practical matters. Even though they said that they did not support the idea of delaying the setting up of the Australian Securities Commission, they said quite clearly that there were grounds to do so.

The position of the Western Australian business community has been clearly made known today in a letter which was only recently provided to Michael Duffy, the Attorney-General. The head of the Western Australian Opposition Group, Laurie Shervington, representing the Law Society of Western Australia, the Institute of Chartered Accountants, the Australian Stock Exchange in Perth, the Confederation of Western Australian Industry, the Western Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, the Chamber of Mines of Western Australia, the International Association of Financial Planning and the trustee companies of Australia, have, in a very clearly, concisely worded letter, said that it is just impossible and outrageous to try to set up the Australian Securities Commission by 1 January. There are just too many logistic problems, not to mention the problems caused by the lack of mirror legislation in Western Australia.

Last night the Committee received, as Senator Spindler and Senator Hill have said previously, some very detailed submissions from a number of business groups, including one from the Business Council of Australia and the Confederation of Australian Industry, which was sent to me by Michael O'Connor, a former head of the Corporate Affairs Office in Perth, now the Assistant General Manager, Corporate Services, for Perpetual Trustees (WA) Ltd, and others from the Law Institute of Victoria and the Law Council of Australia.

I do give credit to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate), the Attorney-General and the officers responsible for preparing what are fairly detailed responses to some of the concerns, as was promised last night at the Senate Standing Committee, but, as Senator Hill, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, said here today, it is a bit hard for senators to go through those responses in much detail when they were delivered to our offices only a few minutes ago.

Some of the responses do point out the concerns raised by industry and professions last night. I will quote one as an example because, as I said, I have not had time to go through in detail the responses and indeed the submissions because time has been just too short. I think we all agree on that. On page three of the response prepared by Mr Dennis Rose, the Chief General Counsel in the Attorney-General's Department, he refers under section 6 to some constitutional problems that were raised by Mr Michael O'Connor from Perpetual Trustees and says at the end of it:
In my opinion, it is clear that none of those provisions exceeds the relevant constitutional powers.

That is his opinion. The fact of the matter is that the whole constitutional underpinning of this legislative package has raised doubts in many people's minds. Many of the procedures that are used are doubtful. The complexity of this legislation has basically not allowed time for people even of the eminence and with the knowledge of this issue of Professor Bob Austin, who was before the Committee, to come to grips with in such a short time. It is just impossible for anyone to contemplate the problems that can arise by legislating in this way. I think that is the only real point that we can make here today in this debate, given the constraints that we have upon us.

Professor Austin told me last night after the meeting of the Senate Standing Committee that the response he had received to his submission still left many doubts in his mind. I think all of us would agree that Professor Austin is one of the most well-versed people outside the various offices of Solicitors-General and Attorneys-General in Australia in relation to this legislative package.

The other matters that were raised of specific detail last night concerned the Australian company number (ACN). I think, for the third or fourth time, my doubts and fears about the way this system is going to work failed to be allayed. The concerns of Coles Myer Ltd as to whether this company number will have to appear on the receipts in their checkouts was not answered last night. I suppose the Minister can respond to that today. The concerns about the abbreviations of the Australian company number as they appear on company seals was discussed last night and has been discussed at length.

The matter of the Australian company number and the effect of the moratorium on civil action that may be taken in relation to companies that do not have the ACN on their business documents are all matters that still, and quite rightly so, concern the vast array of corporate Australia, the some 800,000 companies out there which are totally confused about this whole package. I think the point that the Senate and this Government must understand is that to legislate in such an important area for Australia in this way is unacceptable and should never happen again. Senator Crichton-Browne made the point that we are likely to be back here in the Commonwealth Parliament making amendments to this package for the next couple of years. I think, with my only brief consideration of these Bills over the last few minutes, that is quite evident.

The other important matters that were raised last night were, of course, the transitional period and problems perceived with that. I think the concerns of both the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Business Council of Australia, which were referred to by Senator Spindler, were not allayed last night. There are problems with prospectuses, rights issues, the liabilities of directors of those companies and the exemptions for disclosures. If I remember correctly, Mr Hartnell said that those disclosure problems will not affect any companies that he is aware of. The business representatives tended to say to the Standing Committee that there may be many companies, rights issues and prospectuses affected by those transitional provisions. These are all matters which have not been dealt with and which cannot be dealt with properly because of the legislative program this Government has imposed upon us.

The last issue I raise is in relation to the Western Australian position and the way this issue is being handled politically by the Government. I think Senator Crichton-Browne referred to it. The Western Australian Opposition has, for the last two or three years, been at the forefront of trying to cut down on corporate crime, to uncover corruption and to force a royal commission. It has been at the forefront of exposing the corrupt dealings of Western Australian Government Ministers, former Premiers and the involvement of government in business. The Western Australian Opposition has been at the forefront of the fight against corporate crime and the involvement of corporate criminals, corrupt government Ministers and government officials. These matters have all been well and truly exposed in the newspapers. It is the Western Australian Government which has been at the forefront of corporate crime and its own involvement in corporate crime.

For this Government to take the side of the Government of Carmen Lawrence and the Attorney-General, Joe Berinson, who himself is implicated in some of the WA Inc. dealings, is quite laughable to me. The Western Australian Government's new-found will to clean up corporate affairs in Western Australia is an absolute joke. It is quite outrageous to think that we have the Western Australian Government accusing the Opposition members of the Legislative Council of protecting corporate criminals and trying to make a safe haven for corporate criminals, because most of the corporate criminals in Western Australia are to be found in the Cabinet of the Western Australian Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. I have let Senator Crichton-Browne and Senator Campbell make some general statements about the Western Australian Government. Senator Campbell is probably getting pretty close to being guilty of using offensive words in relation to Joe Berinson. Now he has reached the stage of pointing to the Cabinet as being guilty of criminal activities, I think that is close enough to being able to identify the persons to require a withdrawal.
—On the same point of order, I made no reference to anybody in Western Australia, in the Government or outside the Government.
—Generally.
—I did not mention the Government; I did not talk about the Government's role. That is a debate for another day. I was directing myself only to the report.
—Senator Campbell, I would ask you to withdraw those remarks about the Cabinet.

—I am prepared to withdraw the remark about the Cabinet. The point I was closing on was, indeed, how ludicrous and outrageous it was for the Carmen Lawrence Western Australian Government to be painting the legislative councillors in Western Australia as people who are seeking a system that will allow a safe haven for corporate crime.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by saying that this Government has a lot to answer for in the way that it has handled this legislative package. I repeat my assertion that the Federal Government should take most of the blame for the impasse in Western Australia. I call on this Government, as I have called on the Minister, to seek a resolution, a compromise, and be conciliatory rather than use ostracism and political point scoring on this issue to the detriment of business across Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those senators who have contributed to the debate this afternoon, which concludes a somewhat truncated process of parliamentary consideration of this important Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill. For example, I believe the Senate was greatly aided by the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs under the very able and sometimes somewhat eccentric chairmanship of Senator Barney Cooney, whose style permitted a great variety of views to be expressed. As the Minister at the table, I found that extremely helpful and have undertaken, as a result of some very weighty submissions put forward, to take into account certain matters, particularly in the drawing up of regulations, including section 1034.

SPEECH.PARA: In general, I believe that we have reached a stage where, having completed this parliamentary process, this chamber will have done what it set out to do several years ago in responding to a Senate committee report, where in Australia we had a situation where companies and securities legislation was devised, composed and drafted by a committee of Ministers and then put into the various parliaments around Australia for automatic passage. There was no sense of final political responsibility in any one chamber of any one parliament throughout this Federation for the laws which were controlling and purporting to regulate companies and securities throughout this great Commonwealth. We now have a situation where this chamber pre-eminently, together with the House of Representatives-certainly this Parliament-will have to take true political responsibility for the formulation and moulding of those laws which are so essential to ensure that we are properly served by an adequate company and securities legislation package.

Of course, that will be wedded to an Australian Securities Commission (ASC) which will have the resources and the responsibility to properly undergird the regulation of companies and securities throughout Australia. It will have a very important role in restoring the confidence of domestic and overseas investors, who must look askance at Australia as the corporate activity-this was alluded to by Senator Campbell-now leads to various charges being laid against those who played a most prominent role in the corporate life of Australia during the 1980s.

I believe it is because of that general impression, both within the Australian community and overseas, of this area of our commercial life that there is an absolutely imperative need for the earliest possible putting into place of this legislation and the accompanying administrative structures. But I believe it would be completely wrong if those structures bore any of the centralist tendencies which were pictured as being their necessary character by Senator Campbell and Senator Crichton-Browne.

For that reason, it is absolutely essential that we get away from the stereotypes which have sometimes characterised the debate. It became evident last night that, for example, on the part of Mr Tony Hartnell of the Australian Securities Commission-I think this was acknowledged by Senator Campbell-there was evident goodwill towards the regional areas of Australia. The various Attorneys-General at the Alice Springs meeting, and the heads of agreement which flowed from that meeting, made it absolutely clear that it would be intolerable if the regional areas of Australia were left in a situation where the levels of service available to the business communities in those districts and important provincial and non-eastern seaboard areas of Australia were neglected and not provided for adequately.

I believe that those heads of agreement, particularly the Western Australian clauses which found their way into it, through the insistence of Attorney-General Joe Berinson but with a background of pressure from the Western Australian opposition group and no doubt the political pressure that was also apparent from the upper House in Western Australia, will lead to a situation where the regional needs of the business communities of Australia will be very adequately and better served by the ASC-if it does what it has promised to do.

One of the great unfortunate factors in the chronological situation we have got into, with so little time left before 1 January, is that, if there is not the passage of this legislation in Western Australia, there will not be the early establishment of the Office of Regional Commissioner and the early operation of the Regional Liaison Committee whose role it would be to sit down with Mr Hartnell and other officers of the Australian Securities Commission to compose those performance indicators which would be the basis of a true, practical assessment and effective measurement of whether the levels of service promised to the regions were being delivered.

For that reason alone, I think the business community of Western Australia would be well served if the Legislative Council were to pass this legislation, reluctantly, and castigating, as it would and must, not only the Federal Government but necessarily all other governments of Australia because all other jurisdictions have participated in coming to the conclusion that this Australia-wide package is essential to restore integrity and efficiency to companies and securities regulation throughout Australia. It would be wrong to try simply to caricature people as centralist socialists in this matter because, quite clearly, with Mr Greiner and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Marshall Perron, whom I know and respect-he was recently re-elected to that high office and I greatly respect the contribution he makes to rational debate, for example, on firearms control in this country-it is a question of many political minds of different persuasions coming to the common conclusion that the marketplace in Australia must be regulated by laws made by a parliament which takes full responsibility for their creation and amendment and which is responsible to the Australia-wide electorate, because we are talking about an Australia-wide marketplace.

I am beginning to reiterate many points which I made both at the conclusion of the second reading debate and extensively last night in the very valuable session held under the auspices of Senator Barney Cooney. In conclusion, I pay tribute to those officers who have worked so diligently and hard, not only in the last 12 hours or so to provide the responses which that Committee required to certain complex documents which were forwarded by the Law Council of Australia, the Law Institute of Victoria and Perpetual Trustees Western Australia Ltd, Mr Bernard Collaery and others, but also over the last several weeks in briefing me and no doubt the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) and many others. Mr David Edwards, Mr Brian O'Callaghan, Mr Jim Murphy and other members of the working group have performed in a way which shows the excellence of the quality and dedication of some of the public servants who are available to any Australian government of any political persuasion.

I think we ought to record our indebtedness to those who have been prepared to put in such a major effort, under huge political constraints, and have served the elected representative of the people-by which I mean not only the Government but also this chamber-so well in providing the material that was sought and giving advice. I wish this Bill a final passage through this Parliament. I believe that in years to come, some with misgivings and some with more enthusiasm than others will look upon this particular vote as marking a new era in the regulation of corporations and securities in Australia. I commend the third reading of the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I disagree with one thing that Senator Tate said in particular-and this has to be on the record-that is, there is nothing sterile about the fact that under the old cooperative system the legislation had to be mirrored in each parliament. That does not mean that there was no source of responsibility, as Senator Tate would have us believe. It means that the responsibility was shared equally and carried by each Minister and each parliament. We now have a new system where the numbers are in the pocket of the Attorney-General. Senator Tate referred to the heavy responsibilities that this chamber will have, together with the House of Representatives. What he did not say was that the House of Representatives is now but a mere weak, limp extension of the Executive. The House of Representatives never, but never, disagrees with the Executive, because it is the Executive, by the very nature of the Caucus system of the Australian Labor Party and the parliamentary system we have.

SPEECH.PARA: So we put the votes in the pocket of the Attorney-General and the Government controls the decision-making. It is this Parliament that will dictate the processes of reform, the processes of legislation and the direction that the Act will take in future. I would not want it thought that there was some meandering, pointless process that was undertaken previously simply because each State and Territory and Federal Attorney-General had a very special and proper responsibility unto his own constituency and parliament-that in some way it was a headless system. Quite the contrary: it was a classic example of a cooperative system that could operate constructively and properly with an equal and fair distribution of power and responsibility. This will not be the case under the new system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to conclude with a few points that I forgot to mention in my first contribution. I will not say anything politically upsetting to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) so that we do not delay matters. There were only two matters that have not been put on the record in this chamber. One is the performance indicators issue, which the Minister referred to a couple of times. He said that the Alice Springs heads of agreement referred to performance indicators and the regional liaison committees, which I have already publicly supported.

SPEECH.PARA: Had we been able to develop performance indicators-and clearly, that would have been possible to do; the Western Australian opposition group has already come up with a set of performance indicators on the key issue of the delegated powers it wanted for the regional commissioners-and had there been some discussion about that many months earlier, then the Western Australian business community and, indeed, the members of the Liberal and National parties in the Legislative Council would not have that problem.

The other problem we have, which I failed to mention in my initial contribution to this committee stage debate, concerned the regulations and the whole issue of business having to comply with a law which it does not understand and regulations which we know the Government is working very hard to have printed and published before Christmas Day. I cannot see many corporate lawyers sitting down over the Christmas-New Year period to read the regulations and try to come to grips with them.

Those are the two matters. I do not believe they deserve a specific response. Again, they reinforce my point that, had things been done in a more timely manner, perhaps the confrontation and confusion that we are visited with at the moment would not have been necessary.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendments; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Tate) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 14 November, on motion by Senator Tate:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are now debating the Commonwealth Banks Restructuring Bill, a major Bill which deals with the merger of two of the biggest banks in Australia. It sets the framework in place for the sale of the State Bank of Victoria to the Commonwealth Bank of Australia at a cost of $1.6 billion, which is actually $2 billion when one takes into account the related tax measures. In meeting this primary goal, the legislation converts into public companies the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and the Commonwealth Development Bank of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill essentially implements the deal worked out between the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Premier of Victoria, Mrs Kirner, back in August of this year. That deal involved a purchase bid of $1.6 billion by the Commonwealth Bank for the State Bank of Victoria; $170m to eliminate tax loss write-offs from Tricontinental, the failed merchant bank arm of the State Bank; a $243m reimbursement to Victoria for tax revenue which in future will go to the Commonwealth rather than to Victoria; the separation of the State Bank from Tricontinental; and the fact that Tricontinental assets, including tax losses, will not be used to reduce Commonwealth tax receipts. The Bill essentially implements the deal that was worked out.

It is clear that this Bill has everything to do with the Hawke-Keating Government bailing out the Cain-Kirner Government in Victoria and has nothing at all to do with what it should be rightly directed at, that is, privatisation. Indeed, the Treasurer got a good deal out of Mrs Kirner in one sense in that he bought her vote at the special Australian Labor Party conference on 24 September to implement the 30 per cent sale of the Commonwealth Bank and the deals that were worked out within the Labor Party on the privatisation of Australian Airlines Ltd and the part sale to private interests of Qantas Airways Ltd. But it was a vote that was bought by the Treasurer at very considerable cost so far as the Commonwealth is concerned.

Not only was the deal done in an attempt to save the doomed but unsavable Labor Government in Victoria; it was also done in an attempt to retain any professional credibility that the Treasurer may still have had. Of course, it is now quite clear to all Australians that this architect of our deliberately engineered recession has not one shred of credibility left.

I turn now to the reason why the deal was done in the way that it was, in other words, to legislate to sell the State Bank of Victoria to the Commonwealth Bank rather than saving the State Bank of Victoria by direct intervention from the Budget-and honourable senators should remember that this deal was done two days after the Federal Budget was brought down on 22 August. The politics of it, so far as Mr Keating's credibility are concerned, are very well set out in the debate on the Bill that took place in the other chamber on 14 November. A member of the Government, Mr John Scott, the honourable member for Hindmarsh, said:

The sell-out of the Commonwealth Bank will stand as one of the greatest betrayals of the Australian Labor Party. Those who allowed this to happen cry crocodile tears and say that they did it to save the Government and the people of Victoria. The false tears and argument add insult to this great injury. The need for action to salvage the State Bank of Victoria was never an issue. The funds could and should have been found from within the Commonwealth Bank and/or from the Budget.

The reason the Budget was never contemplated as a vehicle by the Treasurer was that he has as his icon a thing called the public sector borrowing requirement. He was producing a Budget with a surplus of $8 billion. He knew that to handle the bail-out of the Kirner Government in Victoria through budgetary measures would have blown his $8 billion surplus, which is being blown day by day anyway-it is now down probably to $5 billion. That surplus made the Treasurer look good. Again, as his colleague the honourable member for Hindmarsh, Mr Scott, said in the other place:
. . . history will judge the Hawke-Keating Government on the sell-out of the Commonwealth Bank . . .

The coalition, let me hasten to add, does not support Mr Scott's view. We say that the Commonwealth Banks Restructuring Bill does not go far enough and that what we should be seeing here is a 100 per cent privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank because that is the only way that that bank is going to be made increasingly competitive and able to raise the necessary funds for its growth and development on behalf of all Australians in the period ahead. In other words, it ought to be placed on the same footing as any of the other major privately owned banks.

At the outset, I want to deplore the lack of time given to debate this very important Bill in the House of Representatives. The Government's mismanagement of the parliamentary program is a recipe for bad legislation as it cuts time for consultation and debate. This Bill went through the House of Representatives in something like 40 minutes; it may have been a little longer but it was subject to the guillotine procedures-procedures which are again applying to the Bill here today.

The importance of the legislation is evident in the fact that the merged organisation will be the biggest bank in Australia. It will employ some 50,000 people. The State Bank of Victoria alone has over four million depositors. The merged organisation will have 26 per cent of deposits and 23 per cent of bank lending in Australia. It will also be the dominant operator of superannuation roll-over funds, with more than $2.5 billion of deferred retirement benefits under management and control over approximately $1 in every $7 in the superannuation business.

The mismanagement of this very important legislation has of course continued in the Senate. I will be proposing when we get to the committee stage certain amendments which were discussed by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Administration last Friday. That debate was supposed to take place only after the second reading of this Bill had taken place, and even that we could not get right. It is not surprising that the Government does not want a meaningful debate. The Bill relates to a merger of convenience which has torn the Labor Party asunder because of the divisions within it on the ideology of State ownership. Nothing could be more evident than that from the fact that members of the Government-and I think Senator Tate was one of them-voted against its own policy proposals here in the Senate in September.

Members of the Government in the Senate, including Ministers-and I think Senator Tate was one of them-voted against a motion put by the coalition supporting the selling of the shares in the Commonwealth Bank, Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines Ltd. The failure to support that motion directly, of course, contradicts the substance of the Bill which is before us today. But the confusion is even deeper than that. One has only to look at the Caucus resolution of the Federal parliamentary Labor Party of 28 August, which imposed 17 of the most draconian restrictions surrounding the sale even of this 30 per cent of the Commonwealth Bank. It was the only way that the leadership of the Party could get the agreement of Caucus to even this small step. That again is indicative of the very deep divisions that this Bill has caused within the Labor Party and within the Government. Hence, it is a clear reason for the Government not wanting to see this Bill debated at any considerable length. But the confusion, I think, is even deeper than that--

TALK.START.PARA: —How much of it would you sell-100 per cent?

—Yes, it is official policy, as I assumed Senator Tate would have known. Why on earth would one not sell 100 per cent? Why, if one was really serious about assisting the Commonwealth Bank, would one sell 30 per cent of it with no change in the operation of the bank and no considerably greater access to the finance and the necessary inputs and so on that it needs if it is going to be a great competitor bank with the other major banks in Australia? The Government is in a halfway house. It has fallen between two stools. It has achieved nothing other than to try to sort out a squalid political deal to save the Kirner Government in Victoria, which, as I said, is an absolutely unsavable Government. That is what it is on about in this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The confusion is even deeper than that. Conflicting statements by the Treasurer and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) are further evidence of a party not knowing what it is doing. In 1985 both the Treasurer and the Prime Minister were out whipping up a scare campaign for all they were worth when it came to privatisation of any sort. The Treasurer said in May of that year:
No matter where one looks, whether it be at TAA or other authorities, there is no case for the Opposition's-
that is, the Liberal and National parties-
. . . argument in economics, except simply to indulge ideologically in a Thatcherite, vandalistic splurge to try and destroy these authorities.
Also in 1985 the Prime Minister said:
. . . privatisation would be an expensive and disastrous experiment.

The political nature of that opposition to what is the only rational and economically sound argument on the treatment of assets such as the Commonwealth Bank was highlighted by a letter from the Prime Minister to the Commonwealth Bank Officers Association just before the last election in March of this year. In that letter the Prime Minister said that the Labor Government was opposed to privatisation. It knew that it did not believe that. It made that statement, knowing that it was untrue, in a sordid, blatant attempt to buy votes at the election in March.

I would not object to the backflip made on Government policy if the Government itself had not gone out and blatantly misled the public about its intentions. If the Government had come to accept the coalition's policy in total rather than going halfway with a partial privatisation to satisfy purely political ends, and if the Government was now prepared to say it had adopted this new stance for the right economic reasons rather than to find some compromise which had to be jammed down the throats of the warring factions within the Labor Party, then this situation might look very different.

In stark contrast, the coalition has a policy position to which it is unwaveringly committed and has been for a considerable time. We find the Government's continued shifting of position dishonest and destabilising. It is nothing more than a blatant politicisation of an issue which should always have been won or lost on the real economic arguments involved.

The Bill before us today is typical of a Government only prepared to approach sensible policy options kicking and screaming. It is ironic in the extreme that the gross mismanagement of one Labor government has helped at least partially to rationalise the policies of another. The Bill before us shows that the Government was left with a mishmash of compromise and a half-baked privatisation. The coalition will attempt to limit the damage of compromise in amendments that I will move at the committee stage, which have already been circulated. Those amendments, in essence, involve deleting the section which seeks to retain 70 per cent of the bank in the hands of the Government in perpetuity, deleting the section which disallows foreigners from purchasing shares in the initial sale, and altering the section specifying the 5 per cent ownership limit and have the Commonwealth Bank instead subject to the same 10 per cent and 15 per cent limits applying to other banks under the Banks (Shareholdings) Act 1972. That Act allows unrestricted ownership of up to 10 per cent, between 10 and 15 per cent requires approval from the Treasurer that it not be contrary to the national interest, and ownership in excess of 15 per cent must be deemed in the national interest by the Treasurer to proceed.

These amendments address issues which the Labor Party was very deeply divided on. The other irony is that I am sure that there are members on the Government side-Senator Tate may well be one of them-who would totally support these amendments of the coalition but are unprepared to do so publicly because of the divisions on the issue within the Government. I will discuss those amendments further at the committee stage, given that the guillotine has restricted the length of this debate.

I would also like to raise a number of issues concerning the propriety of the way that this sale has been handled. As the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, has pointed out on a number of occasions, there seems little doubt that the tender process in this case was of a very questionable nature. Participants in the tender were given only four to five business days in which to finalise their bid, which is hardly enough time for due diligence. In fact, there is no time in a situation like that for adequate due diligence. The announcement of the successful bidder was also made only one day after the bids had closed and the successful tenderer was not the highest tenderer-Westpac was. Again, one day is hardly enough time for the alternative offers to be properly assessed or for the Government to make an informed and objective choice.

The Treasurer's hypocrisy is also exposed again, since he chose to reject the ANZ-National Mutual merger on the basis of a 15 per cent national market share but, under the terms of this Bill, the Commonwealth will end up with 25 per cent national share, and in Victoria its share of the market will be 33 per cent. The Treasurer certainly uses his discretion on these matters in very strange and inequitable ways.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is to help his mates.

—As my colleague Senator Kemp says, there is no doubt that the whole basis of this Bill is to help the Treasurer's mates and at the same time to attempt to retain some credibility on the part of the Treasurer. The irony of it and certainly the fact of it is that the Treasurer has no credibility left at all and there is no way that this action is going to save his mates in Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: As a Victorian, I take very great exception to what is happening under the Kirner Government in my State. That Government and its predecessor, the Cain Government, have bankrupted Victoria; not just for Victorians today but for future generations of Victorians. I invite those honourable senators who do not live in Victoria to visit my State to see the state of depression that the Cain-Kirner Government disaster has wrought.

TALK.START.PARA: —We know what it is like back home.

—Senator Campbell has a similar situation in Western Australia. It is clear that in this instance the Treasurer was happy to manipulate the situation in such a way as to place the burden of a Victorian problem onto depositors of the Commonwealth Bank and the Australian taxpayer in general. ``It seems that the Labor Government of South Australia was also involved in the whole fiasco.
