The South Australian Government Financing Authority invested $300m in the State Bank of Victoria late in 1989 when the State Bank of Victoria was experiencing financial difficulties. It was only after examination through Estimates committees of the State Parliament in Adelaide that an additional $100m deal was also revealed.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that the Government proposed in the Senate Standing Committee discussion of this Bill, that it will be making some technical amendments of its own. They relate to the superannuation conditions which will apply to transferred employees. Those amendments have now been circulated, but it is another example of the haste with which the Government is attempting to push through its legislative program, at risk of getting it wrong. The amendments that have now been moved at this very late stage are typical of the incompetence that this Government is bringing to the handling, programming, preparation and content of its legislative program.

My colleague in the House of Representatives Mr Warwick Smith said that he will be investigating the possibility of making the Commonwealth Development Bank a separate privately owned specialist small business private bank. That investigation will further advance the coalition's policy strength in this area.
I will save any future remarks for the committee stage of this Bill. In recent days the Government has had to accept the `R' word-recession. I wonder how long--

TALK.START.PARA: —Technical recession.

—Technical recession. As Senator Kemp says, the Government was forced to acknowledge last week a very deeply based and deeply rooted recession that has been with us for a year-as every other Australian but the Government seemed to know.

SPEECH.PARA: Having at last grappled with the facts and bitten the bullet on the `R' word-I make this very serious plea to Senator Tate, his colleagues and the less irrational and, to be generous to them, the more rational Ministers on the Government side-how long will it be before Senator Tate is able to get his Party to fully adopt the `P' word, that is, privatisation? That is the only way that the Commonwealth Bank and the other great institutions and government business enterprises of Australia are going to be allowed to develop and flourish in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to contribute to this debate because I, like the previous speaker, Senator Short, have been an advocate of privatisation for many years. I remember back in 1984-85, at a time when I was helping to develop privatisation policies for the Western Australian Liberal Party-I think it was leading up to the 1986 campaign-that the Australian Labor Party seized upon the Liberal Party's privatisation initiatives at that stage. If I remember correctly, it spent millions of dollars employing people such as Graham Kennedy in some quite amusing television advertisements to lampoon privatisation.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is quite right and proper for the Opposition to applaud the shift in the sea state of policy in the Labor Party towards privatisation, albeit an incomplete shift. It is a shift that is perhaps motivated by the serious economic circumstances of Australia and the problems that the Federal Government has with its own accounts.

The sale of 30 per cent of the Commonwealth Bank can clearly not be supported on any logical basis, except that someone has made a rough estimate-probably on the back of a packet of cigarette papers-that 30 per cent will roughly equal the $1.6 billion needed to bail out the State Bank of Victoria and the Labor Party cronies of this Federal Government down in Victoria.

The same can be said about the Government's announced policy decisions to sell 49 per cent of Qantas Airways Ltd and 100 per cent of both Australian Airlines Ltd and Aussat Pty Ltd. All these figures are not based on any philosophical or policy logic; they are purely based on what the Government could get through its Labor Party conference earlier this year.

The Liberal and National parties' commitment to privatisation is based on providing a better service for the customers, more competition between the entities and a more internationally competitive economy. It is also designed to maximise the once-off effect of the sales. None of those things are mutually exclusive to the other.

In any privatisation program there needs to be a balance of those objectives. Leaving aside the once-off effect of the sale and once-off effect to the Budget of the sale revenue, the key objectives are the effects that these sales would have on the Australian economy, the level of competition and the level of service that both the entity and the industry provide. Of course, the sale of 30 per cent of the Commonwealth Bank cannot do anything to enhance any one of those objectives.

The other thing that is of concern in relation to the privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank-this deal that was done in a few short days to solve a political situation in Victoria-is that the program for its privatisation has been rushed through, as we have seen with the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 which we were dealing with earlier.

In the United Kingdom, the Conservative Government has been privatising for most of the past 10 years. The United Kingdom has developed more expertise in privatisation programs than anywhere else in the world. Many countries, such as Australia, are following a long way behind.

It is fair to say that some of the privatisation programs earlier in the Thatcher Government's period did not meet some of the objectives that we have developed today. I still have severe doubts about the value of privatising an organisation such as Telecom Australia where one really creates a private monopoly instead of a public monopoly, because it does not achieve the competitive effects that really give service advantages to consumers of the service. However, the Thatcher Government, with a whole new professional industry set up around the privatisation programs-for example, the divisions in their merchant banks, the accounting and legal fraternity that have developed expertise in the privatisation area-learnt how to do it properly.

Many of us would have read in the Australian on Monday that the sale of the British Electricity Utilities has been a great success. It has oversubscribed. The amount of money the Government believes it will raise out of the float is much higher than expected and it has been a total success. The lesson to be learnt is that the program was put together over many years. The Government looked into how to do it; decided how it should be sold; looked at how the shares should be broken up; and set aside a certain amount of shares for the employees, a certain amount of shares for the consumer-share limits that were suited to the market.

After questioning the relevant Minister, Senator Button, in the Senate Standing Committee that dealt with this Bill last Friday, it would seem that the amount of thought that has gone into how to structure the share placements is not there and could not hope to match the sort of detail that the British Government and its advisers have gone into.

The limit on individual shareholdings in this package is five per cent. There are limits on the first-up sale of those shares, in that those people who buy them initially must be Australian. But there is nothing to stop, within the first five seconds of the float taking place, all of the 30 per cent capital in the Commonwealth Bank being transferred to foreign ownership. I am sure that is of concern to left wing members of the Labor Party and possibly even the Australian Democrats. I am not sure of the Democrats' position on that particular issue. I would say there are probably provisions whereby some friendly companies could get together and buy five per cent each and amalgamate further down the track, and that is something the Government may not have looked at.

The important point is that by selling only 30 per cent of the Commonwealth Bank and by not designing an effective privatisation program to meet the objectives, even the once-off effect to revenue, the once-off effect to the Budget, will not be maximised. There is no way the Government can get a maximised price per share if no effective control and no voting rights go with those shares. I think that is true in the case of Qantas, where the Government is selling 49 per cent. There is no way the Government is going to get the same price per share it would get if it were selling 51 per cent and providing some control for the people purchasing the shares, and this is a matter of concern. The trouble is that once the Government has sold 30 per cent of the Commonwealth Bank, it cannot sell it again. It is a once-off effect, a once-off policy error. The many millions of dollars this Government short-changes the Australian taxpayer by choosing to compromise and sell only 30 per cent will be lost for all time.

In summary, this privatisation is to be applauded in that it is moving in the right direction. The Government has moved a long way since 1984 when it was totally opposed to privatisation. I understand the political problems that the economically rational Ministers in the Cabinet have trying to move the left wing and the Centre Left of their Party towards these rational proposals. To the extent that the Opposition can blaze a policy trail and have the Government tag along many miles behind, we will continue to do so.

We will encourage the Government to sell the whole of the Commonwealth Bank for those objectives that I have stated before, that is, to increase service, to increase competition and to maximise the return to the Australian taxpayer. This legislation does not do that; it is a compromise deal. It is a deal to help the Victorian Government and it is going to cost the Australian taxpayer millions of dollars in revenue that can never be recovered. It is therefore partial privatisation, which we are opposed to in principle, but we will support this Bill because it is certainly moving in the right direction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the Senate is discussing the Commonwealth Banks Restructuring Bill 1990. The Bill proposes to provide, with the support of complementary Victorian legislation, for the Commonwealth Bank of Australia's succession to all the rights, property, staff and liabilities of the State Bank of Victoria. The takeover will make the Commonwealth Bank the biggest bank in the domestic market, holding a quarter of all dollars deposited.

SPEECH.PARA: In Victoria, the Commonwealth will control 33 per cent of the market with a branch network of approximately 800 outlets. The merged Commonwealth Bank and State Bank of Victoria will be the dominant operator of superannuation roll-over funds with more than $2.5 billion of deferred retirement benefits.

The Bill originates from the spectacular collapse of the wholly owned merchant bank subsidiary of the State Bank, Tricontinental Corporation Ltd. Indeed, a former officer of Tricontinental is facing criminal charges and a royal commission into the circumstances has been called by the Victorian Government.

The Commonwealth Bank group is to be restructured. The Commonwealth Bank and the Commonwealth Development Bank of Australia will be turned into companies with share capital. The Commonwealth Bank will be deemed to be a public company and will be listed on the Australian Stock Exchange. Some existing provisions will be retained. These are: the Commonwealth guarantee on all liabilities of the bank; the charter of the Commonwealth Bank; the residual power of the Government to overrule the bank board in a matter of policy; a power for the Treasurer to intervene in the bank's dividend policy, although it must not exceed 45 per cent of the consolidated profits of the group; and the existing exemption of the Commonwealth Bank from State taxes.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting, I was describing the existing provisions governing the Commonwealth Bank which are being retained. These include the power of the Treasurer to intervene in the bank's dividend policy, although it must not exceed 45 per cent of the consolidated profits of the group. As well, the provision governing the existing exemption of the Commonwealth Bank from State taxes and charges is to be abolished. A total amount not exceeding $243m is also appropriated as compensation for the loss to the Victorian Government of the income tax of the State Bank, and $170m for the tax losses that Tricontinental incurred which will not be available against Commonwealth income tax.

SPEECH.PARA: All the staff currently employed by the Commonwealth Banking Corporation and by the State Bank of Victoria will be transferred to the Commonwealth Bank with all their conditions of service and entitlements preserved. Notwithstanding this, there appears to be the prospect of substantial staff rationalisation-in other words, job losses-over the next few years. This appears more certain now, given the recent statements of the major private banks concerning job losses and staff retrenchments in their establishments.

Doubt has also been raised about the constitutional validity of part 5 of the Bill. Before discussing in detail some of the particular provisions of the Commonwealth Banks Restructuring Bill, it is appropriate to consider the history of this most symbolic of all publicly owned businesses. To save the time of the Senate, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a summary of the history of the Commonwealth Bank.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
HISTORY OF THE COMMONWEALTH BANKS:

Although there was increasing philosophical movement during the l9th Century towards State control of banking and finance it was the economic decline in the early 1890's which laid the foundation for the creation of the Commonwealth Bank.
In aggregate between mid-1891 and mid-1893 of the 64 institutions which called themselves banks only 10 were not forced to close or refuse payment for some period.
Of the quasi-bank institutions (building societies and land and mortgage companies) only one out of 36 was not forced to close.
The crash was occasioned by a fall in land prices which followed the enormous boom period of the 1880's.
The pressure filtered through the quasi-banks to the banks as confidence was eroded. In an uncanny resemblance to contemporary events the worst failures occurred in my home state of Victoria.

Many lost their life savings and the loss of purchasing power by the general community caused great hardship and had a very depressing effect on business. One of the major problems was that the banks would not support each other.
This disaster showed that the people still had faith in the state as a banker with the colonial post office savings accounts becoming the only ``haven'' during the crisis.
The call for Australia's own Bank of England intensified even though that institution was still private at that time.
Suddenly, there was movement for uniform banking regulation which could only occur as a result of federation of the colonies.
The early Labor Party platforms contained a policy of a national bank although the specific purposes of the institution were nebulous.
Most of the colonies debated the state bank question-indeed Queensland actually took over the issuance of currency notes, yet apart from this nothing of major significance was achieved.
However, a Victorian Royal Commission did suggest a model which closely resembled the actual composition of the Commonwealth Bank when it was finally formed 15 years later.
Such an institution was made possible by the banking power granted to the Commonwealth Government under the Australian Constitution.
All of the first seven Federal Governments between 1901 and 1910 had a banking plan-none of them were implemented. Meanwhile a strong movement for bank nationalisation had arisen.
The flamboyant King O'Malley led the call within the Labor Party to establish a Commonwealth Bank. This culminated at the Federal Conference of the Labor Party in July 1908.

Here O'Malley outlined his plan to create not only a banking institution, but also a mechanism to revolutionise Federal-State fiscal relations. Although the conference merely resolved to create a Commonwealth Bank which will be a bank of issue, deposit, exchange and reserve, O'Malley's plans were detailed and certainly practical.
Indeed O'Malley detailed his proposals in a five hour speech in the other place in 1909-we are only being allotted that amount of time to deal with this whole piece of legislation.
However, the Peoples' Bank would take decades to evolve into the institution that O'Malley envisaged.

The Fisher Government won the 1910 election and commenced the implementation of its Platform. However, the function of currency issuance was given to the Federal Treasury. Whilst a reasonable decision it was contrary to the O'Malley vision for the Commonwealth Bank.
The Commonwealth Bank Bill was introduced on October 25th, 1911; it became law on December 22nd, 1911.
Incredibly the Bank did not require any initial capital, although there was provision in the legislation for a 1,000,000 pounds debenture issue for this purpose.
The Bill gave the Bank power to:
* carry on business as a savings and a trading bank;
* make loans and issue bills;
* to deal in assets.
It did not create a central bank.

Indeed the Governor, Mr. Denison Miller went out of his way to not attempt to dominate either savings or general banking. He was appointed on June 1st, 1912 and completely dominated the policy of the Bank until his death in 1923.

The Commonwealth Savings Bank opened in Victoria with the other states following progressively. Andrew Fisher opened the first account, King O'Malley the third. The Bank did obtain a market advantage by occupying the post offices which had formerly been used by the various State Savings Banks.

Although the Commonwealth took over the State Savings Bank of Tasmania on January 1st, 1913 there was no attempt to dominate savings banking. Whilst it was thought that eventually all the state banks would become redundant, such a policy was not pursued.
Indeed the Governor set the rate of interest to be paid on accounts at a rate below that on offer from the state banks.

As well as the Savings Bank the Commonwealth commenced general banking business as well. The head office was located in Sydney not Melbourne, quite a controversial decision at the time. The first deposit was by the Commonwealth Government. The Government transferred its business in each State and in London.

Prior to the Bank commencing business, all of the private Trading Banks charged half yearly account keeping charges on all current accounts. The Commonwealth abolished fees on accounts that were overdrawn (and hence incurring interest) and on those with a minimum balance of 50 pounds.
The accounts of local government bodies, friendly societies, churches, charities, non-profit associations and State and Commonwealth Government accounts were completely exempted from fees.
Even Senators' and Members' accounts were exempted.

Lower interest rates were charged on loans to social organisations and governing bodies, and Friendly Societies and other similar bodies were granted the flexibility of current account facilities whilst their deposits accrued interest at the savings bank rate.
Thus right from the start the Commonwealth Bank has provided competition which only a public institution can do.

World War I really showed the value to the nation of the People's Bank. When war broke out there was great fear that runs would commence on every bank in Australia. The Commonwealth averted this by a simple yet brilliant strategy. Extra tellers were put on and instructed to pay out all withdrawals as quickly as possible.
This extraordinary action prevented large queues forming and hence averted a crisis of confidence.
Furthermore, whilst all British banks other than the Bank of England were closed during the banking moratorium which occurred in London, the CBA remained open.
The Bank even provided funds to the Federal Government to purchase necessary horses for the Australian forces before the relevant Supply bills had been passed by the Parliament.

Members of the armed services were provided with a variety of services including savings facilities, exemption from any fees including telegraphic transfer fees for ``diggers'' or their families, emergency money-even financing holidays in Britain, France and Italy for those on leave.
All prisoners of war who were repatriated back to Britain were met by an officer of the Bank on arrival to ensure that they should not be even temporarily short of money.
But the Bank's major contribution was to raise massive war loans to assist in the financing of the war effort-what would have happened if the ``People's Bank'' had not existed?
In addition the Bank played a key role in financing the export trade. Trade was predominantly with Britain and was dominated by agricultural commodities-wool, wheat, meat, etc.
Pooling arrangements were devised to guarantee orderly marketing of these products. Financing these pools was a combined banking operation in which CBA acquired a central role.
Whilst these were purely pragmatic wartime measures, such control of commodity marketing was a function the socialist elements envisaged for the CBA.

The Bank was also instrumental in Billy Hughes' astounding acquisition of a shipping line for the Australian Government. To further Australia's interests, Hughes decided to create an Australian shipping line to sever our reliance on the British controlled fleet.

With CBA finance Hughes secretly acquired 15 merchant ships which he subsequently convinced the British Government he should be allowed to keep. This was the birth of the Commonwealth shipping line-unfortunately the Coalition also sees no benefit in maintaining a public shipping line, and hence proposes to sell Australian National Lines.
Meanwhile the Bank was assisting to establish BHP and the Trans Australian Railway.

The Bank was also progressively picking up the banking business of the smaller states-with Tasmania transferring in June 1914, Western Australia in October and South Australia in March 1916. In December 1920 the Queensland Government Savings Bank was acquired by CBA as was the business of the Queensland Government.
The Bank was heavily involved in the post war transition and played a leading role in the provision of housing for veterans.

Indeed the British Labor Party became very impressed with the CBA and began advocating an English State Bank. Such a proposal caused problems in the City of London which then determined to attempt to starve the radical Labor State of Queensland from raising funds through the CBA.

The Queensland Government simply went to New York which forever broke the finance monopoly the City of London had on Australian Governments. Obviously this transition was brilliantly managed-the outcry which arose when the Whitlam Government attempted to bypass the existing finance markets (New York and London) and borrow directly from the Arabs shows how politically dangerous such a move can be.

The note issue function was transferred in 1920 from the Treasury to the newly created Note Issue Department in the Commonwealth Bank. This department was run by a separate Board. This was the front runner of the full Bank Board which was created in 1924.
By the time of the 1922 election campaign the Country Party had become a force in politics and Earl Page adopted the O'Malley policy that the Commonwealth Bank should
``become a Central Bank by giving it control of the currency under an independent Board of Directors and making it the Bank of Exchange, Discount and Reserve''.
After the election a Coalition was formed and Page became the Treasurer. In 1924 a package of reform measures was enacted. These principally being
* the creation of an independent Bank Board which consisted of business leaders;
* empowering the Bank to effect interbank exchanges.

However, the Government acceded to the request of the Private Banks to remove from the legislation the necessity for the private banks to keep their reserves in special accounts with the Commonwealth Bank-thus this fundamental element of a central bank was still denied to the Commonwealth Bank.
In 1925 a Rural Credits Department was created to provide farmers with short-term finance to assist them in marketing their produce-this greatly enhanced the Bank's standing in the community.

To allay the fears of the private banks, the Commonwealth abandoned active competition for trading bank business. In 1927 Legislation was also passed to constitute the Commonwealth Savings Bank as a separate institution, although still managed by the same Board.

In April 1930, the Scullin Government introduced into Parliament a Central Reserve Bank Bill to provide for a fully fledged central bank, separate from the Commonwealth Bank. The Opposition controlled Senate sent it to die in a Select Committee which, in due course, it did.

Although Australia emerged from the Depression without a formally constituted central bank, important central banking functions were undertaken during that period. The Bank gained control of Australia's domestic gold reserves and arranged gold exports to ease the nation's international liquidity problems. It secured a Mobilisation Agreement from the private banks to ensure that adequate foreign exchange was available to meet Government commitments. It coordinated the underwriting of Government loans and the take-up of Treasury Bills, assumed control of exchange rate determination and acted as adviser to the Government.
The battles between the Bank and the Government during this period were legendary and show the possible dangers of a too independent central bank.

The savings bank business of the Commonwealth Bank also received a fillip due to the demise of the Government Savings Bank of NSW. After a succession of crises a major run on the State Bank occurred on 22 April 1931 and it had to shut its doors. Negotiations continued for months between the Commonwealth Bank and the State Bank with an agreement finally being reached in December.

The takeover was not total with the State Treasury retaining the advances of the State Savings Bank's Rural Bank Department and the business of the Advances for Homes and Government Housing Departments. In 1933 these became part of a newly established Rural Bank of NSW.
No compensation was paid, although under the agreement the profits and losses of the former State Bank were split between the NSW Government and the Commonwealth Bank.

During this time the CBA also became involved in similar negotiations with Western Australia. These culminated in a takeover by agreement of the State Savings Bank of Western Australia in October 1931.

By the end of the Depression the Commonwealth Savings Bank had become the dominant savings institution whose only competitors were the State Banks in Victoria and South Australia and the two trustee savings banks in Tasmania.

In 1936 a Royal Commission into banking and the monetary system was established-it reported in 1937 although none of its recommendations were put into practice until the second world war. Ben Chifley gave a dissenting report which argued for complete Government control of banking.

In 1938 legislation was introduced to implement the less controversial recommendations of the Royal Commission. King O'Malley started a `save the People's Bank' campaign from what he saw as the legislation's attempt to deliver the Bank to the private bankers. It is unclear exactly how this could have come about but it involved the proposed power to issue debentures to private interests. Larry Noye (a noted authority on the Bank) claims the legislation was an attempt by the Treasurer, R. G. Casey, to privatise the Bank. In any event the legislation lapsed and a modified Bill was aborted by the outbreak of World War 2.

During the war the Bank was given comprehensive powers of exchange control, foreign exchange transactions monopolies and a formal power to fix exchange rates under the Defence power of the Constitution. In addition the ``special account'' procedure was introduced and supplemented by the power to licence private banks, control bank interest rates and to obtain information from banks as and when desired.
To control total bank credit the Commonwealth Bank was also given power on bank lending policy, the control of bank profits and the control of bank purchases of Government securities.

Again the Bank was a key institution in the war effort, providing service to the troops, developing local industries, financing capital works, arranging the war financing effort and managing the private banks.

In 1943 a Mortgage Bank Department was created along the lines recommended by the Royal Commission. In 1945 a further department, the Industrial Finance Department, was created to meet the needs of small business.

Most of the wartime controls were enacted in the 1945 Commonwealth Bank and Banking Acts of 1945. In addition the Bank Board was abolished, and the Bank was instructed to pursue trading bank business actively. The Bank also received additional specialised trading departments.

This legislation was opposed bitterly and a constitutional challenge by the Melbourne City Council resulted in Section 48 of the Banking Act being declared invalid. The provision made it illegal for private banks to conduct business for a State or State Authority, including Local Government Authorities, without Australian Treasury approval. This apparently motivated Mr. Chifley into full bank nationalisation in 1947.

Of course, as we all know, the conservative High Court accepted Sir Garfield Barwick's reasoning and section 92 of the Constitution was held to invalidate the legislation. Given current judicial interpretation a different decision would probably now prevail.

In March 1950 the new Government honoured its election promise and introduced legislation to repeal the nationalisation legislation and reintroduced a Bank Board. The Labor controlled Senate blocked the legislation and a double dissolution ensued. Menzies won control of both Houses and in 1951 the legislation passed.

In 1952 the Board restructured its General Banking Department along the lines of private trading banks and issued comparable financial statements. It also voluntarily complied with the Special Account reserve deposits.

Further concessions were made to the private banks by the Menzies Government in 1953 and 1959. In 1953 the Commonwealth Trading Bank was created out of the General Banking Division and was subjected to income tax to level the playing field with the private banks. The new Trading Bank was also subjected to the same regulation as the private banks.
In 1956 the amalgamation agreement with the Western Australian Government was terminated and the State Government established a Savings Bank Division of its Rural and Industries Bank.

The major reform of the period was the 1959 legislation which formally split the Commonwealth Bank's major functions by separating the trading and central banking operations. A previous Bill had been stalled by the Senate until the 1958 elections.

The Commonwealth (Central) Bank, the Note Issue Department and the Rural Credits Department, were transformed into the Reserve Bank of Australia. All the commercial and savings bank subsidiaries were removed except for the Rural Credit Department which only provided finance to (mainly government) marketing authorities. The Statutory Reserve Deposit scheme also replaced the special account requirements.

The trading section of the Bank was also restructured. The existing Savings Bank and Trading Bank were joined by the new Commonwealth Development Bank (CDB) which was created by merging the Mortgage Bank and the Industrial Finance Departments. These were all parts of the new Commonwealth Banking Corporation. Since January 14th, 1960 these three banks have carried on business as separate legal and accounting entities.

The Commonwealth Trading Bank joined with the Reserve Bank and the private trading banks in 1964 to form the Australian Banks' Export Re-Finance Corporation Limited (ABERC). In 1967 a similar arrangement was concluded for the commencement of the Australian Resources Development Bank to foster the development of Australia's natural resources. ABERC was taken over by the Resources Bank in 1980. The CTB was also a founding shareholder in the newly established Primary Industry Bank of Australasia (PIBA) and the Development Bank has a special relationship with PIBA.
CSB and CTB also jointly started a finance company (CBFC), a travel company and a property company.

In March 1969 the Corporation became the first Australian banking organisation to introduce `on-line' computer processing of savings bank transactions. The Trading Bank was also a founding shareholder in the Merchant Bank and the Australian European Finance Corporation.

In 1984 the Commonwealth Banks were restructured into a structure similar to the private banking groups. The Commonwealth Trading Bank reverted to the original name of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. A $15 million capital injection was provided by the Government and some of the reserves of the Development Bank were transferred to the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. The Savings Bank became a subsidiary of the Trading Bank.

The arrangements requiring half of the after-tax profits of Trading Bank and half of the profits of the Savings Bank be paid to the Commonwealth were repealed and replaced with dividend arrangements. The Savings Bank and the Development Bank were subjected to income tax.

In 1985 the Development Bank's charter was broadened to allow it to provide finance for all business purposes and to provide equity finance. This was accompanied by the removal of interest rate ceilings on loans under $100,000.

A further restructuring of the Commonwealth Banks occurred in 1988 when the charter of the Savings Bank and the CBA were expanded in the areas of banking, insurance and investment. A dividend requirement was also instituted for the Development Bank.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The takeover of the State Bank of Victoria is part of the restructuring and, indeed, the continuing evolution of the bank. The State Banks of Tasmania, Queensland and New South Wales have already contributed to a stronger Commonwealth Bank, and certainly the State Bank of my own State will do so if this legislation becomes law.

SPEECH.PARA: However, there are certain aspects of the Bill which are matters for concern, and there are certain matters which the Australian Democrats will oppose. One matter of concern is the compensation to my State of Victoria for its loss of the revenue stream which the State Bank would have provided to State revenue. The Bill appropriates an amount not in excess of $243m for this purpose.

Dr Kevin Davis of the University of Melbourne has pointed out that this amount of compensation grossly undervalues the stream of tax currently received by the Victoria Government. The present value of any annuity paid in perpetuity can be established by dividing the annual value of the annuity by the real rate of interest which applies during the period. Hence, if tax was paid at the rate of $80m per annum, and the real rate of interest was 5 per cent, the present value of such an income stream would be $1.6 billion. Clearly, the compensation of $243m is grossly inadequate. Admittedly, even a solid government guaranteed profit earner like the State Bank does not carry quite the certainty of an annuity, but even if one cuts the present value in half, fair compensation would still amount to approximately $800m.

The other matter is the method used to finance the purchase of the State Bank. We are totally opposed to the decision to issue shares to private and foreign investors. This legislation purports to guarantee government majority control of the Commonwealth Bank group, and that the subsidiaries of the Commonwealth Bank will remain 100 per cent owned. However, to be fully effective the people's bank must remain in full government ownership. If private equity were necessary, then an employee share ownership scheme and subscriptions from superannuation funds would be the preferable means of raising funds.

The sell-out contemplated is simply not necessary, in our view. There are other forms of finance which could be and should be employed. The Federal Government could dip into some of the hollow logs which its authorities have accumulated in recent years, just as it has forced the State governments to do in recent years. As an example, I refer to the $500m transferred from the earnings of the Reserve Bank of Australia under section 78 of the Reserve Bank Act in the last financial year. The combined reserves representing provisions for the effects of movements in market yields and in exchange rates stood at over $1.8 billion at 30 June 1990. The total call on these provisions during the last financial year was $200m, so there was a net addition during that year alone of $300m.

While it is clear that it is prudent to have a strong central bank, it is also clear that section 78 provides a perfect opportunity to park surplus funds which would otherwise revert to the Commonwealth for a rainy day. Such a rainy day has arrived. One of the greatest public assets in the country is threatened with partial privatisation. This strategy was adopted to influence the National Conference of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) to authorise the privatisation and deregulation agenda of the Cabinet in this and other areas. That purpose has now been served and the fate of the Commonwealth Bank should be reviewed.

The Government could raise additional revenue to pay for the purchase. Indeed, there are many possibilities. Our alternative budget lists over 20 options. Ending the section 128F withholding tax exemption, and raising the withholding tax rate on payments of interest to residents in countries which do not have double taxation agreements with Australia alone, would provide the revenue needed within a couple of years. A 40 per cent excise increase on tobacco and alcohol would raise in real terms $1.1 billion. Apart from the health benefits which would result, in real terms a cigarette is now considerably cheaper than it was in 1949, when a single cigarette cost 16 cents, compared with 10.5 cents in 1990.

Alternatively, the Government could simply apply some of the existing surplus, as Mr John Carson explained in an excellent letter which appeared on page 14 of the Australian Financial Review on 2 September 1990. The letter points out that the surplus will be spent in repaying debt. However, at the current rate of debt repayment there will be no Commonwealth debt in existence after three or four years. After that, the Government must buy assets with the surplus. What a fantastic opportunity to build the kind of facility and infrastructure this country needs.

Clearly, the Government should keep the Commonwealth Bank as a good investment, if for no other reason. But there are, of course, several other reasons which I will go into later. In terms of investment, if one looks at the last two years one sees returns of between 13 per cent and 14.6 per cent on average equity. An investment carrying that sort of return, backed by government guarantee, must be an investment that Australian taxpayers and the Australian community should retain.

Mr Carson also noted that asset sales and investments should not affect the Budget surplus. The only reason Australia treats such investment decisions as within the Budget is that we adopt the International Monetary Fund system of public accounts. The United Nations system of national accounts is the alternative measure. This system excludes assets sales and public investments; that is, it treats such transactions as capital transactions, which is of course what they are-they have no place in an income and expenditure statement.

The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development uses this system when comparing the fiscal policy of member countries. Indeed, Glen Milne, in an excellent article in the Australian of 30 August, pointed out that in November 1987 the Treasurer (Mr Keating) referred to the United Nations system as `the most respected basis of comparison for total government deficits'. The whole basis of the Government's crying poor in this regard simply arises because of the system of national accounts we use in Australia. Indeed, commentators always exclude asset sales when determining the real or underlying surplus or deficit which is predicted by a Budget. So basically this assertion that we cannot afford such assets being publicly owned is absolute ideological balderdash. Alan Kohler in the Sunday Age of August 1990 wrote on the takeover as follows:
I'm a shareholder of both banks, so I've got a conflict of interest to declare. It means I don't know whether to laugh or to cry.
I would love it if the Commonwealth Bank bought the State Bank, although I'm torn about the price: as an Australian I hope it gets it cheap, but as a Victorian I want it to pay through the nose.

But what I really oppose is a cheap dilution of my shareholding in the Commonwealth Bank to pay for it, and I wish Paul Keating would stop acting like a politician and think more like a shareholder's representative.
This comes from a self-confessed pro-privatisation journalist.

Professor Hugh Stretton has also condemned the proposed dilution of public ownership. He points out that a fully public bank can be used to provide services which a private bank would not otherwise provide. In addition, apart from performing specific functions, publicly owned banks may also reduce the need for detailed regulation of the private institutions by being a force for implementing public policy and, indeed, by keeping them honest. The Commonwealth Bank could be used as an instrument of government policy to force certain behaviour from the private banks such as in the area of home interest rates, where the Commonwealth Bank is usually the first bank to drop and the last bank to increase rates. Mr Keating has recently been critical of the banks rather than the Government running monetary policy. Why then would the Government choose to partially privatise its own bank and give up an instrument of public policy? There is simply no consistency in that approach.

I find it incredible that nobody has simply suggested the absolutely obvious option of financing the takeover by the Commonwealth Government, assuming the debt is to be retired by the State Government. Such an arrangement is not simply a bail-out of Victoria, but merely a sensible financing option of a major purchase. There is no doubt that the increased Commonwealth Bank group will be extremely profitable. Why not make the investment that Westpac Banking Corporation was prepared to make and repay the debt so incurred when the investment provides the return to do so? The issue of public, and indeed ALP policy, is at least as important. The sell-out by both the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer is a betrayal of Labor Party history-they are, with this legislation, creating for themselves a position of infamy.

Senator Richardson was reported in the press recently concerning the rapid loss of members which his Party is suffering. Is it any wonder, given decisions such as this, which are really implementing Liberal Party policy? Most significantly, the Government is in breach of the undertakings in the Caucus resolution of 28 August which sanctioned this legislation. At that conference the Treasurer obtained Caucus approval for the 30 per cent sale of Commonwealth Bank shares only on the condition that no further privatisation and no sales to foreign interests took place.

However, both undertakings can be circumvented by the government of the day through loopholes in the legislation as it now stands. Ostensibly, the sale to foreign interests is prohibited by proposed new section 27k. However, subsection (11) provides:
The issue of shares is not affected by the fact that the application for the issue was made in contravention of this section.

Further, under subsection (4), regulations could be enacted to provide for exceptions or modifications, as the Government decides. Finally, proceedings for an offence under this section could not be instituted without the consent of the Treasurer in writing. Also, the sale to private interests beyond 30 per cent is ostensibly prohibited by proposed new section 27l. However, the issue of non-voting shares is not prohibited. This could be used to increase private shareholdings. Most importantly, subsection (5) provides:
A contravention of this section does not affect the validity of any act or transaction involved in the contravention.
Not surprisingly, contravention of the section is not made an offence and there is no provision for anyone to have standing to challenge any breach of the provisions by the Government or the bank.

It is not as if a contravention could be accidental; it must be by way of a deliberate action. Either the Commonwealth must transfer some existing shares or the bank must issue some shares or the voting rights attached to existing shares must be altered. Clearly, this must be a deliberate act. This provision, therefore, envisages that deliberate acts in contravention of this legislation and the undertakings that the Government made to its Caucus can be circumvented at will. A further proviso is found in point 13 of the Caucus resolution. This states that non-government equity will not be introduced to the subsidiaries of the bank.

Clause 36 proposes to insert new section 74a into the principal Act. Subsections (11) and (12) of the section ensure that the Development Bank will remain a 100 per cent subsidiary of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. This is essentially the same as the provisions providing for retention of the Savings Bank as a 100 per cent subsidiary. However, what about the Commonwealth Investments New Zealand Ltd group, the Commonwealth Bank Finance Co. group, the Travel Service group and the life insurance business of the group. Clearly the legislation contravenes, or at least does not implement, this part of the Caucus resolution.

Another interesting effect of the legislation concerns the restructuring of the board of the Commonwealth Bank. Clause 9 of the Bill inserts many new provisions into part II of the principal Act. Proposed new section 8a will grant to the Treasurer the power to appoint the Secretary to the Department of the Treasury to the board of the bank. Such an appointment is revocable without reference to this Parliament. However, what the explanatory memorandum does not say is that clause 18 of the Bill abolishes the current provisions determining the constitution of the board. These provisions state that the Treasury Secretary shall be a member of the board. Thus there is no requirement for the presence of the Treasury Secretary nor for any other representative with the specific responsibility for the public interest and the bank's community service obligations.

We see that this legislation does not even conform to the undertakings given to the parliamentary members of the Labor Party, let alone to the wishes of the Australian people. The Senate currently has a Bill before it for the membership of Australia in the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. The Commonwealth Bank, as has been shown earlier in my remarks, has a proud history of assisting the development of this nation. How ironic it is that we are selling off part of our bank whilst at the same time contributing to an institution which will help to rebuild and modernise the ex-communist states of eastern Europe.

However, before closing my remarks I would like to address the comments about this Bill made by the shadow Treasurer in the other place. We all know about his impressive performances lately. Mr Reith said that if the coalition is elected to government at the next election it will expect the support of the Australian Democrats in fully privatising the Commonwealth Bank. He stated that it would be undemocratic if we did not support his Party's privatisation policies. The Australian Democrats do not support privatisation of profitable government businesses. No apology is needed for that and none will be forthcoming, particularly not for a public utility with public policy and community service obligations-not that we need to deny our support to the coalition; the Government will in fact do it for the coalition parties and make it impossible for them to proceed. The London Times, hardly a left wing newspaper, on 30 August, 1987 reported:
Of all the plums waiting to be picked by the privateers, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia is the juiciest.

Members of the Opposition wish to enrich their stockbroking, banking and advertising mates and impoverish the national Government. They will not succeed and we will have the support of the people of Australia in stopping them.

Mr Reith issued a press release on 13 November 1990 detailing the coalition's support for the Bill and the amendments it seeks to make. In brief, the amendments provide for 100 per cent privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank and for its unrestricted sale to foreign interests. These amendments are purely ideological and they continue the Opposition's policy of selling off the farm-an Opposition attitude which, for Australia's sake, I trust will fail. Certainly, we will ensure that the coalition fails in its efforts.
I draw to the attention of the Opposition the words of the founder of the Liberal Party. Shortly after introducing the 1952 Commonwealth Bank Bill, the then Prime Minister Menzies stated:

I want to make it perfectly clear that the Commonwealth is no more willing to damage the Commonwealth Bank than it is to damage the trading banks. I think there is abundant room for both. The Government is pledged to fair competition, not to destruction. I think that the public will agree with it.
Rest assured that the Australian Democrats will seek to ensure that no such vandalism will be allowed-either by the Opposition or by this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the pressures of time upon this Senate because of the application of the guillotine process and the fact that the Commonwealth Banks Restructuring Bill 1990 has been referred to the appropriate legislation committee, I will indeed be brief in speaking to it. Regrettably, this important measure was shunted through the House of Representatives in a mere 90 minutes. As my colleague Senator Short has indicated, the coalition will be putting forward several important amendments to this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: There are several aspects to this deal between the Federal Treasurer, Mr Keating, and the Victorian Premier, Mrs Kirner, to sell off the State Bank of Victoria (SBV) to the Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA) that do require critical comment. Firstly, on a large number of occasions the Treasurer, Mr Keating, has publicly spoken against privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank and other government owned businesses. However, when it comes to a politically opportune moment to dabble in a bit of privatisation and thus save a State Labor government from complete disaster, the rules are changed, and thus we are here debating the Commonwealth Banks Restructuring Bill-a Bill which perhaps could be more aptly called the Commonwealth Bank (Part-Privatisation) Bill.

While I do not oppose the Commonwealth Bank paying a market price for the Victorian State Bank, I do object to the use of Australian taxpayers' funds, under the stewardship of the Federal Treasury, to supply $430m to the State of Victoria. I thus disagree with the basis of compensation not reflecting the current earnings performance of the bank and its subsidiaries, which currently reflects loss situations. The compensation, therefore, is overgenerous. It does not reflect the current trading or financial position of the bank and its current ability-or should I say inability-to contribute to State revenue.

The Government has used taxpayers' funds, in the words of the Commonwealth Government, to `restructure and expand the activities of the Commonwealth Bank'. It is a grand socialist objective, partly at taxpayers' expense. I believe that is objectionable.

I am not privy to the details of the tendering process which was undertaken by the Victorian Government in determining the new owners of the State Bank. However, most people would be aware that the Westpac Banking Corporation, the other official contender, made an initial proposal that was $55m higher than the $1.6 billion value placed on the bank by the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. The Commonwealth-the Commonwealth Government, mind you, not the Commonwealth Bank-then sweetened the deal by providing extra compensation for forgone tax revenue, a figure inflated by the difference between the Federal tax returns from the CBA and Victorian rates.

There was then a further $170m to reflect the tax losses of the Savings Bank of Victoria arising from Tricontinental Corporation Ltd, since those should not be used in future tax deductibility, given the commercial problems in utilising such tax losses. Because of the application of the tax business test for the takeover by another institution, I would contend that this $170m calculation is indeed a generous allocation of taxpayers' funds. In a normal situation such losses would have been amortised over a long period and hence this figure, I believe, should have been further discounted for the time value of money. I would suggest that the market value of the SBV should have been the basis for determining its purchase price to the Commonwealth Bank. If Westpac was not willing to compensate the State of Victoria for its tax revenue losses, nor should the Commonwealth have been. Such a move is a market distortion which was made purely for political purposes.

Whilst part privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank will pay for the purchase price of $1.6 billion, taxpayers will have to pay the additional $433m promised by Mr Keating. As a taxpayer, I object to this. The decision was also an interesting one in light of the decision made by the Treasurer only a couple of weeks prior to the SBV takeover announcement. I am of course referring to the Treasurer's decision to disallow the merger of the National Mutual Life Association of Australasia Ltd and the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd. The acquisition of the State Bank of Victoria will make the Commonwealth Bank the dominant player in the domestic banking market, holding $1 in every $4 deposited. In Victoria the combined bank will control 33 per cent of the market, with a branch network of nearly 800 outlets. This takeover produces more market combination than the ANZ-National Mutual would have created. This would appear to be a case of double standards and certainly a conflict of interest on the part of the Treasurer, Mr Keating.

Having thus had the takeover of the State Bank of Victoria by the Commonwealth Bank of Australia virtually decreed upon us, we now have the Commonwealth Banks Restructuring Bill before us today for debate. The Commonwealth Banks Restructuring Bill is to put into effect the Commonwealth Government's decision for the Commonwealth Bank to purchase the State Bank of Victoria for $1.6 billion, to be paid for by the sale of 30 per cent of the share capital of the resulting enlarged Commonwealth Banking Corporation. While not reflecting at all on the current management of the Commonwealth Bank, this whole concept of privatisation should be designed to get business enterprises out of the hands of government and into the hands of people in business who have a real motive and interest to promote efficiency and better administration.

As I said before, this is a messy partial privatisation which will not result in all these privatisation objectives being fully achieved. Some of the flaws in this legislation which will prevent the objectives being met have already been brought to the attention of this chamber, but I wish to reiterate a few of them: firstly, the Commonwealth Government is to maintain majority ownership and control of the Commonwealth Bank in perpetuity; secondly, a limit of 30 per cent private ownership is proposed by this legislation; thirdly, other banks, including foreign banks, will not be permitted to acquire original shares in the merged bank; and, fourthly, individual shareholders will be limited to a five per cent interest. Such requirements are not typical of banks operating in the real world-they are artificial and messy-nor should they be adopted in this legislation or by the Commonwealth Bank.

During the debate in the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration I raised with the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) the need for an aide-memoire as to the Government's use of the reserve powers to intervene in matters outside board structure issues, including changes and amendments to the corporate plan. On the other hand, the Government has perhaps lost an opportunity on this occasion of the restructuring of the Commonwealth Bank to widen the charter of the operations of the bank to allow it to compete with other banks for the collection of savings within the community.

Given the new role of superannuation as a vehicle for diverting savings, such as industry superannuation schemes, much of the traditional role of savings and trading banks will now decline and will be redirected to superannuation funds. I must admit to being of the opinion expressed by Des Keegan in his column of 25 July, when he said:
Why not let the Victorian Government sell the crippled State Bank off for what it is worth? Then, why not sell the sound Commonwealth Bank off for what it is worth?

The coalition's philosophy supports this Bill. Despite the fact that it is based on partial privatisation, it is certainly a step on the very long road to complete privatisation. It is not complete privatisation; I reiterate that in this case the privatisation is only partial. It is also messy. Despite these reservations, with our amendments the coalition supports the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Government's Bill to partially privatise the Commonwealth Bank. When Senator Spindler was talking, I noticed Senator Cook and Senator Button looking closely at him and thinking, `My God, that is what I used to believe'. They have seen the past, and it does not work. I will also comment on other aspects raised by Senator Spindler.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I agreed with him on one aspect: this is a very important and historic piece of legislation for a number of reasons. By bringing this legislation before the Senate, the Hawke-Keating Government has in effect dumped Labor's philosophy, platform and election promises. As Senator Watson pointed out, this is a small step for privatisation. To paraphrase Commander Armstrong's comments, this is indeed a small step for privatisation but it is a mighty step for Labor. With this Bill, Labor has conceded that the privatisation approach of economic management advocated by the coalition is the way ahead. If one likes to use a Labor Party analogy, it is the light on the hill. It is certainly not, however, the light on the hill that was spotted by Ben Chifley. It is certainly not the light on the hill to which Mrs McLean, a delegate to the recent Australian Labor Party special conference, referred when she called Mr Hawke `Comrade Bob' and quoted the words he spouted during his now notorious Chifley speech in September 1987, when he said:

What in the name of reason is the justification for breaking up and selling off the great and efficient national assets, like the Commonwealth Bank, Telecom, TAA and Qantas? As the people of Australia come to realise the extent of the economic and social vandalism proposed by our opponents-
the vandalism he was talking about was the selling off of the Commonwealth Bank and Australian Airlines Ltd-
. . . it will be necessary for us, Ben Chifley's great heirs and successors, to keep fresh and green the memory, the example and experience of this great Australian.

That was Comrade Bob Hawke in 1987. By bringing this Bill before the Parliament the Government has conceded the pathetic nonsense its own Prime Minister spouted just three years ago. Of course, the Labor Government went to the last election making promises such as the one it made to the Commonwealth Bank Officers Association, as my colleagues mentioned, that the Commonwealth Bank would not be privatised.

The honourable member for Hindmarsh, Mr John Scott, at least had the decency to stand up and defend what I believe is an outdated philosophy. Mr Scott happens to believe it, as do quite a number of people on the Labor benches, but not one of them will speak in the debate tonight. Not one of them is prepared to stand up and defend the Government's role.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that a challenge?

—Yes, that is a challenge. If Senator McKiernan thinks it will be of any help to him, I will be happy to post copies of his speech on this subject to his constituents. On 14 November the honourable member for Hindmarsh said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Members and supporters of the Australian Labor Party and everyone voting for Labor had every right to believe that a Labor Government would not-repeat, not-sell off the Commonwealth Bank.

It was probably naive of the honourable member for Hindmarsh to believe any statement made by Mr Hawke or Mr Keating. Has he not heard of the huge list of broken promises the Prime Minister has accumulated? Does he not remember the promises on child poverty, higher living standards, low interest rates, low taxation, no capital gains taxes and no extensions to the tax file number? They are all great Labor Party promises, all broken.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or for a thousand new jobs.

—I thank Senator Maguire for butting in. Remember that Mr Hawke and Mr Keating-and I suspect Senator Maguire-said there would be no recession. I bet Senator Maguire said that in the last election campaign. While they said that there would be no recession they were actually engineering one. What a great effort! Remember that Hawke promised to retire at the next election. I suspect that Mr Keating believed that promise. The broken promises of the Labor Government are endless. Despite its importance, the Commonwealth Banks Restructuring Bill was debated for only an hour and a half in the other place. As a result of the deal done by the Australian Democrats, we are allowed to debate the Bill in this chamber for only three hours. That is only four and a half hours in total for the Commonwealth Parliament to consider one of the biggest deals in Australian corporate history, worth about $1.6 billion, and to consider a number of important related issues such as the tendering process for the State Bank of Victoria.
—The biggest bank in Australia.

—As Senator Short pointed out, after this deal goes through it will be the biggest bank in Australia. This Bill, together with the Government's proposals on Qantas, Australian Airlines Ltd and Aussat, represents the first major privatisation package brought into the Parliament by the Labor Government. With this Bill the Government has failed to carry through effectively the management and ownership philosophy it has recently adopted. Senator Spindler is right in saying that the coalition's policy is in favour of 100 per cent privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank. Nevertheless, this legislation represents a step forward from the reactionary approach to management which has dominated this Government virtually from the day of its inception.

SPEECH.PARA: Some 80 countries around the world have carried out privatisation activities. They have carried them out for the simple reason that it is a method of providing better services to customers and better deals for employees. Only the Australian Democrats now wear ideological blinkers on privatisation. The Australian Democrats must be one of the few parties in the Western world, Eastern world and Third World which resolutely oppose every measure of privatisation. Is it possible for a Democrat at some stage to stand up in this Parliament and tell us whether we can privatise anything? Can we contract out government cleaning services? The ideological blinkers Senator Spindler wears when he comes into this place and discusses privatisation are unbelievable.

TALK.START.PARA: —We just care for the public benefit.
—Don't get excited.
—Order! Senator Kemp, please address your remarks through the Chair.

—Sorry, Mr Acting Deputy President. The Labor Party, as must be expected from a party which has dumped its history and not discovered any new coherent philosophy or principles, finds it difficult to come up with a privatisation approach which is consistent and logical.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Banks Restructuring Bill represents a desperate attempt by the Labor Party to adopt a more rational economic structure while at the same time placating the Labor Party's left wing. Somehow it is appropriate to fully privatise Australian Airlines Ltd and Aussat Pty Ltd, but only 30 per cent of the Commonwealth Bank. Therefore, the coalition believes in many ways that while this legislation heads in the right direction it still does not go far enough and, to that extent, it is poor legislation. As has been flagged, we shall be moving some amendments which will help to improve this Bill.

From the ALP's point of view, there are very good reasons to guillotine this Bill through Parliament. The Labor Party is hopelessly divided on this issue and on this legislation. The Government has forced this legislation through its party room for one reason and one reason alone--

TALK.START.PARA: —Where are all their lefties?

—Senator Macdonald has very appropriately said, `Where are all those lefties?' Where are these people who told us that the Commonwealth Bank was one of the great sacred cows of the Labor Party? What a miserable defence they are putting up.
—There is one of them over there talking to Senator Button.

—I should point out to Senator Macdonald that Senator Spindler belongs to the Australia Democrats, not the Labor Party. In view of the way the Democrats voted in the last three days, we find it hard to believe on this side; nonetheless, that happens to be the case. The Government has been able to force this legislation through its party room for one reason and one reason alone: so that the Government can bail out the State Bank of Victoria which, in effect, has been destroyed by the disgraceful management of the Cain-Kirner Labor governments.

SPEECH.PARA: Undoubtedly, Senator Button breathes a sigh of relief that no Government senators will be speaking on this Bill. By bringing this Bill into Parliament, the Treasurer may have earned the undying enmities of his left wing colleagues and his branch members. Nonetheless, by making what in Labor Party terms is a huge concession to a different philosophical approach, can we now hope for a more rational basis for economic management of public enterprises in this country?

No longer will the Labor Party be able to indulge in privatisation scare tactics. Is Senator Maguire going to go out in the next election campaign and say, `Be careful. The Liberal Party is going to start privatising government assets. We have already privatised 30 per cent of the Commonwealth Bank. The percentage of ownership by the private sector may rise still further'. So it will go on. After four or five years of these disgraceful tactics, we are happy to note the concession which has been made by bringing this Bill into this Parliament.

It is for that reason that I look forward to voting with Senators Bolkus, Cook, Beahan, Zakharov and other members of the Labor Party Left when this Bill comes to the final vote. It will be a great pleasure to vote with Government members but in a sense their hearts and minds will be crossing over to the other side of us. I will conclude there. This is an important and historic day. It is a great pity that this chamber has not had a proper chance to debate the Bill.
