These amendments seek to ensure that the Commonwealth Bank will not be privatised. By that, I mean no part of it. The Australian Democrats believe that the Commonwealth Bank, the people's bank, should remain in the hands of the community. It has a purpose in that position. It provides a foothold for the community in determining public policy in the financial field, it enables the community to obtain community services which private banks are not prepared to supply, and it is an instrument of public policy.

The Democrats believe that to privatise any part of the bank is essentially the thin end of the wedge. These amendments seek to ensure that the 30 per cent privatisation which the Government seeks to enact in this Bill is not possible and that no foreign interests are able to purchase any shares in the Commonwealth Bank either at original issue or later at any stage. As well, the amendments seek to ensure that the Treasury Secretary at all times remains a member of the board and that there are no shares issued which carry differential voting rights. The whole range of amendments 1 to 7 of alternative A in summary seeks to ensure that the Commonwealth Bank remains a people's bank.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not be supporting Senator Spindler's amendments. The amendments go quite contrary to the direction in which we believe the bank needs to go in terms of its ownership. The Opposition wants to see a vibrant, competitive and efficient Commonwealth Bank providing the best possible service to its customers and to Australians as a whole. It is the policy of the coalition to achieve that greater competitiveness, efficiency and ability of the bank to compete in the financial markets of Australia and overseas by moving towards full privatisation. The Democrat amendments go 100 per cent the other way. For that reason, we will not be supporting them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments are not acceptable to the Government, as explained in the second reading debate, for reasons which are patently clear in the policy of this legislation and which have been indicated in the committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Spindler's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 12, page 4, proposed subsection 8a (1), lines 25 to 27, omit the subsection.
(2) Clause 12, page 4, proposed subsection 8a (2), line 28, omit ``While a determination under subsection (1) is in force,''.
(3) Clause 22, pages 10 and 11, proposed section 27k (3), (4), (10) and (11), lines 30 to 36 (page 10) and lines 13 to 16 (page 11), omit the subsections.
(4) Clause 22, page 11, proposed paragraphs 27l (2) (a) and (b), lines 27 to 33, omit the paragraphs, substitute the following paragraphs:
``(a) that the Commonwealth no longer holds shares in the Commonwealth Bank that carry the rights to exercise 70% of the rights attached to the shares in the Commonwealth Bank;
(b) that the Commonwealth no longer controls the exercise of 70% of the rights attached to the shares in the Commonwealth Bank.''.
(5) Clause 22, page 11, after proposed subsection 27l (2), insert the following subsection:

`` `(2a) In subsection (2), `rights' includes voting rights, the total rights to distributions of capital or profits of the Commonwealth Bank to its shareholders on winding-up and the total rights to distributions of capital or profits of the Commonwealth Bank to its shareholders otherwise than on winding-up.''.
(6) Clause 22, page 12, proposed subsection 27l (5), lines 4 and 5, omit the subsection, substitute the following subsection:
`` `(5) Any act or transaction in contravention of this section is void.''.

As I have mentioned before, these amendments seek to ensure that the Government's commitment to its own Caucus is kept. The first two amendments seek to ensure that the Secretary to the Department of the Treasury remains a member of the Commonwealth Bank board. The amendment that the Government has moved seeks to give the Treasurer of the day the power to remove the Secretary to the Treasury from that particular provision.

As far as the Australian Democrats are concerned, it is essential to have the Secretary to the Treasury a member of the board. We believe that the Commonwealth Bank has a public policy role as well as a role to provide community services. We believe that the Secretary to the Treasury should be there to ensure that that role is performed. We would be even more pleased if we had representatives on that board who were members of the community, charged with the duty of protecting the interests of consumers. However, with this amendment, we are moving to ensure that the Secretary to the Treasury remains a member of the board but not at the will of the Treasurer.

Amendment No. 3 deals with clause 22 and proposed section 27k. This section seeks to ensure that no shares are issued to foreign interests. There are four clauses which we shall seek to remove by these amendments. In the first instance, proposed subsection (3), as submitted by the Government, seeks to interpose a discretionary trust or similar structure which, in turn, would be able to have up to 40 per cent of foreign interests amongst its shareholders. We believe that that is an open invitation to contravene the commitment that no foreign interests may take up shares in the Commonwealth Bank. Just to make sure, proposed subsection (4) says that exceptions or modifications to the prohibition to have shares held by foreign interests may be made by regulation.

During the Committee sittings, the Minister admitted that there were ambiguities in the legislation. When he was challenged by me to remove those ambiguities by agreeing to the amendments that the Democrats were moving the answer was, `We can fix that by regulations; we do not have to put it into the legislation'. What we have here is an open sesame, carte blanche to the Government to use regulations to ensure that the undertakings the Government, through the Treasurer (Mr Keating), has made to its own Caucus can be overridden. Proposed subsection (10) is another feature of the Government's plan to ensure that these commitments need not be kept. The proceedings for an offence against this proposed section can only be instituted with the consent in writing of the Treasurer.

So we have a position here where the Treasurer is the most likely person to be involved in a contravention of the section. Yet his approval in writing must be available before any proceedings can be taken for an offence against this section. Finally, the Government must have instructed the draftsmen to make absolutely sure that it had a completely free hand in selling shares to foreign interests. Subsection (11) provides:
The issue of shares is not affected by the fact that the application for the issue was made in contravention of this section.
If one takes those four sections together, it is clear that the Government has no intention of keeping its commitment not to issue shares to foreign interests either immediately or later.

While at first I was prepared to give the Treasurer the benefit of the doubt, and suggested that it may have been a drafting mistake and that it left the way open for the Government to make its provisions watertight to ensure that commitments would be met, we now have no choice but to assume that the Government all along wanted to make sure that it did not have to keep its own commitments.

I now turn to amendment No. 4, which deals with clause 22, page 11. It seeks to ensure that by changing the wording the Government in fact will sell no more than 30 per cent of the shares of the Commonwealth Bank.

Amendment No. 5, dealing with clause 22, subsection 27l (2), seeks to remove one other possibility: to weaken the shareholding still held by the Government in the Commonwealth Bank by removing the possibility of issuing shares without voting rights. It might be argued that there is no harm in issuing shares without voting rights because they have no power over decisions made by the board. However, it is clear that even non-voting shares have a financial interest in the level of dividend and in the level of loans taken up. It is also clear that people holding such shares would use their influence to ensure that they can affect the direction of the bank and the decisions made by the board.

Amendment No. 6, dealing with clause 22, page 12, proposed new subsection (5), seeks to ensure that there is a let-out if the Government decides that it does not wish to comply with the requirement not to sell shares beyond 30 per cent. The amendment reads:
``(5) Any act or transaction in contravention of this section is void.

That is simply plain English. We have met with various arguments about these provisions, saying that they need to cater for various issues of shares that may be made in lieu of profit pay-outs or some other issue of shares with or without rights, but it seems to us that in the first instance we are entitled to look at the plain words of a section. If it says, `Any act or transaction in contravention of this section is void', that is plain language. If, however, it says, `Any contravention of this section does not affect the validity of any act or transaction involved in the contravention', it is also clear that such action can be taken, and that the Government hopes to retain the possibility of taking such action.

The Democrats believe the evidence is on the table: the Government was not interested in making this legislation watertight to meet the commitments that it made to its Caucus. We believe we should try to keep the Government honest and at least put these amendments on the table. We do not have much hope that the Government will support them. We know that the Opposition wants to privatise the bank 100 per cent and sell it to foreign interests--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is its ideological bent.

—Indeed-as quickly as possible. The Opposition now knows that it will be able to do so sooner or later, or that this Government will do so. Nevertheless, I believe it is our duty to put these amendments before the Committee, and I trust that some senators at least will vote according to their conscience and support them.

—For the reasons I and my colleagues outlined in the second reading debate and for the reasons I outlined on Senator Spindler's other group of amendments, the coalition will not support these amendments. In our view, they go in the contrary direction to the direction the bank ought to be heading in if it is going to achieve the aspirations of its depositors, its customers and indeed all Australians who want to see a thriving, competitive, dynamic banking industry unshackled by regulation and unshackled by public ownership. For those reasons-I will not go over all the arguments again-we will not support the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Spindler has rightly pointed out, he can look to no support from the Government on these amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Spindler's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.
Amendment (by Senator Button) agreed to:
Clause 12, page 5, proposed subsection 8b (5), definition of ``Treasurer's nominee on Board'', line 29, omit ``8a (2) (a)'', substitute ``8a (1) (a)''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have circulated several amendments on behalf of the Opposition. In fact, there are nine amendments, but the three important ones are amendments (1), (2) and (3). Amendments (4) to (9) are consequential on the carriage of amendments (1), (2) and (3). I give notice to the Committee that I will be pressing a division on each of those three amendments. Perhaps I could speak to the three of them, because they interrelate, and then, to suit the convenience of the Committee, move each of them in turn.
—Why don't you move them all together?

—The Opposition wishes to have a division on each of the three. In the Labor Caucus's resolution of 28 August which related to the Commonwealth Banks Restructuring Bill 1990, with which we are now dealing, and which gave authority for that Bill to proceed, there was included the following decision:

SPEECH.PARA: The caucus unequivocally rejects proposals to remove Government control of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and to privatise the Commonwealth Bank.
It also included the following:
That the Government introduce to the Parliament legislation requiring majority government ownership and control of the Commonwealth Bank in perpetuity.

The Government has abided by this decision. It can be found in clause 22 of the Bill. The proposed new section 27L of the principal Act, the Commonwealth Banks Act, states that the proportion of voting shares to be held in aggregate by persons other than the Commonwealth will be limited to 30 per cent. In addition, the Commonwealth will be prohibited from selling any of its shares in the bank.

It is obvious from the debate earlier this evening that this clause is quite contrary to the policy of the Liberal and National parties of a 100 per cent privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank. It has obviously been put in this legislation to appease the wishes of those in Caucus who consider that, even if, or when, the coalition wins government in the future, we may not gain control of the Senate and therefore would be unable to change the legislation to allow the sale of the remaining 70 per cent.

The future, of course, will test the validity of that argument. I do not accept that argument because there is no doubt that after the next election there is every possibility-probability, I would hope-that the Liberal and National parties will control not only the House of Representatives but also the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —No hope at all.

—Whether it does or whether it does not, I think Senator Powell will be fairly irrelevant because, given the performance that she and her Party have put on in recent days, particularly its disgraceful support of the Government this morning in terms of the guillotine, I think she will be but distant history after the next election.

SPEECH.PARA: For those reasons we have very strong objections to the existing clause 22 and, in particular, to proposed new sections 27k and 27l of the Bill. In my third amendment, we also have an objection to the proposition that foreigners will be prohibited from subscribing to the first public issue of shares in the Commonwealth Bank. We disagree with that proposal. The disallowance of foreigners purchasing shares in the initial sale will more than likely distort the value of shares, keeping them lower, of course, than would be the case if foreigners were permitted access in the initial subscription. It will also open up the potential for staggering gains to original purchasers when they on-sell to a deeper market which does include foreigners.

That just does not make any sense at all to us, because it means that the public purse will be the loser as a result of the restriction imposed on foreign applications in the first instance. It makes no sense at all to say that foreigners will be prohibited in the initial float but that they will be allowed then to acquire shares that are on-sold by those who are lucky enough to get shares out of the initial float. So we are opposed to that proposition. We are also opposed to the section of clause 22 which-again reflecting the Caucus resolution-contains the provision that individual shareholdings in the bank should be limited to 5 per cent. That is reflected in the Bill and, more particularly, in the schedule to clause 62. But I raise it here because I think that it has relevance in this context as well.

The rationale for this proposition is not clear when it is considered that the rules pertaining to other banks under the Banks (Shareholdings) Act 1972 stipulates tests of 10 per cent and 15 per cent. In other words, the existing Banks (Shareholdings) Act 1972 stipulates that ownership by foreign investors of up to 10 per cent is permitted, that in excess of 10 per cent but less than 15 per cent requires approval from the Treasurer unless it is contrary to the national interest, and that ownership in excess of 15 per cent can proceed only as long as the Treasurer is satisfied that it would be in the national interest to do so.

The Government has expressed the view that its motive for having this provision is that only 30 per cent of the bank will be up for sale, so adherence to the Banks (Shareholdings) Act would open the potential for just two or three big institutional purchasers, if the 10 to 15 per cent rules of that Act applied. Whilst I understand that point, because we are opposed to the 30 per cent limitation of private ownership that is the essence of the Bill, we therefore oppose also the clause which is contrary to the Banks (Shareholdings) Act, which applies to all other banks. We believe that the Commonwealth Bank should be no exception.

For those reasons, therefore, I intend to move on behalf of the coalition the amendments that have been circulated in my name. As I said, amendments (4) to (9) are consequential on the amendment in relation to the Banks (Shareholdings) Act. In effect, the coalition will not be pressing a vote on amendments (4) to (9) because, I think, they will in effect fall out from the votes on amendments (1), (2) and (3). I formally move:
1. Clause 22, page 10, proposed heading to Division 3, line 18, omit the heading, substitute the following heading:
``Division 3-Issue etc. of Shares in Commonwealth Bank''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are now witnessing the Opposition complaining that the Government's provisions and amendments are too watertight. What the Opposition would like to do is to make sure that all of the Commonwealth Bank can be sold, and it does not care a tinker's cuss if it is sold to foreigners. If the people's bank falls into foreign hands, that is just fine by the Opposition as long as sufficient money is being paid for it.

SPEECH.PARA: It does not care about the values that the Commonwealth Bank represents. It does not care about the public policy objectives, the community service obligations, or about the fact that currently the bank is owned by every Australian. That does not concern the Opposition one bit. It is impossible to express the disgust that one feels at this position that the Opposition is taking.

Let us face it; on this particular issue we have the Opposition, as well as the Australian Labor Party Government, making common cause. We have seen that here more often than not in the last few weeks, when we have seen the ideology which says that the free should decide what our values are; the free market should decide where this nation is going, what the direction should be, and what the aspirations of Australians should be. That seems to be what is now governing the actions of the Opposition as well as of the Government.

Both parties, I believe, have abdicated their responsibilities for their function, which is to implement the aspirations of the Australian people. I do not believe that the aspirations of the Australian people are the bottom line of the balance sheet. I believe they lie in a combination of concern for the environment, concern for social justice, and a future for our children that is better than we have now. That is the sort of future that we will not get if we simply abdicate our responsibility, sit down, put our hands to our sides and do nothing and leave it all to the market. As long as the Australian Democrats are here, we will be voting against such attempts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to enter into a lengthy debate with Senator Spindler at this stage of the night, but I cannot let him get away with the misrepresentation that he has just made of the Opposition's position. He said that the Opposition would happily let the Commonwealth Bank of Australia fall into the hands of foreign ownership and control, or the hands of foreigners. That is quite patently not the Opposition's position. The Opposition's position is that the Commonwealth Bank should be treated in no different a way from the other major banks-the Westpac Banking Corporation, the National Australia Bank Ltd, and the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd-and in relation to foreign shareholdings in those banks, there are very strict provisions applying in the form of the Banks (Shareholdings) Act 1972 that I have just been debating. There is the 10 and 15 per cent rule that Senator Spindler knows as well as I applies and which imposes very rigid restrictions on foreign investment in banks in Australia. It is simply a gross distortion and misrepresentation. I am very surprised that Senator Spindler would attempt to pull that one; to suggest that we are advocating a carte blanche for foreign investment in the Commonwealth Bank.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat: in our view there is no reason why the Commonwealth Bank should be treated any differently from the other major banks in Australia at the moment. Senator Spindler does not agree with that. He is so jingoistic that he does not see any virtue in foreign ownership or foreign investment in Australia at all. If he takes that attitude, then he has a problem, but he should not come in here and try to misrepresent deliberately the position of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened to Senator Spindler on this issue and I have heard him before. I can only hope that was Spindler's last stand on this issue. Senator Short rises in high dudgeon saying that his position has been misrepresented. There have been a lot of misrepresentations going on between the two senators tonight. Let us see what this amendment is about.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Short is right in saying that under his amendment to the relevant foreign takeovers legislation, a foreigner could buy a 10 per cent or 15 per cent share of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, as is the position with private banks. He does not tell us what foreign bank is in the discretion of the Treasurer of the day under the foreign investment legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Peter Reith; the mind boggles!

—It does. Here we have a shadow Treasurer, a hobgoblin of such frightening countenance that, if he were ever in government, he might allow the military bank of Iraq to take a 10 or 15 per cent share in the Commonwealth Bank in a fit of aberration. That is a horrifying thought which Senator Short did not advert to as a possibility, but has to concede-I do not want to be tautologist-as a possibility. No doubt he would deny, in all confidence, the possibility of Mr Reith having a moment of aberration. But the point remains.

SPEECH.PARA: The policy of the Government in respect of the Commonwealth Bank has been spelt out again and again-in the second reading speech, when we dealt with this matter in committee, and so on. The limitations on the sale of shares to the public when the Commonwealth Bank shares are floated are quite clear.
Senator Powell interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —For goodness sake, has the honourable senator been lying awake in bed for years worrying about it, Australian Airlines Ltd or about anything else? I do not think so, and I do not think anybody else has either. Here is the great conscience of suburbia telling us that people are lying awake worrying about the Commonwealth Bank. If I lie awake at night it is because I am worried about a lot of other banks.
—Well, you should.

—Yes, but I do not worry about the Commonwealth Bank. The policy of the legislation is quite clear. The Australian people, through various institutions, will get first rights to buy shares in the Commonwealth Bank. I do not want to follow the Australian Democrats down to the shed at the bottom of the garden, which is something nasty in their imaginings, but the fact of the matter is that Australian institutions will get first go at a share in the Commonwealth Bank. Subsequently, as Senator Short knows perfectly well, under the scheme of this Act those institutions will be able to sell their 5 per cent parcels to foreigners if they wish. The total privatised share of the Commonwealth Bank will be 30 per cent.
—You are not fooling anybody.

—I am not trying to fool anybody-that is the problem that Senator Powell has difficulty with-but I suspect that Senator Powell is. What worries me most is that I think she is trying to fool herself and her three colleagues.
—Three? Four.
—One must have slumped under the table. From here I cannot see them.
—He has got two heads.
—Yes, he has got two heads, I agree-Senator Bell from Tasmania.
—Now, now.

—His Leader said that, not me. `He has got two heads', she said. So the scheme of the Act is quite clear. Foreigners will be prohibited from prescribing to the initial sale, as Senator Short says. Subsequently, they will be able to subscribe to the sale. This bank is--

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Powell interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I think perhaps Senator Powell does not understand the policy of the legislation-it is to sell 30 per cent of the Commonwealth Bank so that it will become a bigger bank. The Commonwealth has only 8 per cent of retail banking in the State of Victoria and will get a substantial extra slice of the retail banking business. The Commonwealth Bank will be a much stronger bank as a result of this transaction. None of those naughty private shareholders will influence the capacity of the bank to comply with its charter which is in the legislation now and will remain in the legislation. None of those naughty foreigners, the bogeyman in the Democrats' shed at the bottom of the garden, will be able to influence the policy of a great Australian institution. That is why the legislation is couched this way.

SPEECH.PARA: If this lot opposite got into power, we might have a different situation. Looking at the last few years, who could say with confidence that we want a great institution like the Commonwealth Bank to behave like Elders-IXL or some of the private sector banks have done? Who in their right mind would want to say that? Who in their right mind would go out on a stump and tell the people of Australia that is what they intend to do? We will see about that in the next year or so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hawkie's mate Bondy?

—I did not mention Bond; I had John Elliott in mind. He is one entrepreneur in this country who wrecked a great company. All that time he was President of the Liberal Party. The man I had in mind was the Liberal Party President who destroyed a great Australian company-Elders. If those opposite want to interject and walk into the kitchen, they will get a bit of the heat, but they will learn after they have been here for a little bit longer. This amendment is not acceptable to the Government for reasons which we have gone through again and again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I heard Senator Button say that he was attempting to avoid tautology. I do not know whether it is an oxymoron, an onomatopoeia or just a failed attempt to fool the people. It is nonsense to suggest that the public bank will be sold to the public. I struggle to find any sense in that.

SPEECH.PARA: I am further confused by the contribution of Senator Short. He expressed frustration that the Government's 30 per cent privatisation would not allow the full privatisation envisaged by the coalition parties if ever they achieved government. He then accused the Government's proposal of 30 per cent privatisation of being insufficient and an attempt to frustrate full privatisation. These things did not make any sense at all. One is a nonsense and the other one is a confusion about what the Government is trying to do. I cannot see any sense in sitting around listening to any more of it.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Short's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

(2) ``Clause 22, pages 10 and 11, omit proposed section 27k, substitute the following section:
Shares in the Commonwealth Bank to foreign persons to be issued in accordance with Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act 1975.

``27k (1) An application from a foreign person (whether as principal or agent) to the Commonwealth Bank, or to any agent or underwriter, for the issue of shares in the Commonwealth Bank, shall be treated in accordance with the provisions of the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act 1975.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXPORT MARKET DEVELOPMENT GRANTS AMENDMENT BILL (No.2) 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 November, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on the second reading of the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990, I would point out that, as the Bill is subject to the guillotine, there has been an agreement between ourselves, the Australian Democrats and the Government to limit our speeches to 10 minutes for Senator Button, myself and Senator Spindler and five minutes for Senator Panizza in order that we may deal with the Bill in the 55 minutes allotted.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important to note that this Bill, which has been called urgent, grew from the report of Professor Helen Hughes and that, indeed, the Government had that report for 15 months before any legislation came forward. It is interesting that in May this year the Government introduced a Bill to extend the export market development grants (EMDG) scheme, as it then was, temporarily-or so it said-for five years. When the Opposition took singular exception to the concept of a five-year extension to the scheme, the Government agreed that it would be extended only until December 1990. But the Bill that is before us will be retrospective in effect to 1 July 1990.

It is interesting to look at the history of the export market development grants scheme which was set up some 15 years ago. There have been five reviews of the scheme which have finally resulted in the situation we are presently in. Firstly, there was the report of the national export marketing strategy panel in 1985; secondly, in 1987 there was the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, which dealt with the submissions from Austrade following an audit report; thirdly, in 1988 there was the Bureau of Industry Economics report; fourthly, there was a Price Waterhouse-commissioned assessment by Austrade and, finally, there was the report of the Hughes Committee for the Review of Export Market Development Assistance. Prior to the 1987 Federal election, the Government led industry to believe that there would be no tampering with the scheme at all. Indeed, in June 1987 the then Minister for Trade, Mr John Dawkins, said:

I have written to all recipients of EMDGs, that is the export market development grants scheme, assuring them that the Hawke Government regards the scheme as an integral part of Australia's export effort . . .
He went on to say:
I have also assured them that we will not undermine that effort by chipping away at the spearhead of Australia's export drive . . .

It did not take long for that promise to be broken because by May 1988 the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), having given an assurance as well in 1987, had broken that promise and the changes were announced.

The changes that occurred in 1988 were: exports to New Zealand were excluded from the scheme; an increase was made to the eligible expenditure threshold from $5,000 to $10,000 a year; the maximum grant payable was reduced to $150,000 and to $100,000 for those in receipt of a tenth or subsequent grant; and it was decided to treat affiliated companies as one unit in the assessment of the grants.

Estimates committees, over a period of time, have found that estimates have always been inaccurate and that little research has been carried out on the likely effect on exporters from the changes to the scheme. No answers could be provided to questions on what percentage of grantees would be likely to be first year applicants, nor to the fundamental question of how many applicants would be exporters without the EMDG scheme. Surely those are fundamental questions.

Of course, the final spectacle-one that I do not think any of us will ever forget-occurred during the last election. That, of course, was the sight of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, huddled together with a group of journalists and television cameras, struggling to work out what the figures were and doing his sums on the back of an envelope. It was an occasion on which the Minister managed to alter his position no fewer than four separate times.

To say that we have a piece of legislation which we had to consider urgent because somehow the Government, in the 15 months that it had the Helen Hughes report in its possession, was unable to come up with any legislation to implement that scheme, I think just highlights the points that were made during the debate earlier today when we simply said that the reason that the guillotine is being applied and that we have 55 minutes in which to debate this Bill-bearing in mind that in the House of Representatives honourable members had only 40 minutes and were denied a committee stage and, accordingly, were unable to move any of their Committee of the Whole amendments-is that there has been simple mismanagement by the Government of its business.

In fact, at the committee stage we will be moving two amendments which will be circulated in the course of the second reading debate. We will be moving amendments to effect a change which will result in small business people who are applying to the scheme for the first time being able to combine eligible expenditure which occurs in years one and two, if they see fit. This will give them the same advantage as occurs for people who are in the scheme in subsequent years to combine two years of expenditure.

Indeed, it is quite interesting that I was informed that during the briefing given to the staff of our shadow Minister in this area, it was the understanding of the Government that this was provided for in clause 16a of the Bill. In fact, upon it being explained to it that it was not, I suspect that these amendments may be acceptable.

I would like to make one other point in regard to those amendments. A drafting error appears on page 33 of the Bill, where a colon is in the wrong position and the words `the claimant' should be in a different position. Should the Government choose not to move an amendment to clear up that drafting error, I have amendments drafted that could, if necessary, take care of the problem.

The Government, in dealing with EMDGs, simply did not follow all the recommendations of the Hughes report. The Opposition's proposed amendments were recommended by the Hughes report. The question of the threshold and the Government's requirement that the first $15,000-worth of expenditure in any one year is not reimbursable were also deviations from the report.

Overall, one can only say that the sorry plight of our export industry is compounded by the fact that the law in this area has remained uncertain. I repeat the history very quickly: the Government really forgot about the scheme and dealing with an extension of it properly. Although the Government had the report for some 15 months, it attempted, as I said, to introduce a temporary extension of five years but, after our rather loud cries of protest, agreed to make it temporary only to the end of this calendar year and then to introduce fresh legislation which would be retrospective to 1 July 1990. That is the situation we are now in-debating a Bill with some degree of urgency, according to the Government, but which we contend has simply been done because the Government has mismanaged the preparation of legislation, its drafting and its presentation into both chambers. That has resulted in the spectacle of this complicated area of law having in total only 95 minutes of debate between the two Houses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate tonight is discussing the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990, which is to amend the Export Market Development Grants Act 1974 on the basis, mainly, of recommendations from the Hughes Committee for the Review of Export Market Development Assistance.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed amendments were announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Senator Button in February this year in rather unusual and embarrassing circumstances. The amendments are made retrospective by the Bill to 1 July 1990 in accordance with the then announced commencement date. Earlier this year, the existing scheme was extended until the end of 1990. The Government said that this was to enable consultation with exporters in relation to the proposed changes. Despite these discussions, it appears from the legislation that the original recommendations remain substantially unchanged. It is obvious from the representations my office has received that a large number of exporters are not happy with the legislation, but the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) does not appear to see merit in their views. One reason for that might be that the Bill is also intended to be a cost-cutting measure, saving some $30m in the first year.

The proposed revised scheme follows the main recommendations of the Hughes report to alter the targeting arrangements and to focus more on new exporters demonstrating a substantial commitment to export development. The Bill follows the recommendations of the Hughes Committee except for a few points. The main provisions of the Bill increase the minimum expenditure threshold from $10,000 to $30,000, with the first $15,000 being ineligible for a grant. This is the main provision to which the Australian Democrats are opposed. We believe that it is false economy to lift the thresholds, thereby depriving small exporters of achieving a foothold in the all-important export market.

My main amendment will be directed towards rectifying that by tapering that proposal of the Government. We believe that single firm exporters should remain at the threshold level of $10,000, but where consortia can be formed-and this is part of the provisions that we welcome in this amendment Bill-we believe the threshold should be $20,000. We welcome the various amendments in this Bill which target the funds better than was the case before; for instance, allowing firms to claim a nominal $200 per day as eligible expenditure for a maximum of 21 days for overseas visits in lieu of the openended expenditure on hotels, meals and entertainment which in some cases has been rorted. We believe it is a positive measure to increase the maximum payment from $200,000 to $250,000 and to extend the cut-off limit from $20m to $25m of export earnings.

We also do not see a great many negative results in the measure to cut the rate of grant from 70 per cent to 50 per cent of eligible expenditure. We believe that indicates a true partnership between Government and the exporter. We believe that, if exporters mean what they say and are intent on expanding their export markets, they should be prepared to carry 50 per cent of the cost.

The maximum of eight incentive payments-in other words, incentive payments over eight years-has been criticised by some exporters, but we will not oppose it strenuously, believing that eight years is a long enough time span for a company to develop its export trade, bearing in mind that it then has the possibility to enter the international trade enhancement scheme at the discretion of the Government.

The Bill contains a mixture of measures. While we believe it contains some positive ones, we are strongly opposed to the increase in the minimum expenditure threshold, which would keep some 350 companies currently eligible for the scheme out of it. The cost saving in that is not great, and we believe that the Government in this case is saving at the wrong end.

Although these facts were put clearly before the Opposition, it has refused to support my proposed amendments. I believe that is a very strange decision, particularly as Opposition members claim at every opportunity to support small business and profess concern for our poor export performance. The small business community will be disadvantaged by their lack of concern in this area. Indeed, a similar situation arose last year when the Opposition refused to support former Senator Haines's amendment to exempt most small businesses from the accelerated payment of company tax, which is currently causing problems in the community and which will really bite next July. Opposition senators should reflect on this and not maintain their opposition to my proposals.

The scheme is supposed to be directed at the small to medium sized exporter. It seems that most of the amendments contained in this Bill will actually work against the small importer to some extent. In order to access the scheme, they will have to increase their levels of eligible expenditure or they will be forced to join consortia, approved trading houses or approved joint ventures. We believe the formation of consortia and joint ventures is not necessarily a negative trend, but it may disadvantage small companies that work in a geographical area where they find it difficult to access such consortia.

Under this scheme grants are paid in respect of the prior year's expenditure. Payments under the new scheme will not commence until 1991-92, when it is expected that claims of around $134m will become payable.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXPORT MARKET DEVELOPMENT GRANTS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1990

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is estimated that the amendment to the scheme will save $31m in the 1991-92 financial year and $44m in the 1992-93 financial year. It must be asked why the Government is proposing to save money in respect of an export incentive scheme when the current account is and has been in crisis for years. The savings take into account the cost of the new discretionary scheme, the international trade enhancement scheme, of $31.3m for both the 1991-92 and 1992-93 financial years. The trade enhancement scheme is due to run for four years from 1 July 1990 and will be administered by Austrade. I hope that the scheme is a success and proves the worth of Government intervention to improve trade performance.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill also proposes to widen substantially the export market development grants scheme to include legal, health and other services to inbound tourist operators. We have no problems with this, although we are wary of institutions in the search for export dollars neglecting to provide these services to residents. Such concern is not limited to this scheme but relates to the general question of the export of health services.

Senator Bishop has referred to the amendment that she will be moving at the committee stage of the debate. The Australian Democrats will be supporting her amendment but we clearly see this as a bandaid measure and very much as a second best option. Indeed, one must say that, while the amendment will extend eligibility because it allows the entitlements to be added up over two years, it does not do the same for the actual grants to be paid and the high grant excess levels will remain. Thus, the actual payout to exporters will be very measly indeed under this amendment. We will be monitoring closely the operation of the Bill during the coming year. I foreshadow that in 12 months time it may be necessary to have another look at the legislation.

The question of government action in the field of trade is a complex and exceedingly political one. The horrendous debacle of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade discussions underlines the complexities and difficulties associated with world trade. We must not pursue the naive free trade direction of the 1980s in a unilateral fashion. Such schemes as the one we are dealing with tonight must be massively expanded unless the Europeans and Americans start to level the world playing field in their favour-and I am using the term `level' ironically.

I wait with great anticipation for Senator Button's forthcoming industry policy statement. I hope that sufficient attention will be paid in that statement to the massive growth industries of the 1990s, such as solar and other alternative energy technologies, waste management technologies and other environmentally friendly industries. As time does not permit me to extend this debate to a full discussion of the issues involved, I will conclude my remarks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak very briefly this evening because debating time is limited. I join in the debate because of the representations I have received from some of Western Australia's more remote coastal areas which do not have quite the same advantages of city-based areas.
—Geraldton?

—Yes. Geraldton, Carnarvon, Bunbury, Albany and some areas in South Australia are in the same position. The Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990 is another piece of legislation by press release. As has already been pointed out this evening, the legislation was announced on the run by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Senator Button on 28 February during the election campaign.

SPEECH.PARA: A lot of problems have been created for companies because the announcement was made so far ahead and because amendments to the Act will be made retrospective to 1 July. Companies will need to work within the existing law. They will have to keep an eye on what the new law may be, be aware of the implications of original media release and then monitor any adjustments. The legislation puts them in quite a pickle-especially the smaller companies.

The Bill seems to punish success rather than reward it. The number of grants are to be limited to eight. The reality is that exporters have to compete every year. I know that they should be getting stronger every year so that they are able to continue to compete but, unfortunately, with the state of the economy at the moment, that is hard to do. The need to compete does not stop after eight grants have been allocated. Exporters have to continue to defend, to expand and to diversify their exports and markets. The limit of eight is seen as another blow to small businesses.

In some cases exporters who have developed a market have lost their grants. This allows someone else to come in and capitalise on work that they have already done. The Bill will remove assistance from the initiator and assist a new Australian competitor. I believe that it is false economy to argue that the Act should apply only to newcomers. The Government seems slightly reluctant to acknowledge that a successful exporter may continue to require assistance in remote areas, such as the ones which I have already spoken about, because of certain logistic problems.

The second reading speech of the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) indicates that there was wide consultation with the industry, but what was said does not seem to have quite measured up. That view has been expressed to the Opposition and, no doubt, the Government. I believe that this development scheme is based on too narrow a perspective. We should have a wider look at other basic objectives, such as labour costs, work practices, waterfront inefficiencies and tax system problems. We know what problems there are with the tax system, especially with the new system under which, as I said the other day, two years of tax will have to be paid in seven months. Excessive regulations need to be addressed.

There is the continuing problem of inequitable tariffs around the world. I think everybody has probably heard about this and the lobbying that has occurred. For example, Australia has a 15 per cent basic tariff; developing countries, 10 per cent; Indonesia, 40 per cent; Thailand, 80 per cent; and Korea, 100 per cent. We cannot compete with that. It is critical that we take a much broader perspective and encourage our own manufacturers. I am especially interested in manufacturers who are based in remote areas. I believe that, because the Government has not done enough, we will be looking at this Bill again in 12 months time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contribution to the debate on the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill (No. 2). Senator Panizza says that the Opposition will be looking at it in 12 months time. I hope that the Opposition does not look at it as hard as it did during the election before last when it pledged to abolish the export market development grants scheme altogether. That was party policy. If it looks at it again, I hope it does so a bit more seriously than that.

SPEECH.PARA: I will refer briefly to the scheme of the Bill. Before doing that, however, I refer to Senator Bishop's allegation that there have been a number of delays in this, and there have been. This Bill was introduced on 14 November in the House of Representatives and the Liberal Party amendments were distributed three minutes ago. It is not everybody who can talk about delays with a great degree of confidence.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a load of old nonsense because discussions have been going on for some time, including with your office.

—Senator Bishop says that is a load of old nonsense. She would be a good judge of that sort of thing. What I said was that the amendments were distributed three minutes ago, and that is right. It is no good rattling on at me; one has to consider the Senate. My point simply is that, whether those opposite like it or not, this legislation was introduced into the House of Representatives on 14 November and it has taken the Opposition all this time to prepare these scrappy little amendments. Do not point fingers at other people; that is all I am saying.
—Wrong.

—Not wrong; right. As far as the legislation itself is concerned, other senators have referred to the various inquiries into the scheme which have gone on for some time. This is a response to the committee of inquiry chaired by Professor Hughes. That committee of inquiry recommended the eight-year cut-off point. This is not intended to be a subsidy forever for importers. It is not an export subsidy; it is an export market development grant scheme. That is to say, it covers expenses and costs associated with the setting up of an export market. It is not an export subsidy. I think honourable senators should be clear about that.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as the threshold is concerned, the view of most small businesses is that we have to spend this sort of money in this sort of legislation if we are going to establish an export market. One cannot really do it for less. The Hughes Committee for the Review of Export Market Development Assistance recommended that certain trading houses or consortia of small businesses should be eligible under the international trade enhancement scheme for support in setting up new export markets. It is very difficult and perhaps wrong to encourage a very small firm into an export market on its own without some support from other firms operating in an export cluster or from a trading house or something of that kind. That has been very much the experience over a number of years. That is the essential purpose of the legislation.

The Hughes Committee recommended a cut-off threshold of $50,000. The Government, after hearing representations of the kind that honourable senators have referred to, made it $30,000. I indicate now that I am quite happy to accept Senator Bishop's amendment. We will not divide about that. Her amendment relating to the punctuation or syntax is, I think, a good amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the rest of the amendments?
—I have only two at this stage.
—You have four, actually.

—I do not have four. We will come to the amendments in detail when I have had a chance to have a look at them. A minute ago I had two amendments circulated here. It is an insult to the Senate that amendments should be distributed at this stage when the Opposition has had since 14 November to consider them. That is perhaps a reflection on the diligence of the Opposition. The amendment I was referring to which I said was acceptable is the one which is described as-
—Amendments (3) and (4).

—No, (1) and (2). The other ones, (3) and (4), related to the punctuation, dealing with the expression, `the claimant'. I can indicate now that those amendments will not be disputed by the Government and we will have a look at the other ones. I commend the legislation to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 8-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 9, page 33, proposed paragraph 14 (1) (b), lines 19 and 20, omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraphs::
``(b) where the claimant is not an approved consortium or an approved joint venture, the amount of the claimant's eligible expenditure for the grant year is $10,000 or more; or
(c) where the claimant is an approved consortium or an approved joint venture, the amount of the claimant's eligible expenditure for the grant year is $20,000 or more.''.
(2) Clause 10, pages 35 and 36, proposed subsection 16 (3), line 38 (page 35) to line 2 (page 36), omit the subsection, substitute the following subsection:
``(3) (a) Where a claimant is an approved consortium or an approved joint venture, a claimant's provisional grant amount is the amount worked out using the formula:
(eligible expenditure-$15,000)/2
(b) Where a claimant is not an approved consortium or an approved joint venture, a claimant's provisional grant amount is the amount worked out using the formula:
(eligible expenditure-$10,000)/2
(3) Clause 10, pages 37 to 39, proposed section 16a, line 19 (page 37) to line 15 (page 39), omit the section.

These amendments were circulated some two or three hours ago. As I indicated in the second reading debate, the amendments seek to retain the $10,000 threshold for single traders and to introduce a $20,000 threshold in contrast to the Government's $30,000 threshold, where single traders are able to combine into consortia or joint ventures. Subsequently, we also wish to amend the eligible expenditure levels to $10,000 and $15,000 respectively.

The purpose of these amendments, as I have said previously, is to make sure that small traders are given a go in developing their export markets. We are all very concerned to say nice words about small business, and in fact it employs some 80 per cent of our work force. The Democrats believe that we should give small business the opportunity to develop the export potential which undoubtedly they have, and we think it is wrong of the Government to try to put barriers in their way.

I believe that the Government should seriously consider these amendments. I do not believe that a large amount of money is involved. As Australia is struggling to improve its balance of payments and to improve employment in export industries, I believe that this is a measure that the Government should consider.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not be supporting the Australian Democrats' amendments. As I said earlier, we will be moving our own amendments, which the Government has indicated it will support and the Democrats have indicated they will support. The reason the Opposition does not support the amendments is that it does not support the maintenance of the current threshold.

SPEECH.PARA: The Hughes Committee for the Review of Export Market Development Assistance found that success in exporting is considerably enhanced if firms are willing to expend a reasonable amount of money. Professor Hughes found that currently less than 50 per cent of firms accessing export market development grant schemes survived to year three when the performance test cut in. It is also interesting to note that approximately 50 per cent of year one to year eight firms currently in the scheme incur less than $50,000 in eligible expenditure. The Opposition's amendment, rather than the Democrats', achieves the appropriate balance of supporting small business on the one hand and on the other encouraging firms to spend realistic amounts on export promotion to enhance their prospects of success.

On the question of how much notice of this Bill was given, as I said in my second reading speech, when the Bill was introduced into the lower House only 40 minutes were made available for the debate of that Bill and no committee stage was allowed to proceed, so no amendments were able to be moved in the House of Representatives. The delay in circulating the amendments as I have proposed them was because amendments (3) and (4) as have been circulated by me as distinct from (1) and (2) were errors in drafting and properly were the responsibility of the Government. I note that Minister Button was not in the House when I made my speech in the second reading debate so would not have heard this.

As I had the amendments drafted, I offered to circulate them in my name. The circulation of the amendments was held up because I was waiting for confirmation from the Minister's office, with which I had consultations; indeed, I have had consultations with the Democrats since 14 November, so our position was well known. I am pleased that the Government has seen that our amendments fairly and equitably improve the legislation. It has seen fit to make a similar judgment about the Democrats' amendment not being in line with the recommendations of the Hughes report.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Clause 9, page 33, after proposed paragraph 14 (1) (b), insert the following word and paragraph:

``; or (c) in respect of a claimant in his or her first grant year after the commencement of this section and who elects in writing that this paragraph apply, the sum of the amount of the claimant's eligible expenditure for that grant year and for the year immediately preceding that grant year is $30,000 or more.''.
2. Clause 10, page 36, after proposed subsection 16 (3), insert the following subsection:
``(3a) Where paragraph 14 (1) (c) applies to a claimant in his or her first year grant, the formula for calculating the provisional grant income for that year is:
(Eligible Expenditure-$30,000)/2
3. Clause 9, page 33, proposed subsection 14 (1), line 17, omit ``the claimant''.
4. Clause 9, page 33, proposed paragraph 14 (1) (a), line 18, before ``has incurred'', insert ``the claimant''.

I draw the attention of the Committee to the fact that the effect of amendments Nos 1 and 2-the substantive amendments-is to allow a first entrant into the export market development grants scheme to combine two years of eligible expenditure to meet the $30,000 threshold. At the same time we are amending the formula set out in clause 10 of the Export Market Development Grants Amendment (No. 2) Bill to subtract two years at $15,000 per year so that a new entrant would not be advantaged unfairly as opposed to other participants in the scheme.

If it were compulsory to combine those two years it would be possible to disadvantage a claimant who wished to rely only upon the expenditure in the second year, so under the amendment it is necessary for the claimant to elect in writing to combine the two years to protect his or her position. It is important to apply the $15,000 limit to both years and that is the reason for the amendment in addition to the one set out in the Bill, so that there would not be an unfair advantage given to someone who chose to combine those two years.

These amendments offer small business people an opportunity which they were previously denied. We are delighted that both the Government and the Opposition have seen the wisdom of the argument and support the amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is pleasing to hear Senator Bishop acknowledge the Australian Democrats as the true Opposition in this chamber. The Australian Democrats support Senator Bishop's amendment. We do find them slightly niggardly in that although they provide an improvement in the threshold for small exporters, the actual entitlement to the payments to be made is still left at the high level. Even though we support the amendments, it is a matter that we will take up next year.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

— It is not pedantic.
