SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in the adjournment debate on an issue that affects all Australians-their standard of living. It has become and continues to be a matter of debate because it is one of the justifications that Senator Cook and his colleagues put forward to justify their so-called accord with the union movement.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook also used to talk about the value of the accord in promoting job growth. It has to be said that in recent days Senator Cook has shown a disinclination to use that particular argument. While Senator Cook and Mr Keating were publicly running the line that the accord equals job growth, apparently privately Senator Cook, Paul Keating and probably Senator Button and other senior colleagues decided that what this country needed was an engineered recession.

As any grade 1 economist knows, an engineered recession results not in job growth but in job losses. The figures released today show that unemployment is rising at frighteningly high rates, and it was interesting that Senator Button was very careful to avoid indicating today just how high unemployment might rise in the engineered recession that, in Paul Keating's words, we had to have. It is worth reflecting on the point that probably no other government in Australia's history has actually felt proud that a recession has hit the economy during its term in office. Certainly no other government that I am aware of has regarded it as a badge of honour.

To my mind, it is astonishing that this Government is prepared to trot out the phrase `an engineered recession', which leads us to ask, quite reasonably: if it is engineered, how well engineered is it? Therefore, we would be entitled to know-and, indeed, the public would be entitled to know-what the consequences are, including the consequences for unemployment and dole queues. But when we pressed the Government on those matters today, no answers regrettably were forthcoming.

The other leg that Senator Cook has used to justify the accord is that household disposable income has risen, the implication being that workers and other employees are better off. Senator Cook has conceded a number of times in this place that wage rates under the accord have fallen. In the last two months Senator Cook has answered some 10 questions or so which have looked at the issue of workers' remuneration. Senator Cook tells union members, `Don't worry, you are better off despite falling wage rates; household disposable income has increased'.

I naturally felt that these claims by Senator Cook needed further analysis so that we could ascertain whether union members were in fact better off under the accord. After all, I think that even the Minister at the table, Senator Robert Ray, will admit that with the Labor Government's record on broken promises, which seems to grow longer day by day, it is reasonable to check carefully the statements by senior Ministers. However, let me state at the outset that Senator Cook is correct: wage rates have fallen during the term of the Labor Government. Household disposable income, according to statistics prepared by the Department of the Parliamentary Library, has in fact risen by contrast. This is not a bad start for Senator Cook in a period when credibility of Labor Ministers is highly suspect.

I now turn to the issue of household disposable income on which Senator Cook rests his case to prove the value of the accord to trade union members. Household disposable income is in fact a summary of all incomes received by households. As well as wages and salaries-the typical remuneration of union members-it also includes income of small businesses and farmers. One would have to say that these people are not typically trade union members. Farm income, for example, has grown very rapidly during the period of the Hawke Government, in part because the 1982-83 period was a very low base, reflecting the worst drought for 50 years. It is possible that farm income during 1990-91 could show some very poor trends indeed.

I repeat that household disposable income, which is the statistic which Senator Cook regularly throws about this chamber to justify the accord, also includes the income of higher paid groups in the community-senior managers and corporate directors. These are the two groups that Senator Cook likes to castigate regularly for their rapid increases in income. Household income as calculated by the Commonwealth Statistician includes large sums for rental income, interest and dividends.

The superannuation component of household disposable income has also increased rapidly. This is not money in the pocket to the average union member, because it goes directly towards the superannuation fund. It is therefore not really disposable income in the sense that workers can use the money to help pay mortgages, school expenses and so on. Household disposable income also includes social security benefits and pensions.

In summary, roughly over 40 per cent of household disposable income does not derive from wages and salaries-the main source of income for trade union members. If it were possible to exclude the higher paid groups, the wages and salaries components of people who are typically union members would possibly be less than 50 per cent of the household disposable income that Senator Cook quotes.

The wages, salaries and supplement section of the household disposable income has also been affected by the very sharp rise in female participation rates in the work force. For example, in 1982-83, female participation rates were around 42 per cent. Today, it is around 52 per cent-a very significant rise over eight years. In some cases this increase in participation reflects demographic factors; in other cases it reflects the priorities of women who wish to enter the work force. I suspect that Senator Cook would not argue that it would also reflect the need for married women to supplement household income in a period of record mortgage interest rates and falling real wages of husbands. In these cases it is possible that many of the women may not see it as a benefit to be forced into the work force in order to ensure a reasonable living standard for their families. Nonetheless, the fact that these, can we say, unwilling workers have been required to enter the work force also, in a paradoxical sense, helps boost household disposable income. In fact, this large boost of 10 per cent of families where wives have entered the work force hides declining incomes among the other 90 per cent.

To summarise, for all these reasons, household disposable income is not a complete and satisfactory measure to indicate how trade union members have fared under the accord. We must ask ourselves: is there a better measure to test the benefits or otherwise of the accord to the average worker? I think a better measure is average weekly earnings, because average weekly earnings are based on survey examples of all employees in the country. Unlike household disposable income-the statistic that Senator Cook uses-they are not distorted by incomes which do not typically affect the average income available to many trade union members, such as dividends and business and farm income. Average weekly earnings are not perfect. Nevertheless, they are a better indicator of the likely trend of incomes of trade union members than household disposable income.

The figures which are available for average weekly earnings since the advent of the Hawke Government show that there has been a very dramatic fall in after tax annual earnings. In 1982-83, average male weekly earnings after tax totalled-and these are in real dollars-$475 per week. Today-eight years after the original accord; eight years after all the promises of improvements in living standards to Australian workers; eight years of a Labor Government whose main interest one would have thought would have been the welfare of Australian workers-the comparative figure has fallen by $23 per week after tax. That latest figure is based on Budget forecasts.

If we convert those figures into annual totals, in 1982-83 the after tax income of a person on average weekly earnings has fallen from $24,800 to $23,580-a fall of $1,220. That is eight years after the advent of the Hawke Government; eight years after the accord; and eight years after all those promises that Mr Hawke and his colleagues made to trade union members. This is a huge fall in earnings available to the average member of the work force.

There will always be a debate about statistics. I suggest that if Senator Cook, Mr Kelty and Senator Robert Ray, sitting at the table, wanted an indicator which was more likely to represent the trend in trade union member incomes-incomes which they, above all, should be most concerned about-they would be better advised to use the average weekly earnings statistics than the household disposable income statistics.

Clearly, at the end of the day, trade union members will make their own judgment on this issue. They will make a judgment as to whether I am correct in suggesting that their living standards have fallen, or whether Senator Cook is correct in saying that their standards have risen. I suspect that if any happen to be listening tonight they can ask themselves this question: am I better off after eight years of the Hawke Government? Perhaps a leading indicator that workers themselves feel worse off is that Labor Party support is collapsing amongst blue collar workers. It is not surprising that more blue collar workers support Dr John Hewson's Liberal Party than the Hawke-Keating Labor Party.

I suggest that Labor Party members, before asking Senator Cook dorothy dixers on living standards, which they do tirelessly almost daily, satisfy themselves that they are being given appropriate statistics. After all, their future depends on whether workers' living standards are rising or falling. In my view, they should look very closely at these statistics before they stand up and give Senator Cook a chance to cite figures which, I think, are highly suspect to the extent that they seek to represent how trade union members have fared under the accord. In my view, living standards have collapsed under the accord. I sustain that view by pointing to trends in average weekly earnings.

Senator Cook has a slight fall-back position. In fact, when one reads his answers one finds he talks not only about household disposable income but also about the social wage. People in the 1960s and 1970s used to talk about the social wage. I sometimes regard it as an approach which does not meet realities. The social wage is paid for by taxes. With the tax rates under the Labor Government, trade union members make a mighty contribution towards the social services that they receive. There is no doubt that the accord has failed to protect employment, as it has failed to protect workers' incomes.

I conclude by saying that this is a debate which we would like to have. When Senator Cook gets up in this chamber in Question Time and makes these claims he should be very careful in outlining what he believes to be statistics which represent the reality and feelings of the average worker. In my belief, the accord has been a disaster for Australia. It has been a disaster for workers' living standards; it has been a disaster for employment, and it is one of the major reasons that the Labor Government-Senator Robert Ray and his colleagues-will be changing sides in this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I shall be ever so brief. I want to raise tonight the matter of drugs in sport. I commence by seeking leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter dated 12 December written by me to Mr Jim Ferguson, Executive Director of the Australian Sports Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
PARLIAMENT OF AUSTRALIA-THE SENATE

TALK.START.PARA: —BROWNE

SPEECH.PARA: SENATOR FOR WESTERN AUSTRALIA
COMMONWEALTH PARLIAMENT OFFICES
ST MARTIN'S TOWER
44 ST GEORGE'S TERRACE
PERTH WA 6000
12 December 1990
Mr Jim Ferguson
Executive Director
Australian Sports Commission
PO Box 176
BELCONNEN ACT 2616
Dear Mr Ferguson

You will recall the urine substitution incident which took place in Belfast on June 30, 1986 involving Miss Jane Flemming and Mr Maurice Plant, then Assistant Manager for the Australian Track and Field Team.

You will recall that this matter has attracted considerable publicity since it was referred to the Interim Report of the Senate Standing Committee on the Environment Recreation and the Arts and subsequently in a Second Report of that Committee.

You will also recall Miss Flemming on a number of occasions publicly claiming to have appeared before the Committee voluntarily and that particular claim was referred to by the Australian Sports Commission when responding to the Inquiry's findings in providing the then Minister, Senator Richardson, with a Report to be tabled in the Senate.

You will be aware of course from having read Miss Flemming's submission to the Committee that there was no reference to the urine substitution incident and in fact as Miss Flemming said in her public evidence on 13 February 1989, and I quote, ``I am basically here to support the Institute of Sport on some of the allegations that have been made against it. I have been at the Institute for four years.'' The Chairman, Senator Black, particularly asked Miss Flemming inter alia, ``Do you have any knowledge . . . of the provision of clean urine samples by athletes for others?'' Miss Flemming responded in the following terms: ``I have heard of that sort of thing going on and I have also heard of people who have been tested and have had a positive result. Not in Australia, but internationally.'' The matter was pressed with no indication from Miss Flemming of her own personal experience until the Chairman subsequently asked, ``Have you ever been asked to provide a clean urine sample for anybody?'' at which point Miss Flemming asked that her evidence be taken in camera, which evidence has subsequently by resolution of the Committee been published and tabled in the Senate.

Miss Flemming in response to a question from myself as to who the official involved was, said, and I quote, ``He was a gentleman by the name of Maurie Plant and he is a friend of mine, too, and so I would not have said anything about this but I know that Merv was going to say something tomorrow.''

Subsequently I asked of Miss Flemming, ``The reason you are telling us is because you know that if you do not, tomorrow . . . '' at which point Miss Flemming interrupted me to respond, and I quote, ``That Merv is going to say something, and I just wanted to be able to tell you what the story was from first hand and let you know.''

The Chairman asked Miss Flemming, and I quote, ``Why did you not want to say it publicly before Merv did?'' Miss Flemming replied, and I quote, ``Because I do not want my name to be even associated with it. I have got contracts with sporting goods companies and things like that, and if they think that I am even slightly related to drugs, then I will lose my contracts.''

I would have thought even with the most vigorous and fertile imagination it would be inconceivable to believe that Miss Flemming appeared before our Committee in a voluntary capacity to provide information in respect to her involvement in the urine substitution incident.
This incident was first brought to light as a result of a letter written by Mr Kemp-then one of Miss Flemming's AIS coaches who, on 19 August, 1986 wrote to the Australian Athletic Union.

The Senate Committee has been advised by the Australian Athletic Union, as it was then known, that on 6 October, 1986 the General Manager of that Union met with Mr Kemp and Miss Flemming at the Australian Institute of Sport. However, Miss Flemming declined to comment on the matter other than to say that she had produced a sample and according to the Union she advised that she would not put anything in writing regarding this matter.

Miss Flemming in her evidence to the Committee advised that in response to her correspondence from the Australian Athletic Union, and I quote, ``I did not know what to do and I decided that I would not write back and I would see what happened and they have never, ever contacted me again about it''.

I asked Miss Flemming, ``Have you heard no more?'' and she responded, and I quote, ``No, I have heard no more.'' Miss Flemming further advised the Senate Committee in her evidence, and I quote, ``But the Australian Athletic Union, in its letter to me, said that if I had any light to shed on this subject I should write back to it. I did not write back to it.''

I asked Miss Flemming, ``Do you have any concern that the Australian Amateur Athletic Union might have a view about it?'', referring of course to the incident, and Miss Flemming responded, and I quote, ``I do not know what it thinks, to tell you the truth. I do not even know whether the same people are still working there that know. I do not know who knows there.''

The Australian Athletic Union's correspondence to the Committee went on to observe that as a consequence of the problems that arose with Miss Flemming not prepared to make a written statement, a mail vote to associations conducted at that time amended the law regarding investigations to read, ``If the person, or club, or association concerned fails to respond to the request for a Statutory Declaration within the specified time, the person, club or association shall be suspended forthwith till such time as the response is received.''

I have bothered to set down the circumstances of Miss Flemming's disclosures of this matter and the subsequent steps which the Australian Athletic Union found it necessary to take because of the clearly wrong information which has been provided to the media, Australian athletes, sporting officials and the Commonwealth Parliament.

I turn now to the part played by Mr Maurie Plant in this incident. To my knowledge the Australian Athletic Union, or more recently Athletics Australia, have never interviewed Mr Plant about his role and involvement in the incident but have relied exclusively for that judgement upon correspondence received by the Senate Committee wherein Mr Plant, while not acknowledging he had made any error by way of his involvement, simply acknowledged that he had committed a potential error of judgement.

Mr Neil King, General Manager of Athletics Australia, has advised the Committee on 27 August of this year that since Mr Plant has indicated that he did not subvert the collection or testing process it is probably reasonable to reclassify this as a potential error of judgement rather than an error of judgement. I find that a quite remarkable conclusion by any measure, not the least one from the General Manager of a publicly funded amateur sporting body.
I still await Athletics Australia's response as to what inquiries they personally made into Mr Plant's involvement in this incident.

In the light of Mr King's view, I propose when dealing with the appropriation of funding for sport in 1991 to establish what criteria and minimum standards of conduct Athletics Australia expects from its officials and office bearers.

My further interest in Mr Plant's present role and association with young Australian athletes travelling overseas has been stimulated by the knowledge that Mr Plant was referred to in a bulletin of the Athletics Association of WA as an Australian athletics promoter and athletics representative on the International Amateur Athletic Federation (IAAF) Athletes' Commission for the Grand Prix Circuit.
I have subsequently been advised by Athletics Australia that Mr Plant is a Member of the IAAF Grand Prix Commission.
On 22 August this year, the Secretary of the Senate Committee wrote on my behalf requesting of Athletics Australia the following information:
1. what is the process by which appointments are made to the Grand Prix Commission by the International Amateur Athletic Federation Council?
2. what extent is Athletics Australia involved? and
3. do appointments bear any relationship to the nationality of the appointee?
The relevant part of the General Manager of Athletics Australia's response was:
1. the IAAF Council decides, from time to time, in its discretion both to establish Commissions and to determine the membership thereof; and
2. Athletics Australia is not involved whatsoever. Consultation is not sought. Further, Australia is not represented on the IAAF Council.

However, on 16 November the IAAF wrote to me stating in clear and unambiguous language that Mr Plant was nominated by the IAAF (and with the approval of Athletics Australia) as a Member of the IAAF Grand Prix Commission.

The General Manager of the IAAF went on to say that, amongst the criteria which are applied in appointing members to the position Mr Plant presently holds, is that of the ability to keep confidences, to be one hundred per cent trustworthy and loyal.

I am quite unable to reconcile the contradiction by the IAAF of the assurance given to me by Mr King of Athletics Australia that Athletics Australia was neither involved, nor consulted, about Mr Plant's appointment.
I am sure you will appreciate the significance of my inquiries and the response by Athletics Australia as to their involvement in the appointment of Mr Plant.

The Secretary of the Senate Committee has further been advised by the General Manager of Athletics Australia in respect to Mr Plant, ``that the IAAF, which is Athletics Australia's governing body, and the British Amateur Athletic Board have both investigated these specific matters and have resolved to continue their professional relationship with Mr Plant.''

Mr David Prince, President of Athletics Australia Inc, in correspondence to myself on 26 October, styling himself as President of the National Sport of Athletics and a Board Member of the Australian Sports Commission and the Australian Olympic Committee, assured me that ``both the IAAF and the British Amateur Athletic Association have concluded that no further investigation is warranted.''

However, I am advised by Mr John B. Holt, General Manager of the International Amateur Athletic Federation, ``that IAAF has not specifically discussed the incident in Belfast. It would not be appropriate for us to do so, as the meeting concerned was not one conducted directly by IAAF. We have been assured by our member federation, Athletics Australia, that there is no breach of IAAF rules, and that they have satisfactorily dealt with the matter in this light.''

Mr Holt went on to say, ``that it should be noted that except in extreme circumstances where there has been a clear breach or flouting of IAAF rules, it is not the practice of the IAAF to intervene in the Federation's management of its affairs.''

These statements are of course again, in total contradiction to the claims made and information provided both to myself and the Senate Committee by both the General Manager and President of Athletics Australia.

The IAAF further advised me, ``We have been assured by our Member Federation, Athletics Australia, that there was no breach of IAAF rules, and that they had satisfactorily dealt with the matter in this light.
``We have again discussed this matter with Neal King, the General Manager of Athletics Australia, and we are satisfied that Athletics Australia carried out a proper investigation.''
I still wait advice as to evidence of any investigation whatsoever by Athletics Australia of Mr Plant's involvement by the simple process of that body even interviewing Mr Plant.

Much seems to have been made in Australia of the fact that neither Mr Plant nor Miss Flemming contravened any sports regulations. However, I draw to your attention the particular words of the code of conduct signed by Miss Flemming as a scholarship holder at the Australian Institute of Sport and refer you also to the criteria of the IAAF in appointing people to the Grand Prix Commission. They include ``the ability to follow closely rules and guidelines relating to the Grand Prix'' and ``the ability to keep confidences, to be one hundred per cent trustworthy and loyal.''

You will of course know that the conduct of Miss Flemming and Mr Plant is now in clear breach of sporting regulations and obviously the fact that those regulations were not in place in 1986 was not due to a belief that such conduct was acceptable or proper, but rather that the appropriate bodies had not conceived that such a process would be undertaken to subvert proper testing of athletes so as to determine whether or not they were competing fairly or by means of cheating.

Clearly the IAAF have relied upon a proper and responsible investigation by Athletics Australia into the conduct of Mr Plant. Mr King and Mr Prince have also both assured myself and the Secretary of the Senate Committee that the British Amateur Athletic Board have investigated the specific matters relating to Mr Plant and concluded that no further investigation is warranted.

The extent of the British Board's inquiries are at this moment unknown to me save for correspondence from the Australian Athletic Union which states that the British Board have written to Athletics Australia following Mr Kemp raising a matter of doping control undertaken at a meeting held in Birmingham some time following the Belfast incident, wherein the British Board stated that on that occasion, ``the identity of the person presented for testing was never in doubt.'' That would appear to be a totally unrelated matter.

The Australian Amateur Athletic Union in the same correspondence advised the Senate Committee that the British Board had categorically stated that the identity of athletes at all testing under their jurisdiction was never in doubt.

Even a casual observer of this incident will at once of course appreciate that it was not the identity of the athletes at the testings which was in question but rather whose urine sample was provided for testing.

In pursuing this matter with the IAAF I asked of them that they provide details of the deliberations of the IAAF with respect to Mr Plant and correspondence which ensued between the IAAF, the Australian Athletics Union (Athletics Australia) and the British Amateur Athletic Board.
I am advised by the IAAF that a study of the Australian file in London reveals that there was no correspondence on this subject among the three bodies mentioned.
The reason for the protracted nature of this matter is at once obvious.
I have written to the President of Athletics Australia Inc, and asked for the reasons for the apparent contradiction in the advice of Athletics Australia and that provided by the IAAF.
Yours sincerely
Noel Crichton-Browne
SENATOR FOR WA

TALK.START.PARA: —I will summarise, in hopefully a succinct and articulate way, this ongoing saga which is now becoming quite painful to all of us, not least to myself. Evidence was taken by the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts in respect of one particular athlete and one particular official-the assistant general manager of the track and field team, Mr Maurice Plant-at the Commonwealth Games when Mr Plant solicited from an Australian athlete a urine sample so as to substitute that for the purpose of cheating.

SPEECH.PARA: I have written this letter seeking a final resolution to the matter. It has been written finally as a result of the fact that the Committee wrote to Athletics Australia asking for certain information. It was written ultimately because it was brought to my attention that Mr Plant is a member of the Grand Prix Commission, appointed by the International Amateur Athletics Federation (IAAF) Council. I wrote to Athletics Australia asking how he became a member of that Commission. The General Manager of Athletics Australia assured me that:
. . . the IAAF Council decides, from time to time, in its discretion both to establish Commissions and to determine the membership thereof . . .
He went on to say:
Athletics Australia is not involved whatsoever. Consultation is not sought. Further, Australia is not represented on the IAAF Council.

This is correspondence which, in substance, is supported by the General Manager of Athletics Australia and the Chairman, who is a member of the Australian Sports Commission. The IAAF wrote back, after I wrote a letter asking the same question-as quite obviously one would-and said:
Mr Plant was nominated by the IAAF (and with the approval of Athletics Australia) as a Member of the IAAF Grand Prix Commission.

I will not go into any more detail on this correspondence, except to say that there appears, prima facie, to be a clear contradiction between that information which was provided by Athletics Australia and that which was provided by the International Amateur Athletics Federation. This seems to be the ongoing saga in this matter.

Perhaps this is the golden thread that goes through our attitude to the recently introduced legislation setting up a statutory authority for the Australian Sports Drug Agency. The reason we support the establishment of a statutory authority is that it is our philosophical view that we are not convinced that one can trust the officials. The history of this inquiry and the history of drugs in sport in Australia is that there is no evidence of an overwhelming, or at least reasonable or substantial, standard which would persuade any objective person that the officials, particularly in amateur sport, had the commitment and dedication to drive drugs out of sport. The concern fundamentally and essentially seems to be to cover up, to compromise and to pretend that there is not a problem.

One will find, I am sure, that without doubt Senator Baume will be prosecuting the argument for the statutory authority on the basis that it is necessary because the people associated with sport in many respects, at an elite level, cannot be trusted to act in the way they should act-that is, with a voluntary code of conduct of their own. I find that very sad. It was only this morning that I found an article written in the New York Times of 28 October-which is perhaps a bit outdated but terribly germane to my views. The article states:
The USOC-
that is the United States Olympic Commission-

which should really be looking out for the health of America's athletes as well as promoting level playing fields and ideals of sportsmanship, has been more concerned about its image and fund raising ability. When a cloud of rumours surrounded the testing procedures themselves, Dr Voy, the USOC's chief medical officer, resigned. The new chief, Dr Deborah Waters, felt a responsibility to get a handle on the problem.
Last April, with the help of Dr Yesalis and Edwin Moses-
as we all know, he is the 440-metre hurdles champion-

Dr Waters proposed an anonymous survey of all athletes attending the Sports Festival this year in Minneapolis. She realised that meaningful research can only be done with the help of athletes themselves. It was a much needed first step. Why, then, did Harvey Schiller, the USOC executive director, cancel the research after all the preparations were made and researchers were in the dorms with the athletes at the Sports Festival?
As long as there are more questions than answers, don't think, for one hundredth of a second that drug testing has done much to protect the health of athletes or to level the playing field.

That really summarises the problem we have in Australia. We cannot help but note these things, if we take even a casual observation of them. For instance, we had a long debate two days ago on the question of whether we ought to be advertising tobacco products. One of the people on the International Olympic Committee Medical Commission-the body which is essentially made up of prominent doctors, biochemists and authorities on testing, sampling, effects, results, causes and implications-Dr Klausnitzer, is in charge of the East German drug testing laboratory at Kreische. He was the head of the laboratory at the time that the East Germans were paid in hard currency to take drugs, when it was regimentation that all these East German athletes had to take anabolic steroids or other performance enhancing drugs. Absurd as it might seem to us, they were even having to induce gas to give them buoyancy in their swimming. As one of them said, the greatest challenge for them was not to win the 440 or the 100 metres; it was to hold themselves in physical contact until such time as they dived into the water. It was like a balloon under water.

Dr Klausnitzer is still on the International Olympic Commission health body. He has not been driven off. My understanding is that Mr Gosper is now a Vice-President of the International Olympic Federation. To my knowledge, neither he nor Mr Coates, nor any other Australian Olympic official has raised a hand or, more particularly, a voice in protest against this former East German, who manufactured and manipulated and ensured that these athletes took the drugs in a regimented form, or said that he should be removed.

I conclude by saying that I hope that next time we make a bid for the Olympics it will be received with more enthusiasm than Melbourne's bid was. I am moved to observe that in the events that flowed from that those States such as Victoria, South Australia and Tasmania that supported Melbourne and not New South Wales-which is now the heart and centre and soul of the Australian Olympic Committee-were punished in a very unpleasant way for their support of Melbourne. Each of those States nominated a person to be on the Australian Olympic Committee. Victoria nominated Bill Hoffman; South Australia nominated John Rodder; and Tasmania nominated John Watson. The other nominations came out of the blue-Keith Murton, David Prince, and John Whitehouse from those States, in that order. Their association with Sydney and with the elite sports was clearly identified.

What is commonly known in the trade as the bloodbath of that night demonstrated the pay back for those who dared support Melbourne on this occasion. Athletics Australia, for instance, gets half a million dollars a year of taxpayers' hard-earned money to indulge itself in sport for its own glory. I hope that those officials, when they are playing these games with politics, reflect on the effect that is having on Australia generally and the effect it had on the Melbourne bid. Everybody, but everybody, knew, when the Australian bid went up, about the politics involved. I only hope that when Sydney gets its bid up it gets our complete and absolute support and that the same sorts of politics are not used. I will raise more detail about that at a later time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —As members of a free democratic society, there are a number of principles which we must and should hold very dear. One of those principles is equality before the law. I think it would be remiss of me, therefore, if I did not take this opportunity to address one of the very grave threats to that principle of equality before the law, that is, recent attempts by the Commonwealth to put itself above the judicial process. Unfortunately, I am only able to be brief on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall approach it from the point of view of international law, for two principal reasons. Firstly, I believe that the obligations a state owes to its individual members are at least the same as the obligations that a state owes to an international citizen. Secondly, increasingly in this corporate world, the relations that governments have with the private sector are frequently relations between governments and corporate entities. It is a recognised principle of international law that large corporations, even if they are incorporated in the same state as the government in question, have an international character. That was recognised by the International Court of Justice in the Barcelona Traction, Light and Power Co. case, which was heard in 1970.

I think the starting point should be to ask whether the Commonwealth should effectively enjoy immunity from judicial process. This question is sometimes taken for granted. Certainly the obligation of the Crown to obey certain principles of judicial process was recognised as early as Magna Carta. There is a very nice exposition of the matter given by O'Connor in International Law, volume 1, page 841. He says:

. . . the most that can be said of customary international law is that it enjoins immunity from the judicial process only in respect of governmental activities that pertain to administration, and does not compel it in respect of other activities which are more truly commercial than administrative.

Mr O'Connor is saying that we have to draw a distinction between acts of government that are administrative and acts of government that have a commercial character. To put this in legal terms, governments can indulge in acts which are jure gestionis, that is, commercial, or acts which are jure imperii, that is, acts of administration, acts of government.

It is appropriate at times that the Government does put itself above normal judicial processes when we are talking about acts of government and acts of administration. Unfortunately, sometimes that is necessary. At the moment, we are in a period when governments all around the world-State governments, Federal governments, sometimes even local governments-are indulging in corporate activities and commercial activities.

We saw the Victorian State Government indulging in stock market speculation. I hope that most State governments, if they choose to indulge in such activities, are a little more successful than the Victorian Government. But a government cannot be allowed to rectify its commercial or fiduciary mistakes through the use of legislation. Nor should it take the opportunity to abuse its position as a law maker to its own financial advantage. When individuals abuse their power to their own financial advantage-for example, trustees in the administration of a trust-it is a matter that the law takes very gravely. It is only appropriate, therefore, that, if a government abuses its trust to administer the law fairly and equitably, we should take the same view. Lord Denning, in Rahimtoola v. Nizam of Hyderabad (1958) AC 379 at 418, said:

It is more in keeping with the dignity of a foreign sovereign to submit himself to the rule of law than to claim to be above it, and his independence is better ensured by accepting the decisions of courts of acknowledged impartiality than by arbitrarily rejecting their jurisdiction. In all civilised countries there has been a progressive tendency towards making the sovereign liable to be sued in his own courts; notably in England by the Crown Proceedings Act, 1947.
Again, recognition-this time by the Privy Council-of the importance of governments and sovereigns not enjoying immunity from judicial process when it comes to their commercial activities.

As I said, there is a distinction to be made. The question sometimes, however, is what is an administrative act and what is a commercial act? Sometimes acts are supposedly administrative in nature but have such an overwhelming fiduciary aspect-an overwhelming financial vested interest-that they are, to all intents and purposes, acts of commerce or fiduciary interest rather than acts of administration.

This draws me to the conclusion of this speech and the particular reason for speaking tonight. It was with great dissatisfaction that I noticed in the previous couple of weeks the introduction into the Senate of a Bill which was calculated from the start to deny a corporate individual the right to due judicial process. That Bill was passed today. I do not intend to canvass questions of retrospectivity but it was very clearly the case that the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1990 was introduced in an attempt to deny Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd a right to fair judicial process before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

I do not believe it reflects fairly or satisfactorily upon any members of this chamber-be they Government or Australian Democrat-who take the opportunity to put the Commonwealth above the law and above the rights of the corporate individual. People may well say that corporations are big enough and bad enough to look after themselves. Unfortunately, corporations are made up of many individuals-many small individuals-who each suffer the hurt that is inflicted upon the corporate body.

That is a matter that was also recognised in the previously cited case of the Barcelona Traction, Light and Power Company, which is a matter of major principle. I believe that this principle needs to be upheld. I believe that if the principles of open and accountable government are more than just words, they should be reflected by our deeds. If we are to live in a democratic society and if we are to have respect for judicial process, I believe it behoves us here in this Senate chamber to stand up for the rights of individuals, to stand up for the rights of corporations and to stand up for the rights of all of our citizens before the law to give them the opportunity of due judicial process and a fair hearing and to ensure that the Government does not abuse its powers in its own vested financial interests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad to see that the Manager of Government Business in the Senate, Senator Robert Ray, is in the chamber tonight because I want to make a few remarks about a procedure that took place today. I must say that this procedure has caused some concern among members of the Opposition but not the Australian Democrats or members of the Australian Labor Party who have combined, once again, to stifle effective debate in this place. The point I want to make is that during the debate on the application of the guillotine some incredible nonsense was spoken, particularly by one Minister, Senator Collins, who protested too much that, in fact, he had some kind of special access to the truth that was not available to anyone else, although how he recognised it, I must say, I do not know.
—At least Senator Ray had the decency to rely on nothing else except precedent.

—I think that is a nice point. One of the things that I believe must be replied to by the Opposition is the claim by Senator Ray that the delay in the legislative process in this place has been the result of Opposition obstructionism and time wasting. I thought it worthwhile in the circumstances to have a look at what the facts actually show.

SPEECH.PARA: When one looks at the number of Bills passed in the Senate prior to today, one sees that there were, in fact, 49. In the first two weeks of this Parliament, no Bills whatsoever were passed because, in fact, the Government did not have Bills to pass. In the third week there were four; in the fourth there were seven; and so on. It dribbled on and on. It dribbled on because the Bills were not coming into the chamber from the other place, not because the other place was out of the Government's control but because the Government had no Bills to bring forward. I sat here and listened to Senator Ray denying that there was any delay, apart from one little interruption, in the flow of the Bills into this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't say that at all.
—That was the clear impression that he gave.
—That is totally misleading.
—Good. I am overjoyed to hear Senator Ray correcting the false impression he conveyed earlier today.
—Your false interpretation.
—I am glad to hear that Senator Ray is saying no, he was not saying that it was us delaying it- it was his own delay. I am overjoyed if that is the inference of his interjection just now.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to deal with the exact facts here. How come, if all these Bills we have now been inundated with are so important-and we had a motion today, which was successfully carried as a result of collusion between the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats, to label them vital, important and urgent Bills-they have only come here in the last 15 sitting days?

Fifty-five of the Bills listed on the Notice Paper have been introduced within the last 15 sitting days. It would be very difficult for the Opposition to have delayed those Bills to the extent that the sort of remedy that is required is a guillotine. In fact, in the last four sitting weeks I think we have had something like 25 Bills passed. I do not know whether Senator Ray regards that as obstructionism-apparently he does. It is obstructionism when we pass 25 Bills in four weeks but it is sound Government progress to pass four Bills in three weeks.

What hypocrisy did we get today? All I want to do is put on the record what the facts are about this disgraceful performance by the Government. Senator Ray asked me by way of friendly comment across the chamber today, `Did you ever vote for the guillotine or the gag when you were in government?'. I have to say yes, I did, in the lower House. That, by the way, is a pattern and a practice. Whether it is good or bad, it is a practice in the lower House.

I am celebrating, along with Senator Walters, Senator Short and Senator Chapman, the fifteenth anniversary of our election to a parliament. We are watching the procedures of that parliament being subverted, the procedures of a House of review being subverted. The bulk of this legislation, which has been dumped on us in the last 15 sitting days, has in the main been gagged through the lower House with no debate. It is now being guillotined through this House of review with no debate.

Quite frankly, when I look through this list I see a great number of Bills which are not urgent to the extent that they need to be rammed through this legislature, whether or not they have been subjected to proper scrutiny. Senator Watson has told us that one piece of legislation in particular was agreed not to be sent to a committee in order to try to assist the Government if there was to be a decent opportunity to scrutinise it in the Committee of the Whole. When I look through the list of these Bills I wonder what the urgent need is for some of them to be put through in a state which may very well lead to further amendments, further corrections.

We were inundated with compendium Bills this year-compendium Bills correcting legislative muck-ups. I have been astounded at the number of Bills that have had to come into this place in this compendium form correcting drafting errors in Bills because they simply have not been looked at and examined properly. The Government certainly has not looked at them properly. Government members have not applied their great intellects to them, or maybe the problem is that they have applied their great intellects to them and that is why they are in a mess.

In recent times we have continually had correcting Bills coming through this place. One of the reasons is that we have this rush at the end of the session because the Government cannot organise itself. Towards I think the last week of the short session we had at the beginning of this year about 37 Bills hit us, as I recall.

It is a lousy way to run a government. I do not mind Senator Ray saying, `Come on. You are making the same speeches complaining about this as I used to make when I was in opposition'. I take that point; that is fair enough. But the pretence that somehow there is something especially phoney or improper about our objections and that they are really just objections by way of form rather than substance is what I resent. We are making sound and proper objections. Maybe even some of those that Senator Ray made when he was in opposition were sound and proper. But the way you and Senator Collins responded to them today suggested that you had no genuine concern or sympathy for the point of view being presented here. Quite frankly, you should have. They are the same points that you have made in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Baume, will you direct your remarks through the Chair?
—I am sorry, Mr Chairman. Senator Ray boasted about the fact that the same points were made when he was in opposition.
—Senator Baume, I do not think I am the Chairman at this point in time.
—Mr Acting Deputy President-and filling your role extraordinarily well in the circumstances. This is your maiden performance during the adjournment debate, if I am correct.
—No. He has graced us here before, and very well.

—In the adjournment debate? I should have participated in more adjournment debates. I will try to correct that in the future. I thank Senator Ray. I conclude by saying that the Opposition's objections have substance. The flow of legislation has been appalling. I admit that it was not helped by what happened during Senator Ray's absence. Certainly, the management of government business fell away from bad to appalling during that period. But I want to stress--
—Who was in charge?

— Senator Richardson actually, now that Senator Kemp asks. I remind Senator Ray that that flow of Bills was substantial. We have attacked it with some vigour. I believe that the use of the guillotine in a House of review, on Bills that have not been subjected to proper scrutiny in the initiating House, the House of Representatives, is a disgrace. It is a particularly bad way to conduct the business of the chamber. I look forward to hearing Senator Ray's second reading speeches on the host of correcting Bills that we will no doubt have to put up with next year, as we did this year.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Application of Guillotine-Drugs in Sport-Commonwealth Government: Judicial Process-Economy

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had four contributions tonight. Of course, Senator Michael Baume is a master of the adjournment appearance. He says that, if a person says one thing and then denies he said it, it means the opposite. This is an old journalist's trick. It is one that he is very proficient at. It is not a particularly good one, though, when it comes to real debate, real reasoning and real results. Nevertheless, it is the sort of muckraking approach that one would expect from an ex-representative of the fourth estate.

SPEECH.PARA: I would be interested to hear Senator Baume's views about the recent events in New South Wales, where the titular head of the Liberal Party, Mr Nick Greiner, kept the Parliament sitting for 33 hours on end for the end of year rush. It is not only this Parliament; the great Liberal Party Premier did that from 10 a.m. through to 7 p.m. the next day, for 33 continuous hours. Bar a meal break or two-not many-he kept that Parliament sitting for the last minute rush. I will search the record for Senator Baume's press release on that. Who wants to bet me that there was never a press release on that? Of course there was not; there was no press release at all.

Senator Baume went on to distort the debate. He said that I came into the chamber this morning and said that the sole reason for this situation was Opposition obstructionism. That is a direct untruth. I acknowledged this morning that there was fault on behalf of the Government for the end of season rush. Those opposite should go back and read the Hansard. I also pointed to the fact that there were several parliamentary statements, which was unusual, which also delayed the process. Senator Michael Baume coming in here tonight highly offended is knocking over a straw man.

He then came up with an extraordinary proposition. He wrung his hands. He actually came in here and confessed that he voted for the guillotine in the other place. But, after he was scrubbed out of the House of Representatives and after he had worked for the great John Howard for a few months, he came back here to haunt us-a reformed man. He had been on a road to Damascus conversion. He was no longer a guillotiner but a wimp. He has come into this chamber no longer the tough man he was in the House of Representatives but a marshmallow man. I dare Senator Baume to get up tonight or any other night and swear on a stack of whatever religious beliefs he has that he will never vote for a guillotine in the future. None of those opposite will-not one of them.

If Senator Baume's conversion is genuine, he has gravely insulted his colleagues here tonight. He has said, `This is a House of review and a guillotine should never be used'. But from 1975 to 1980 his colleagues sitting here tonight voted for a guillotine time and time again. There they sit-Senator Walters, Senator Peter Baume, Senator Durack, Senator Teague and Senator MacGibbon. They all marched into the chamber and happily voted for the guillotine. Not only did they vote for the guillotine; they voted to gag the guillotine motion. They did not even allow a debate on the guillotine. They came into this chamber and squashed everyone. Why? Because they had an absolute majority. That is why they did it. In 1980 the gag was moved at eight past eight and sixteen Bills went through by 10.55-democracy Liberal Party style.

The only difference between Senator Baume and me is that I am not a hypocrite. It never would have bothered me if it had happened when we were in Opposition. I would have taken it as being part of the natural course of events, but we have absolute hypocrisy here tonight.

Opposition senators have complained about Senator Watson's treatment. Yes, Senator Watson did want a whole day to be spent on the committee stage of one Bill. We have saved honourable senators from that and I think everyone in the Opposition may be grateful. However, as we were approached today on that matter we have agreed to convene the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration tomorrow morning so that Senator Watson can have his day in court. We did not have to do that; we could have gone ruthlessly through and ignored his wishes. We also made it very clear that we had moved the guillotine now-with six days debating time before the end of the session-to make sure that legislation was not guillotined on the last day. I have noticed an enormous lift in the standard of debate in this chamber today, as people have put forward concise arguments for the points they have made. We have heard some good speeches today and honourable senators can thank me for my largesse.

We had a few other contributions to the adjournment debate tonight. There was a contribution from Senator Kemp-an apprentice senator doing an adjournment run. I think that is a good idea-it gets the bugs out of the speaking system. I really think that Senator Kemp has done the Senate a grave disservice tonight. He has put out a challenge to Senator Cook and I have received a message that Senator Cook is now working on a couple of really great answers to questions next week to thoroughly and totally contradict the rather facetious and shallow speech that Senator Kemp has made here tonight. I am looking forward to Question Time next week to hear my great colleague expound these questions.

I have only one thing to add. It is said that there are lies, lies and damn statistics. Half-way through Senator Kemp's speech I knew that he would use the figure for 1982-83 as his point of comparison. Why? Because it followed a massive wages blow-out. Opposition senators always use that figure because it came after a massive wages blow-out when profit share was crushed and there would have to be a rebalancing over the next couple of years. Of course it happened because in 1981-82 Fraser gave away a centralised wages policy, which blew the wages out. Therefore, honourable senators use that figure.

TALK.START.PARA: —We use that figure as the base year because that is when the Government changed.

—Why does the honourable senator not try using figures for the years later or years before? Of course he will not, because like everyone else-especially economists-he picks the year most favourable to himself.

SPEECH.PARA: We also heard tonight from our great adjournment recidivist, Senator Crichton-Browne. Whilst I have not necessarily agreed with the way in which he has prosecuted some of these matters, I must assure him that we all support the stamping out of drugs in sport. I do not think this matter is restricted to one side of the chamber. People feel very strongly about it. I am still very disappointed that Raelene Boyle has never won a gold medal. She was not beaten through lack of ability, but through drugs.

TALK.START.PARA: —From the other people.

—Yes, from the other people. Senator Crichton-Browne made some comments about the Olympic Games. He started off trying to be hurtful to Melbourne. Let me assure him that, even though I am a Melbournite, I and this Government will do anything we can to support Sydney's bid for the Olympic Games, and we will do it enthusiastically.

SPEECH.PARA: Last and least we had Senator O'Chee's contribution tonight. It was a very unctuous speech, as always. My only advice to Senator O'Chee is that he should loosen up. I am not trying to be patronising, but he has to loosen up his style. It is great to quote Lord Denning, apple pie, motherhood and all the rest of it, but he should loosen his style up a bit and then I am sure he will make a major contribution to this Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Put my feet on the furniture?

—Yes, something like that. Senator O'Chee's major point, as I understand it, was that the rule of law must win out at all times. For that reason I expect a really big swing to the National Party at Boggo Road gaol at the next election.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 6 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What relevant experience and/or qualifications were possessed by the FISP advisers employed by the Department of Social Security as at 30 June 1990.
(2) Does the Commonwealth accept any legal or other, and what responsibility for, any negligent advice the FISP advisers might provide.
(3) Are the advisers required to make a written record of any assistance or advice which they may give.
(4) Do the advisers hold any and what licences or similar qualifications.
(5) In what respects will the FISP advisers who will be engaged as a result of the 1990 Budget announcement differ from those employed as at 30 June 1990 in terms of the above matters.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (4) and (5) The main purpose of the Financial Information Service for Pensioners (FISP) is to provide information for age pensioners and for those planning their retirement on the operation of the Social Security pensions income and assets tests, particularly with reference to the treatment of investments.
FISP Officers do not recommend or give opinions about the suitability of particular investments for clients. They are not licensed or qualified to sell securities or give investment advice.
In the 1990-91 Budget the Government announced an expansion of FISP with 40 additional FISP Officers.

In terms of experience and qualifications of FISP Officers employed by the Department of Social Security as at 30 June 1990 and those engaged as a result of the 1990 Budget announcement, there is no significant difference between the two groups.

All FISP Officers are experienced pensions officers and are selected for their ability to research, analyse and interpret complex financial situations, understand legislation and communicate well with clients.
20 FISP Officers were recruited before 30 June 1990 and within this group:

* 4 hold a degree or diploma from a recognised tertiary institution and all of these are undertaking the unit ``Personal Investment: Planning and Management'' with the Securities Institute of Australia. The unit is part of the Institute's Certificate course on the Australian investment and securities industry;
* 1 Officer has units towards a degree and is undertaking the full Certificate course with the Securities Institute of Australia;
* 4 others are undertaking that Certificate course;
* 8 others have completed the above unit in the Certificate; and
* 1 Officer has undertaken a Retirement and Financial Planning course at a University.
34 FISP Officers were recruited after 30 June 1990 to 20 November 1990 and within this group:
* 4 have a degree from a recognised tertiary institution and 1 of the degree holders is undertaking the above unit in the Securities Institute of Australia Certificate course;
* 6 Officers have a part degree or diploma and 1 of these is undertaking the full Certificate course;
* 1 Officer has obtained the above unit in the Certificate course;
* 1 Officer is undertaking the Certificate course;
* 1 Officer has an accounting certificate; and
* 1 Officer has a teaching qualification.
(2) Guidelines for FISP Officers specify that where incorrect information is given and a client acts on that information, the Commonwealth may be liable for any loss incurred.

(3) FISP Officers are required to make a written statement which summarises information given to each client during interview. The FISP Officer and the client both sign this record and a copy is given to the client.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 14 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it correct that changes to the `rising sun' badge were made in 1959.
(2) Did the changes involve the replacement of the words `Australian Military Forces' with the word `Australia'.
(3) Were there any other changes; if so, what.
(4) Is it correct that these changes are only now being implemented.
(5) Is this because the stocks of the former badge have only recently run out; if not, what is the reason.
(6) When did production of the new badges start.
(7) How many new badges were made and at what cost.
(8) What is the current stock.
(9) Are there any proposals to change this badge again, either totally or back to the former badge.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Changes were made to the `rising sun' badge in 1954 and 1969. No changes were made in 1959.
(2) The design in 1969 did replace the words `Australian Military Forces' with the word `Australia'.
(3) Other changes in the 1969 design were the addition of the torse wreath from the Australian National Coat of Arms and the inclusion of stars behind the crown and on the outer scrolls.
(4) No, the revised design has been used since 1972 on printed material and other items. The hat badge was not changed until existing stocks of the former badge were exhausted.
(5) As stated in the response to question 4, the hat badge has only recently been introduced on the rundown of stocks of the former badge. The smaller cap/collar badges have not yet been replaced.
(6) Orders for the new hat badge were placed in Oct 88 and deliveries were received in June 89.
(7) 7000 hat badges were supplied at a cost of $8800.
(8) Current stock is estimated by HQ Logistic Command at 2000 badges. Given the current usage rate this quantity will be sufficient until Feb/Mar 91.

(9) It has been decided that, coincident with the 75th anniversary of the Gallipoli landings and in keeping with the desire to foster tradition, the `rising sun' badge would be adopted as the principal emblem of the Army, replacing the crossed sword and kangaroo emblem. Before this could be done there was some amendment necessary to the 1969 design to ensure that it clearly identified the Australian Army. To achieve this the words `The Australian Army' replaced the word `Australia'. The contemporary community usage of the word `military' to refer to the entire defence force meant that a reversion to the original wording `Australian Military Forces' was not appropriate. The stars were deleted to allow for the revised wording and also because the seven major points of the badge already symbolise the States and the Commonwealth.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Small Business and Customs, upon notice, on 14 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Government assure Australia's small businesses that it has a serious commitment to the recommendations made in the Beddall Report, in view of the fact that the Budget addresses only three of its 66 recommendations.
(2) Does the Government have a time-frame for implementation of the Beddall Report; if so, what is it.
(3) Will the Government give a strong assurance that it will not allow the remaining recommendations of the Beddall Report to be disregarded.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Small Business and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government's full response to the Beddall Report was released on 13 November 1990. It addresses the issues raised in the Parliamentary Committee's Report, if not always adopting the precise recommendation made by the Committee. The Government believes that the response presents a balanced and considered approach to the challenges confronting small business and a solid basis for reform for the sector.

(2) Most of the issues identified in the Report are of a long standing nature and there are no quick fixes. In consequence the Government's response sets out the basis of what is necessarily a medium to long term reform agenda.

However, action is already underway where possible. The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) has commenced reviews of the sales tax administrative system and of compliance costs for small business. Mr Beddall invited representatives of the major national small business and industry organisations to attend the Second National Small Business Forum in Melbourne on 29 November to discuss the Government's agenda for small business. He has also convened a meeting on 19 December of all State and Territory Ministers with responsibility for small business to seek their commitment to a co-ordinated approach to small business issues.

(3) The Government's response to the Beddall Report reaffirms the Government's commitment to overcoming the difficulties facing small business in Australia. It shows that small business issues are clearly on the Government's agenda and that the Government has now agreed to the steps necessary to ensure that the work begun by the Parliamentary Committee is carried through.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 20 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the department have an estimate of how many of its clients currently have a tax file number; if so, what is that estimate.
(2) What are the estimates for each category of pensioner, beneficiary or allowee.
(3) What are those estimates for the end of 1990-91.
(4) Please provide details of all or any categories of client or classes of persons who will be exempt from supplying the department with their tax file numbers after 1 January 1991.

(5) For each class or category of recipients exempted from having to supply the department with their tax file numbers, how many persons does the department anticipate the exemptions will apply to as of 1 January 1991.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: — The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) &(2) Unemployment and Sickness Benefit (U&B) clients are already required to provide the Department with a tax file number (TFN). At 9 November 1990 536,580 current U&B clients had provided TFNs.
On the basis of a project undertaken in July 1990 the Department estimates that about 40% of total pensioners (900,000) have a TFN. Estimates are not available by pension type.
The Department of Social Security has made no estimate of the number of persons receiving family payments who have a TFN but expects the proportion with TFNs to be very high.

(3) The number of clients with TFNs at the end of 1990/91 cannot be estimated at present. The number will depend on when the legislation authorising the collection of TFNs from new client groups is passed and how quickly requests for TFNs can be issued. The rate of issue will need to take account of the capacity of the Australian Taxation Office to process enquiries and new registrations.
(4) &(5) The Department's policy on exemptions has yet to be settled.

The draft legislation provides for the Secretary of the Department under certain conditions to exempt clients from the requirement to provide the TFN of a spouse. It is not known how many clients will seek this exemption.

It has also been decided that full-rate pensioners over 80 years old and with a low risk of incorrect payment should not be required to provide a TFN. At 14 September 1990 there were 294,716 pensioners over 80 years old.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, during the course of the Estimates Committee of the Whole in the Senate on 12 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the new, tightened up procedures referred to in both the explanatory notes and the report of Estimates Committee B?
(2) How many of the 25 short term missions overseas that were outstanding as at 20 June 1990 totalling $108,723 have in fact been acquitted?
(3) Why do the four outstanding matters from 1984-85 remain outstanding?
(4) Does that mean that the Department is suing three officers of the Department who are presently employed by the Department?
(5) Whether there is one particular officer who has run up a series of debts by way of non-acquittals over a period of years, which amount comes into five figures?

(6) The internal audit addressed areas that were identified as being unsatisfactory or deficient in some ways and as at 11 April 1990, the recording of commitments for domestic travel costs, that is, all costs, and for the ticket component of the overseas travel costs were not being recorded.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Attached is a Departmental Administrative Circular of 19 June 1990 outlining the procedures to be observed by Departmental officers for the recovery of sundry debts and the acquittal of travelling allowances and temporary advances. Also attached are pro forma letters used by the Department in the recovery of sundry debits and advances. Copies available in the Senate Table Office.
(2) Of the 25 short term mission advances outstanding as at 20 June 1990, 21 advances have been acquitted by 23 November 1990. The remaining 4 outstanding advances total $11,986.55.

(3) As at 23 November 1990 there are only three outstanding advances from 1984-85, totalling $6,965. One advance was acquitted in early October 1990. The following are details of remaining outstanding advances.

An advance of $500 for meals and incidentals was paid to an Australian Diplomatic Courier for travel to the US and UK on 14 September 1984. The officer resigned from the Australian Public Service on 13 November 1984. Currently the whereabouts of the individual is unknown. Numerous efforts have been made to locate the individual using Telecom white pages, Electoral rolls and other available listings.

The remaining two advances for $3570 and $2895 were issued to an officer for a short term mission to Noumea, 21 August to 18 December 1984 and 19 December to 21 December 1984. The officer had completed the short term mission but had not acquitted the advances. The case has been referred to the Administrative Law Section of the Department for legal advice and action. The individual resigned from the Australian Public Service on 28 February 1987 and now resides in Brisbane. Advice received from the Australian Government Solicitor on 20 November 1990 is that the former officer has been contacted and that the advance may be acquitted by submission of a Statutory Declaration. This advice will be accepted and the amount cleared from our advances register.
(4) The Department is not suing three officers. The details relating to the 1984-85 advances are provided in the answer for the question on page number 3908 of the Daily Hansard of 12 November 1990.

(5) One officer does have an outstanding debt of the magnitude described by Senator Bishop. This is currently being investigated by the authorities. Any further comment at this stage would be prejudicial to the current enquiries.
(6) Travel and ADP Sections enhanced the Local Accounts Processing System (LAPS) from 1 June 1990 to allow the recording of the ticket component of domestic and international travel.
